Praefatio.	PREFACE.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	AFTER completing this book for you, O Sons, which is the last of medical science with its complement and having reached its end through its explanations and elucidations, it seemed fitting to me to complete it for you with this Treatise which is part of operative practice, that is, surgery by hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	BECAUSE the practice of manual operation has been prostrate in our region and time, and perhaps its science has perished and its trace has been cut off, and there remain from it only brief descriptions in ancient books which have been altered by hands, and errors and hesitations have happened to them until their intentions were closed and their way was made distant: It seemed fitting to me to revive it with the ordering of this Treatise in it according to the way of position, elucidation, and abbreviation: And that I may come with forms of instruments of cautery, and other tools of operation, making additions from explanations and providing what is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	THE reason why there is no good artisan of this manual practice in our time is because the art of medicine is long and its author must be trained beforehand in the science of anatomy which Galen described until he knows the ligaments of members, their forms, their conjunctions and separations, and has knowledge of bones, nerves, muscles, their number, their exits, and the pulsating and non-pulsating veins, their locations, and outlets.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And because of this, Hippocrates said that "a name with a name is much, but with work it is little, and especially in the art of manual practice.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	WE have already spoken about him at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	FOR he who is not acquainted with what we have said about anatomy will certainly fall into error, which leads to the death of men, as I have seen many of those who claim knowledge of this science without true understanding and experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	And this is because I saw a foolish doctor who incised an ulcerous sore on a woman's neck and accidentally cut some arteries thereupon blood flowed from the woman until she died in his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I saw another doctor who presumed to remove a stone from a man who had had it for many years, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	So he approached him and removed the stone along with a piece of his bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	And thus the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	For I had been called upon to remove it, and seeing its size and the patient's condition, I knew that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another doctor who was paid by a certain Duke of our land for his medical services, and there happened to be a black eunuch in his household who broke his leg near the heel. The doctor rushed in with his ignorance, strapped the fracture over the wound with bandages and tight bindings, not allowing the wound to breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he discharged him according to his wishes.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	After a few days he sent him away and instructed him not to loosen the bandage. Thus he remained until his leg became gangrenous, and so did his foot, leading to his ruin.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was then called for him and hurried to remove the bandage, and thereupon he found peace and was freed from his pain.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	But by that time gangrene had already taken hold of the limb, which I could not prevent.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Thus corruption spread throughout the member until he died.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another doctor who lanced a cancerous boil, and it became inflamed afterwards to such an extent that the master of the house was affected by its evil.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	That is to say, when a cancer is pure and comes from black bile, then it should not be approached with an iron tool at all unless it is on a limb that can tolerate amputation of the entire affected part.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And therefore, O Son, it is necessary for you to know that surgery is divided into two parts: namely, operations with which there is associated health; and operations with which there is danger in many dispositions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already indicated in every place of this book where an operation comes about that is fraught with fear and dread.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore it is necessary for you to beware of this and to keep it hidden so that fools do not find a way to speak and bring disgrace upon it.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore take the measure with care and caution, and your patients with gentleness and steadfastness, and use the better way to lead them by the grace of God towards health and praiseworthy success. Leave behind terrible illnesses that are difficult to cure, and banish from your minds whatever causes you fear so that doubt may not enter your faith and your ease.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it is more remaining to your glory, and loftier in this world, and ultimately better for you.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	For already Gallienus has said in certain of his writings.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not treat an evil illness, lest you be called a bad physician.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	And now I have divided this Treatise into three chapters.
Capitulum primum.	Chapter One
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	On the subject of branding with fire and branding with caustic medicine, arranged and ordered from head to foot, together with the forms of instruments and tools for cautery, and everything that is necessary for the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter Two
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	On the subject of cutting and puncturing, phlebotomy and wounds, and the extraction of arrows and similar things, all arranged and ordered with forms of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter Three.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	On restoration and dislocation, the treatment of dislocations, and similar things, all arranged from head to foot with forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	To God alone the glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Book of Surgery by Albucasis
Pars I.	Part One
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	On cautery and its benefits and harms: who it suits, the appropriate time for its use, and whether to use iron or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter One
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before discussing operations involving cautery, it is necessary to speak about the qualities of its benefits and harms, and which constitution it should be used on.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	Therefore, I say that the discussion about the qualities of the benefits and harms of cautery is a long and subtle matter requiring knowledge and secrecy.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	Many wise men have spoken about it, but they disagree with each other. I will mention only a little of what they say, so as not to prolong this discussion unduly.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	Therefore, I say that cautery generally benefits all constitutions whether they have matter or not, except for two constitutions: the hot constitution without matter and the dry constitution without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	But in the case of the hot and dry constitution with matter, opinions differ.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some say that cautery is beneficial in this constitution.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	But others said the opposite, that cautery is not suitable for an illness resulting from heat and dryness, because fire is hot, and it would be inappropriate to treat a hot and dry illness with something hot and dry.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who holds the opposite view says that cautery benefits all hot and dry illnesses that occur in human bodies because when you compare a human body and its moistures to the constitution of fire, you find that a human body is cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And indeed I say through his words that it has been proven true for me many times by experience.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	However, it is not necessary for everyone to undergo cautery, but only those who have been proven and trained in the final chapter on cautery practice, and who know the diversity of human temperaments, the disposition of illnesses within themselves, their causes, accidents, and duration.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	But with regard to other constitutions there should be no fear on your part, especially in cold and moist illnesses.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For all physicians have agreed upon these [illnesses] and have not disagreed about the use of cautery for them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And know, sons, that the secret of cure by cautery with fire and its benefit on cauterization surpasses medicine burning [i.e., medication], because fire is simple and its action reaches only to the limb being cauterized; it does not harm other connected limbs unless there is slight harm.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	But the action of burning medicine reaches also to what is far from limbs and perhaps causes an illness that is difficult to heal or even kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Fire, however, because of its subtlety and the goodness of its substance, does not do this unless it overflows.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	But we have learned this through experience because of the length of our service and study with this art and our standing on the truth of things; therefore I excuse myself for the length of my speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if this were not so, because my book does not permit it, I would bring you the hidden secret of fire and the quality of its operation on bodies in driving out its expulsions, which expels illnesses by philosophical demonstration that would sharpen your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know, O sons, that they disagree concerning the time when cautery should be performed, and they prefer different times according to the seasons.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	But I say that cautery is fitting at all times; for the harm caused by time is submerged in the benefit which is attracted with cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if cautery is performed on account of pains from necessary, strong, and urgent causes which do not tolerate delay; for it is feared that some greater mischief may arise from them than the small harm incurred by time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And do not let this thought enter your minds, O sons, that only the common people and foolish physicians consider, namely that there is no recurrence of the ailment which is cured by cautery. This consequence does not follow, nor is the matter as they suppose; for cautery is employed only instead of medicine which alters the constitution and dries up the humidities which are the cause of pains.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	But cautery prevails over medicine by the swiftness of its efficacy and the power of its operation, and the vehemence of its dominion; and it is possible that the ailment may return at some later time according to the constitution of the patient, and the location of the ailment, and its strength; and what is prepared in the body from an excess of superfluities therein; and what arrives at it through acquisition from foods and similar causes; but if there be no illness in which cautery is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	A subtle ailment in a member of few superfluities and humidities, such as toothache on account of pain, and the like, it is possible that such pain may not return.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But this occurs rarely.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But the common saying that cautery is the last resort of medicine is true, but not for the reason they intend. For they believe that there is no cure to be found after cautery has been performed or any other treatment afterward.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	The truth of the matter is quite contrary to that, and the intent behind saying that cautery is the last resort of medicine is not what the common people or many physicians understand. For when we administer methods of treatment for certain ailments and those remedies do not help, then in the end we apply cautery, which does help. Thus it becomes apparent that cautery is the last resort of medicine, but not as commonly believed.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	Ancient authorities have said that cautery with gold is better than cautery with iron, and they said this only because of the equality of gold's weight and its sublime nature. They also stated that cautery with gold does not cause pus to form at the site of the cautery.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But this is not absolutely true: for I have proven and found that it does not apply to certain bodies without other considerations.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And cautery with gold itself is good and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	However, when you heat cautery with fire made from gold, it is not apparent to you how much heat you desire on account of the redness of the gold. And when it cools down quickly and if you add more heat, it liquefies in the fire and turns into sheets.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Therefore, the artisan is delayed by this [gold cautery] and for that reason we use cautery with iron more quickly and conveniently due to its suitability for operations.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I have already arranged this chapter on cautery according to its sections, from beginning to end, so that anyone seeking information on the subject may easily find what they desire.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	Chapter 1: On the method of cauterization at the crown of the head.
Caput II.	Chapter 2.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	Chapter 2: Here is cauterization for the expulsion of superfluous cold and moisture from the head; which two are the causes of sod (i.e., epilepsy), abundance of flow of humors to the eyes and ears, excessive sleep, toothache, sore throat, and generally all ailments caused by coldness, such as paralysis, dropsy, epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar diseases.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is as follows: first, instruct the patient to evacuate with a purgative medicine three or four nights beforehand, according to the patient's strength, age, and usual customs.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then order him to shave his head clean with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then have him sit before you on a square seat so that he places his hands upon his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Next, place the root of your palm over the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Wherever your middle finger reaches, mark that spot with cautery.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then heat the olive-oil cautery over a fire; its shape is as follows:
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it upon the marked spot with gentle pressure, while you gradually tighten your hand and turn it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then quickly lift your hand away and examine the site.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see that a sufficient amount of bone has been cauterized or that the zeuherb has been burned enough, then lift your hand away.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	But if not, repeat the cautery with the same iron or another one if it has cooled down until you see the bones that I mentioned to you.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt and dissolve it in water; pour this over the wound and apply it to the site, then let him rest for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then put upon the same wound, soaked in butter, and leave until the burn is destroyed by fire.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with Tetrapharmacon ointment until healed.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	It has been said that the more open a wound remains, the more pus it emits; therefore, it is better and more beneficial to close it.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	Some have said that the skin should be cauterized up to the bone and hold the cautery until some thickness of bone is burned.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then it should be scraped away after what has been burnt from the bone; then treat it.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	Others say that one must reach the end with a cautery until it makes an impression like a brand on bone, so that the bone falls out like a letter in wax or the instrument women use for impressing letters on dough. They believe that vapors from the head are thereby expelled and that the wound should be left open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then treat it until it heals solidly.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	But to me these two methods of cautery seem useful only in certain people who are afraid.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And leaving him to rest with his health preserved is better, according to me.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	For the head is weakened by breaking its natural continuity; as we have seen with other limbs, especially when the head is naturally weak. The first method of cautery seems safer and better to me, which I use; therefore, operate with caution for the sake of health.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	**On the Method of Cauterizing the Head for Headache.**
Caput III.	BOOK THREE
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When chronic headache occurs and persists for a long time despite the use of diuretics, purgatives, head washes, oils, and plasters.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if the headache has already been treated with the cautery method we have described once without improvement; then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head of the patient is of strong constitution by nature and not weak, and it finds itself subject to violent cold; then cauterize with another cautery slightly below that spot.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize the very top of every horn of his head with the cautery without piercing the skin too deeply and exposing as much bone as we have mentioned.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize him with the cautery once on the back of his head, at a point called the "vessel," which is where the windpipe is placed; elevate your hand in this location but do not expose bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For the patient finds relief from that severe pain distinct from the pain caused by other cauteries on the head.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I shall call this cautery the "Vessel," and it is necessary that it be a cautery used for cauterizing the horns of the head and the back of the head more finely, which is also used for cauterizing the middle of the head.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	**On the method of cauterization in headache, whether using cauterizing medication or iron.**
Caput IIII.	CHAPTER FOUR.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When pain occurs in part of the head with congestion or extends to the eye and is treated with cleansing medications for the head, along with other care as mentioned in the sections on diseases, but there is no improvement; then cauterization is indicated in two ways: either cauterization using burning acrid medication or by means of iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	The cautery using burning acrid medication is as follows: Take one tooth of garlic, peel it, and cut off the ends on both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then make an incision at the location of the pain on the temple using a wide lancet until there is a space under the skin large enough to hold the garlic tooth.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then insert it under the skin until it is hidden. Then tie it in place with a suitable bandage and leave it for fifteen hours. Then remove the garlic and allow the wound to heal for two or three days. Afterwards, apply butter-soaked cotton to the area until pus forms. Then treat it with an ointment until it heals.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish, do this with certain cauterizing medicines which I have written about in the twelfth treatise on burning medicines.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	The cautery of it with iron is done in this manner.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	The shape of the cautery used for fire is like this.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called a "Claw" because its head has the shape of a claw, with some curvature and a small prominence in the middle.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it on the spot and hold your hand steady while you slowly turn the iron with speed. The amount that is cauterized should be as thick as half of its own thickness in the skin.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And lift your hand so that the artery below is not burned, and thus avoid excessive bleeding.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then soak the cotton in saltwater and apply it to the area, leaving it for three days. Then apply butter-soaked cotton followed by treatment with an ointment until it heals.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish, cauterize this half of the head with the second tip of the scalpel-shaped cautery.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And beware of cutting the artery in this half of the head, especially not an old one.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	About the method of cauterizing in an old half of the head.
Caput V.	Chapter 5
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When treating a half of the head, if previous treatments and divisions of diseases do not suffice, and you see that the condition requires further intervention beyond the first cautery with medicine or fire cautery, then use the scalpel-shaped cautery heated over fire until it turns white. Mark the location of pain with a line about half a finger's length or slightly longer. Then place your hand once and press firmly until you cut the artery and reach the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	However, you must be careful to avoid damaging the lower jawbone that moves during chewing, lest the side or the nerve controlling it be burned, causing spasm.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And be mindful of caution and care regarding blood flow from the cut artery.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For in cutting it there is fear, especially for one who is ignorant of what he does and is neither studious nor experienced. For such a person should not undertake this operation first.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I will come with a reminder of managing blood flow after an arterial injury according to its nature and location, in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you find that this cautery is not sufficient for the condition and observe that the patient's body cannot tolerate further cauterization in the middle of the head as mentioned earlier, then treat the wound until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, use the cautery described in the chapter on arterial ligation with a cautery having two blades.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For this cauterization is better and more effective.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	ON THE METHOD OF CAUTERIZATION FOR EAR PAIN
Caput VI.	Chapter 6
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When pain occurs in the ear due to coldness and is treated with remedies and other treatments mentioned earlier but the pain does not subside, then use a cautery heated over fire. This type of cautery is called "The Point," and its shape is as follows:
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then apply this heated point around the entire ear, or around both ears if pain is felt in both.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And extend the cautionary [cautery] from the root of the ear slightly afterwards, after you have marked the places with caustic; and let the quantity of the cautery be ten points on each ear, like those.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then treat the spots until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	On the Method of Cauterizing in Torment.
Caput VII.	CHAPTER VII
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	The torture that is treated with cautery is only of those kinds which arise from humors, according to what we have said in the divisions of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And avoid cauterizing species that arise from drying out and nerve spasm.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this kind of torture with heat, and purgatives, and gargarisms, and your treatment does not help, then it is necessary to cauterize the patient with three cauteries: one at the root of the ear, and the second a little below its own tympanum, and the third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cautery on the opposite side of the affected part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For softening does not occur except in the part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of cautery is that you should cauterize with a cautery on the direct extremity of the upper ear beneath the horn of the head, and another on the tympanum; whose length shall be according to the length of a thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And hold your hand with the cautery until it burns through half the thickness of the skin.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the cautery, and it is a species of scalpel, whose shape is as shown above; but do not make it too delicate, as you see; rather, let there be a little extra thickness on the blade.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then treat the spots with what preceded until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	On the Method of Cauterizing in Ancient Apoplexy
Caput VIII.	CHAPTER VIII
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When apoplexy becomes chronic and you treat it with what we have said, but your treatment does not help, and the patient does not have a fever, then cauterize him with four cauteries on every horn of his head, and one in the middle of the head, as we have said, and one at the back of the head, according to what has been mentioned before; and the manner of cautery shall be according to what has been mentioned before.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	Also, cauterize with a cautery on the stomach bone: this is the last resort.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat him according to what has been mentioned before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	On the manner of cauterizing in Paralysis
Caput IX.	CHAPTER IX
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that the patient be given first a large draught of barley water and cleansing pills for the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then shave the entire head of the patient and place upon his occiput a plaster made from treacle, as described in the treatise on plasters; and apply it repeatedly.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	For this is the manner of cautery: and do it according to the same order which I have mentioned above.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If therefore he is healed thereby, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	But if not, then make three cauteries on the back part of his head, running from the top of the head down to the bottom of the eye; and place a thickness equal to a finger's width between each cautery.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat the cautery with what has been mentioned before.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	But if you wish to add more and the patient is able to endure it, then make a cautery in the middle [of his head].
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	If you wish to add more, then cauterize him on both horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then treat him until he is healed; and let the cautery be oily according to the shape which has been mentioned before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	On the manner of cautering in Paralysis and Softening
Caput X.	CHAPTER X
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary that you proceed with cleansing the head with barley water, and with what we have said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then shave the head of the patient; afterwards cauterize him with a cautery in the middle of his head, and with one on every horn of his head, and with one on the back of his neck, and three on the shoulders of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	But if you desire to mollify the body by cauterization in many places, and the patient is able to bear it, and the sickness is strong: then cauterize him with four cauteries on the shoulders of his back, and one last cautery, until the skin is burnt as much as possible; and raise your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then care for him until he recovers: and thus conclude with the cautery of Oil.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	On the manner of cauterizing in Epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter XI
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	The epileptic is not to be cauterized unless his epilepsy is from phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Therefore you should cleanse his brain first with hysop and with the remainder of the treatment which we have spoken of in division: when the patient is great or bears well the reception of medications.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	But if he is a child who does not bear medicines, then give him gargarisms and cleansing chewings of the brain, before that for many days with good diet.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then shave his head, afterwards cauterize him with one cautery in the middle of his head, according to what has been previously stated in manner; and another cautery on his nape, and on every horn of his head one cautery.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	But if the patient is strong and bears well, then cauterize him with the cauteries which I have mentioned in one having paralysis, and mollify the body with cauteries on the shoulders of the neck, and on those of the back: and let the cautery be of oil according to the manner previously stated.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	But if the patient is a child, then place a thin cautery, according to this manner.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	On the manner of cauterizing in Melancholy.
Caput XII.	Chapter XII
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholy are corrupt humors and thick phlegm, then cauterize him with cauteries which we have spoken of in one having paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is an excess leaning towards melancholy, and the body of the sick is moist, then give him to drink something that cleanses his brain according to what has preceded in division: then shave the head of the sick, and afterwards make a bandage decently made from linen like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of the head: and let the sick person sit squarely held on every side.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present the ointment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is more proper from old sheep butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And heat it over a fire with moderate heating, such that the finger can tolerate when inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then pour it on the middle of his head in a circle, and let it remain until it cools down.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this for the sick person once each week along with his other good regimen until he is healed.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterize him by making many small punctures on it except for where you hold the cautery: indeed let there be a pleasant smell.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this type of cautery moistens the brain with quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place over it a cloth soaked in butter or chicken fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	§ On the manner of cauterizing in water descending to the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When you have determined the beginning of water descending to the eye through signs which I spoke of in division, then begin and give the sick person something to drink that cleanses his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And protect him from all moistures, and make him sit in a bath for several days while fasting.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then order him to shave his head, and cauterize him on the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize him over the two temples with two cauteries if there is a beginning of water descending into both eyes at once, or on one side if there is a beginning of water in one eye only; and cut off with the cautery all veins and arteries that are under the skin; and let the cauteries be long in width according to the temples; and take care against the flow of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	But if you see anything coming from it, then cut it off immediately with whatever medicine is possible; and I will forgive with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and cutting off of them, and caution against the flow of blood.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And sometimes it is cauterized in the neck under two bones with two cauteries brought out last.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	On the method of cauterizing ancient lachrymal passages.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIV
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are old and continuous and there are visible veins and arteries on the surface of the head above them, it is proved that this comes from cold and phlegmatic superfluities. Then cauterize with the same cautery as mentioned in the beginning of water descending, placing one cautery in the middle of the head and two on each temple, and two under the two bones in the neck.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if you need to add more, then cauterize along the entire side of the eye carefully with a small cautery at the end of the eyebrow.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	On the method of cauterizing for bad smell of the nose
Caput XV.	Chapter XV
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you are treating it with what we have said about division and there is no improvement in the treatment, then hurry and give him three nights of chickpea gruel to drink. Then shave his head and cauterize him with a medium-sized cautery dipped in olive oil.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize him with the claw cautery using two cauteries on each eyebrow slightly under the hair.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And take care not to cut the artery.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the shape of the claw cautery
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	On the method of cauterizing for softening of the eyelid
Caput XVI.	CHAPTER XVI
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid is softened by sickness or moisture, then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery, using this crescent-shaped cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it above the two eyebrows a little with two cauteries on every part; and they will grow long in two times; and let the length of every cautery be according to the lengths of the eyebrow; and do not extend your hand too much with the cautery, but rather according to the quantity that burns one-third of the eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the shape of the cautery according to this method of cauterizing with a crescent-shaped cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	On the method of cautering the eyelid when hairs turn inward and prick the eye
Caput XVII.	CHAPTER XVII
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	In this case, there are two methods of cautery: either with a hot iron or with a cautery that burns with medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	But before using the hot iron cautery, instruct the patient to let their hairs grow out and become even if they are of the type that plucks them out.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	But if they prick him at their root, then constrain his eyes with a bandage so that they do not move until they grow out.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they have grown out and become even, then place the patient's head on your lap; then mark the eyelid of his eyes with a hot iron brand, making the mark in the shape of a myrtle leaf, so that the beginning of the mark is near the hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place cotton soaked in egg white or slippery elm mucilage on his eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then take the cautery of this shape with fire
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize along the mark you have made gradually in many places until the surface of the skin burns and appears like the true figure of a myrtle leaf.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of success for your operation is: if you see that the eyelid contracts and the hairs lift up at the point where they were piercing the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Therefore, raise your hand then: and let him be [for] three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place upon it a piece of cotton soaked in butter until the scab is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat him with ointment until he is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	But if some of the hairs return after an hour, and the eyelid becomes soft again, then cauterize that spot once more as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	But if the hairs are below: then cauterize them until they lift up to their natural place: and become even so that they do not prick the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	On the manner of cauterizing with burning medicine in this case
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is that you should instruct the patient to let the hairs grow until they lengthen and become even.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make from paper or cloth the shape of a laurel leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from known soap and from lime that has not been moistened each one ounce or almost that amount. Then grind them together with good kneading quickly so that they do not cool.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then take from it and spread it over the paper you made in the shape of a laurel leaf, and place it upon the eyelid of one or two eyes.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye cotton soaked in egg white: and let the patient's head be on your bosom.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your index finger upon the medicine, and press it gently for a little while.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you should move it whenever the patient feels the biting of the medicine because its bite is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While therefore that bite which he felt continues, then leave the medicine and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When therefore the biting has ceased, then remove the medicine and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And then consider if you see the eyelid lift up as it lifts during contraction with fire or with incision, that is good: and if not, then repeat upon it with medicine on the spot where the medicine did not impress and did not darken until your operation succeeds and the eye contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place upon it Cotton with butter until the burnt skin is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then dress it with diaphanous ointment or another until it heals.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary that you, during the operation, observe the last safeguard lest anything from the medicine fall into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	But if the eyelid becomes soft after some days and something from the hairs fights in the eye, then repeat the medicine on that spot which is softened by the eyelid properly, as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then dress it until it heals.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the form of the leaf of myrtle.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And know that human eyes vary in size and delicacy.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore according to this should be your consideration: and the way of correctness is not hidden from him who strives in this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	On the method of cauterizing a lacrimal fistula.
Caput XIX.	CHAPTER XIX
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you treat a fistula with what we have said concerning its divisions and the treatment does not help, then it is necessary to cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Instruct the patient to place his head on your lap and have a servant hold his head between their hands so that it does not move or shake with his head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then place cotton soaked in alum or in slippery elm mucus on the eye of the patient and then apply the cautery whose shape is as follows.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Let it be concave like the shape of a crow's feather quill at one end with which the cautery is made; and if you wish it to penetrate up to the other end, or if you wish it to be raised thus temper it.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	However this concave shape is better for your purpose.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express the fistula, if it is open, and remove the pus from it, and dry it out; and if it is not open, then open it and remove its pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place upon it a cautery that has been made very hot.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold your hand near the cautery for a short while from the eye toward the nose, so that your hand may not err or disturb the patient; and place the cautery on the fat of the eye, and burn it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If therefore you reach with your cautery from its beginning up to the bone, it will be well done.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not, then repeat the cautery once or twice more if necessary; and leave it alone for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then apply a dressing with butter and treat it with a drying ointment until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	But if forty days pass and it does not heal, then apply to it a sharp corrosive medicine until the bone is exposed; and shave it according to what comes up in its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of cautery for fistulas which some first said:
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Pay attention to the location of the fistula and find it; then place in its fissure a fine camel-hair brush, that is, a fine cannula, which has this shape:
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it a quantity of melted lead equal to one drachm, and hold your hand with the cannula steadily, and do not let the patient move at all so that the melted lead does not run into his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary to place over the eye of the sick person a dressing soaked in egg white or water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For the lead burns away the location of the fistula and heals it with wonderful healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	But if the fistula is healed with what we have said concerning cautery and treatment, then that is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, then it is necessary to perform a nasal surgery, and reduce the fistula back into the nasal passage according to what comes up in its proper place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	On the method of cauterizing labial fistulas
Caput XX.	Chapter 20
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Fissures often occur on the lips, which are called "hairs," and especially on the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	But when you are treating these fissures and the remedies we have mentioned in dividing them do not help, then take a small knife-shaped cautery and apply fire to it in this shape.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let its hollow be shaped like the fineness of a knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then quickly place it while hot on the actual fissures until the cautery reaches the bottom of the fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with a poultice until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	On the method of cauterizing an oral fistula
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an abscess occurs at the root of the gum, or on the palate, or at the roots of the teeth, and then it bursts open, and afterwards becomes chronic, and pus runs through it, and a fistula forms, then you must cauterize it with fire using a cautery that fits into the fistula in size.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert it while hot into the opening of the fistula and hold your hand until the heated iron reaches to the bottom and end of it. Do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then treat it afterwards with what we have said about treatment until it heals.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If the pus is cut off and it heals, that will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	But if not, then it is necessary to uncover the place and remove the corrupted bone according to what comes up at its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	On the method of cauterizing gums and softened teeth
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gum is softened due to moisture and the teeth are loose, and you treat it with medicines but they do not help, then place the head of the patient on your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then take a cautery with the shape that will follow, and place it over the tooth. Quickly insert the heated cautery into it while holding your hand briefly until the patient feels the heat of the fire reaching the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And lift up your hand; then repeat the cautery several times as desired.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then let the patient fill their mouth with salt water and hold it for one hour before spitting it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the tooth is strengthened, the gums softened are tightened, and corrupted moisture is dried out.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	On the method of cauterizing for toothache
Caput XXIII.	CHAPTER XXII
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When toothache is due to coldness either because there is coldness in the tooth itself or a worm, and treatment with medicines does not help: then cautery should be applied in one of two ways: either cautery with butter or cautery with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	The cautery with butter is made by taking fresh butter and boiling it in an iron spoon or a bronze vessel.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take some cotton and wrap it around the end of the heated cautery.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Next immerse it in the boiling butter and quickly place it on the painful tooth, holding it until it cools. Then repeat this several times until the heat reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you wish, immerse wool or cotton in cold butter and place it on the painful tooth. Then put hot iron on top of it until fire reaches the depth of the tooth cavity.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	Cautery with fire is done by heating a bronze or iron tube
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And let there be something thick inside it so that the sharpness of the heat does not reach the patient's mouth.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then take a cautery heated over fire and place it on that tooth while holding your hand until the cautery cools.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Repeat this several times, for the pain will be removed either on the same day or the following day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary that in applying this cautery, the patient should fill his mouth with good butter and hold it for one hour; then he should spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the form of the cautery
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Brand with whichever extremity you wish, as far as possible; and this is the shape of the cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	ON THE METHOD OF CAUTERIZING WHARTS
Caput XXIIII.	CHAPTER 24
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When wharts are caused by phlegm and cold moistures, and are not amenable to digestion through medications, and it is desired to digest them quickly: then use a hollow cautery, the shape of which is as follows.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open extremities, so that smoke may escape from the cautery at one extremity: and place it heated upon the whart once, and a second time if necessary, until it reaches the depth of the whart.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	But if the whart is small: then apply the cautery according to its size.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then leave it for three days, and apply over it a cloth infused in butter until what was burnt by the fire is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then treat it with toothpowder until it heals in the shape of a cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	ON THE METHOD OF CAUTERIZING IN HOARSeness OF VOICE AND CONSTRICTION OF BREATHING
Caput XXV.	When the voice is hoarse and breathing is constricted, as a result of cold phlegm in the throat: cauterize with the rounded extremity of the cautery until the smoke reaches the depth of the phlegm.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When humidities overcome the channel of the lungs, and especially when it is accompanied by coldness of temperament: then it is necessary that the patient first evacuate with solvent medications.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize it at night at the root of the throat in a depressed place: and be careful not to bring the cautery to the throat itself or to the skin except for a little bit of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize it with another cautery at the junction of the neck on the last vertebra thereof, using a cautery shaped like a nail according to the preceding manner.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat it together with what preceded until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	On the method of cauterizing in illnesses of the lungs and coughing.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When coughing and lung illness are due to cold moistures, and the patient has no fever nor consumption, and the illness is chronic: then cauterize it with two cauteries on top of the forked bone in sunken, soft, hollow places.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And cauterize it with another cautery in the middle of the chest between the two breasts; and let the cautery be like a cannula according to the shape which preceded.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.
