And if you wish to perform your cautery by pricking with a cautery called the "Point," the form of which preceded in the pricking of ear pain, then make the pricks from thirty up to almost forty.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat it together with what preceded until it heals.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And now let the cautery have three branches: according to this shape.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Therefore, the cauterization is alleviated when you make it with one cautery in place of three.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	On the method of cauterizing for tickling, in dislocation of the arm.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the forearm is dislocated due to moistures and does not return to its original position within an hour after being reduced until it becomes accustomed to returning, then afterwards when it is dislocated by a sudden movement as we have already testified about this matter, then you must first reduce the dislocation.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then let the patient be placed on their back or on their healthy side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then lift up the skin that is inside the tickling spot towards above with your left hand's fingers: and if the junction is dislocated towards the inside.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then take a cautery having two branches and heat it in fire.
Cuius forma est haec.	Whose shape is as follows.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then cauterize the skin until it reaches the other side, and you will get a figure resembling four cauteries.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And sometimes the cautery has three grooves, in which case the figure resembles six cauteries; the grooves are measured according to the fineness of the touch.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	This is the shape of a cautery with three grooves.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And sometimes one more is added to this pattern, making eight cauteries in total.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then place crushed garlic with salt on top of the cautery.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then keep the patient calm so that they do not move the limb at any time until it is strengthened.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation is towards the upper parts, which rarely happens, then cauterize it above the shoulder with a claw-shaped cautery or by making many punctures with cauteries.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the union becomes strong, and the moisture is removed; and the patient is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	On the method of cauterizing the stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When cold and much moisture accumulate in the stomach so that it is drawn away from its natural state and phlegm collects there, despite repeated treatments not improving, then the patient should lie on their back and extend their legs and arms.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three cauteries: one beneath the collarbone of the chest, about the size of one's finger, and claw-shaped; and two below this on both sides, until you obtain a triangular shape resembling three cauteries.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And lengthen them between the two so that they do not join together when they make pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the cautery be equal to two-thirds of the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And let the figure of the cauteries be according to this pattern without addition; and if you wish, cauterize with a large cautery in the middle of the stomach according to this pattern: and let the cautery used for this cautery be one according to the shape of a circle following this pattern.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And the stomach is cauterized by pricking it with this cautery: and it is as if you mark a point on the stomach according to the size that you wish with encaustum; then cauterize it with the puncturing cautery; then treat it with the treatment that preceded until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	On the method of cauterizing with a cold iron.
Caput XXIX.	CHAPTER 29.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When pain occurs in the liver due to coldness and moisture, or thick wind, until it departs from its natural condition through excessive discharge, and the patient is treated with what we have said but does not improve; then the patient should lie on their back and mark with encaustum three cauteries according to this shape and size below the hypochondria where the elbow reaches. And the space between each cautery should be as thick as a finger, and the length of the cautery should be straight, and do not press your hand too much with the cautery.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let the amount burned be half the thickness of the skin; and let the patient stand on their feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	But if they cannot stand, then let them lie down with their legs extended and arms raised.
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the shape of the cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And indeed it is possible for you to cauterize these cauteries with a scalpel cautery when there is finesse and prudence in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And be careful not to proceed too far in cauterizing so that the entire thickness of the skin is burned, for then the whole body will be burned and it will reach the intestines. Know this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	On the method of cauterizing boils of the liver.
Caput XXX.	CHAPTER 30.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When an exitura occurs and you wish to know if the boil is in the flesh of the liver or its membrane; then if it is in the flesh of the liver, pain seizes the patient with heaviness but without sharpness. And if it is in the membrane of the liver, there is severe sharp pain. And now you see that the treatment of this has fatigued the doctors.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	Therefore, the patient must lie on their back with their head raised.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then outline the location of the boil with a pen and ink; then take a hot cautery similar to a branding iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize with it once, until the skin is entirely burned and until it reaches the boil, so that all pus flows out; then treat it as an exitura until it heals.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	And this method of cautery should not be used except by someone who has long studied the art of medicine and whose hands have often dealt with such ailments through experience. Only then may one dare to attempt such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	But as for letting it go untreated, I consider that better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	On the method of cauterizing in Peritonitis
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients said that for cold peritonitis, a cautery with the roots of Aristolochia should be used in this manner.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And it is that you should take from the dried roots of Aristolochia one root longer than the others, which is found amongst them, and let it be as thick as a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then immerse it in oil and light it on fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize once with it between the continuation of the fork and the neck, and with two small cauteries slightly inclined downward towards that part which is under the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And two more cauteries inclined downward towards the back a little between the fifth and sixth ribs; and another cautery in the middle of the chest, and another above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And three cauteries from behind: one between the two shoulder blades, and two more on either side of the chest below that.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And do not compress your hand with the cautery, but let it smell openly the skin.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And some ancient ones have said that there are men who use a cautery made of iron like a branding iron, and they heat it and insert it between the ribs until it reaches the abscess, so that pus may come out, as we have described in the case of hepatic abscess.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But with this procedure using a cautery there is danger that either the patient will die immediately or a fistula will occur which cannot be healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32: On cauterizing the spleen
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you are treating spleen disease, as we have said regarding its treatment among the divisions of diseases, and your treatment does not help, then there are three ways to use a cautery for it, all of which are correct.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	One way is to make three or four lines with the cautery along the length of the spleen according to its shape, like those of the liver.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And let each cautery be as thick as a finger, or slightly more or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And the manner of cauterizing should be done equally as we have described for the liver.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not compress your hand with the cautery, and let the patient lie on their back with their face up.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	And another way of cauterizing is: heat a cautery with two grooves, as described in the chapter on dislocation of the shoulder. Then elevate the skin that is directly over the spleen where the elbow of the left arm reaches. The elevation should be such that the cauteries fall along the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then insert the two heated grooves very deeply until you penetrate the skin on the other side. Then remove the cautery, making four cauteries in total.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to cauterize with another cautery having three grooves.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then take care to allow the cautery to emit pus for many days after its use: it is more beneficial than all that preceded in treatment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	On the Method of Cauterizing in Hydropsy
Caput XXXIII.	CHAPTER XXXIII
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	A cautery is not applied to hydropsy unless there is proper dropsy.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you treat hydropsy with the methods of treatment that we have mentioned in the division, and the treatment is not effective, then it is necessary to cauterize it with four cauteries around the navel, one cautery on the stomach, another on the spleen, one behind the back between the shoulder blades, and one each on the chest and stomach direct: and let the depth of the cautery be nearly equal to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then leave the cautery open so that it may emit pus for a long time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	And do not remove the patient from treatment after the cautery until two intentions have gathered to him; then healing will hasten upon him with the help of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	But the shape of the cautery with which the belly is cauterized should be like a claw, according to its shape; and that for cauterizing the back should be olive-shaped, according to its shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	On the Method of Cauterizing Feet and Legs
Caput XXXIIII.	CHAPTER XXXIV
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When there is an inflammation and filling with yellow water in hydropsy, it is necessary to cauterize on the back of the foot at the junction between the little toe and the fourth toe; raise your hand with the cautery and do not twist it; then raise your hand again and do not repeat it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	For yellow water will be dried up thereby, and let the cautery have this shape.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make two cauteries on each leg, one above the knee and another below it near the middle of the leg; and make two cauteries on the hip joint. Leave the cautery open without treatment for a long time so that some water may be dried up from it; then treat it with the other methods that we have mentioned.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	On the manner of cauterizing in the case of an abdominal swelling
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When there is an abdominal swelling due to coldness and dampness that weakens the retaining and digesting powers of the stomach and intestines, and it cannot be cured by usual methods, you will find that the patient tolerates cauterization with excessive vigor. Then cauterize the abdomen with a large cautery above the stomach according to the previous method for cauterizing the stomach with a circular cautery, and four fine cauteries around the navel using a small pointed cautery. Also cauterize the side of the liver with one or two large cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if you see excessive dampness and the patient tolerates it, then cauterize the pubic region with a cautery, and also cauterize the whole hip joint. And perhaps you may add two small cauteries near the large stomach.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	For this is a beneficial treatment whose assistance does not fail.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	On the manner of cauterizing haemorrhoids
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When there are many old haemorrhoids or one large one in the anus, due to thick, cold humors or corrupted dampness, and they are treated with the method mentioned earlier without success, then cauterize three times on the lower spine near the buttocks in a triangular manner using three cauteries, and once below the navel about two fingers' width.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that his stomach is cold and his food undigested, and you see spots on his face, then cauterize him on the stomach with a large cautery as before, and once on his liver with another cautery and once on his spleen using a pointed cautery. Leave the cautery open for some time, then treat it until healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	On the method of cauterizing arteries after their excision.
Caput XXXVII.	CHAPTER 37.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you cut an artery, then heat the cautery that resembles a branding iron.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then insert the heated cautery into the cut artery until it reaches the opening of the vein from which blood flows. Do this once or twice only.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If there are many arteries, then cauterize each one with the cautery as we have described.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then treat them with appropriate ointments until they heal.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize him with a large cautery on the armpit, it is more beneficial as a last resort.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	On the method of cauterizing a fistula in the anus.
Caput XXXVIII.	Quando tu vis fistulam in ano, tunc erige eam per digitos: et si non potes hoc facere, tunc introito bistorto introduce in fistulam donec adveniat ad eius capud: et uide utrum fiat exitus de altera parte fistulae.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the patient does not obey a surgery and operation which we have described in its place, and fears it, perhaps he is cured with a cautery.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	If it happens that someone develops a fistula and it becomes old, pus flows from it, and there are corrupted humors.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	Therefore, it is more fitting to probe it with a thin probe
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then determine the depth of its aperture using the probe
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Next, heat a cautery that resembles a skewer.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then insert yourself the heated cautery into the fistula up to the point where the probe entered
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeat the cautery on it until all those corrupted bodies are burned, once or twice or thrice according to your necessity.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And beware of burning the nerve if it is there, or a large vein: or if the fistula leads to the body of the bladder or to the body of the intestine, then beware of all these places.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	And do not perform this procedure unless the fistula is located in a fleshy place and you consider that it does not penetrate through.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then dress the wound until it heals.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	If however the opening closes and no more material comes out of it, and this continues for a long time: then know that it is now completely healed.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if material does not stop coming out of it, then know that it is penetrating or there is a corrupted bone at its depth, or something else like that: about which you will learn later.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	On the method of cauterizing Kidneys
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When pain occurs in the kidneys due to cold or thick wind, and the patient's condition worsens because of it, then you should cauterize him on the flanks above the kidneys with a cautery resembling a nail, once for each kidney
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we cauterize him again on the same flank.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Therefore there will be three lines.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	So they will be more useful for relief.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	On the method of cauterizing the bladder
Caput XL.	Chapter 40
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When weakness and softening occur in the bladder due to coldness and dampness, so that the patient cannot retain urine, then cauterize him on the lower part of the abdomen above the bladder, where pubic hairs begin, using a cautery on the right side of the abdomen and another on the left: let the length of this cauterization be equal to the size of a thumb joint. Also cauterize him with an inferior dorsal cautery or two if needed, and let it be according to what precedes the claw-shaped cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	On cauterizing the Uterus.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When coldness and dampness occur in the uterus, preventing conception and corrupting menstrual flow, delaying its onset and causing pain during menstruation, then it is necessary to cauterize with three cauteries around the navel, as we have said in cauterizing the bladder, and with a cautery on the lower back or two cauteries: let the claw-shaped cautery be used.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	On cauterizing the Anus for dislocations
Caput XLII.	When the anus is dislocated and prolapses, it should be treated by cauterization with a hot iron around its base until it contracts and returns to its original position. Then it can be treated with poultices of hot herbs to promote healing and prevent recurrence.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When mucus moistures drain into the anus and cause it to prolapse from its place, and the sign of this is that one thigh extends over the other when they are brought together, and the location of the dislocation is found empty.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	Therefore, it is necessary to cauterize the patient around the rim of the anus with a cautery similar in shape to a circle: after you mark with a hot iron around the rim as it revolves, so that the rim falls in the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let the cautery have the same shape as the one used for cauterizing the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	But if this cautery is not available to you, then cauterize with three cauteries using a large olive-oil cautery, and let the depth of the cautery be according to the thickness of the whole skin.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	**On the method of cauterizing sciatica.**
Caput XLIII.	Chapter XLIII.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When pain occurs in the hip joint due to cold and dampness, and the patient is treated with what we have said in division but there is no improvement, then it is necessary to dissolve the thick humors by using foul pills or artificial pills and similar ones.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize him.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the method of cautery is done in two ways: either with a cautery using burning medicines, or with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	A cautery with fire has many methods.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	One method is to cauterize the hip joint itself with three triangular cauteries in this shape: △
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make their depth good or bad.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	Let the space between each cautery be as thick as a finger's width, and let the cautery be of olive-oil.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	Sometimes the cautery is made in the middle on top of the hip joint itself
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Therefore there are four cauteries.
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you wish to cauterize with a circle, whose shape is shown in the cautery for dislocation of the hip joint, then let it be one complete circle containing the whole hip joint.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the entire thickness of the skin.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the method of cautery for sciatica when the pain is attached to the hip joint itself and does not extend to the thigh and leg.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	But if it extends to the thigh and leg, then cauterize with two cauteries on the thigh, over the place where the pain is indicated by the patient, and make a fourth cautery four fingers up towards the groin, using a knife-shaped cautery.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the cautery be according to the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	But if the patient indicates that pain extends near to his toes, then cauterize him there where he indicates with one or two or more cauteries as needed.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if the patient indicates that pain is under the knee towards the leg, then cauterize him there with one knife-shaped cautery.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And be careful in all your cauterizations that you do not burn the nerves or a large artery, and thereby cause harm to the patient or contraction.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	I have indeed seen one and another among those who cauterized the groin too deeply, causing swelling in the leg until a tumor formed on the foot. The whole foot then became perforated and corrupted, followed by abdominal rupture and death.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	If pain is in two parts at once, cauterize both according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And wise men have said that this is the manner of cautery for sciatica.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a similar one from iron, with a diameter of half the palm. Let it be thick at its opening like the thickness of a finger's bone or slightly less, and let there be another small one inside it.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And let the space between each of the cauteries be like the thickness of the joint of the thumb. Let them be open at two sides and have a height of about one or two joints. And make handles of iron suitable for the cauteries.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its shape.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then heat it in the fire until it glows red and sparks fly off. Then place it on a dish of hot coals and have the patient lie down on his healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	Therefore, cauterize him with three round cauteries in place of one.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then let him rest for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Afterwards, apply a plaster with butter; and leave the wound open for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat him with ointment until he is healed.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis says, "We have used this kind of cautery infrequently, because of the fearsome appearance it inspires and because few are willing to undergo it.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	Nevertheless, it is among the good cauteries for one who endures it, and he will find its place.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	The cautery with burning medicines is made thus: you make two hollow rings into which the iron or steel pin descends that serves as its handle. The height of the rings should be such that they each have two knots, or nearly so.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And the distance between them should be about the thickness of a finger, and they should be open at both ends. They should fit together snugly in this shape.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then place it on a dish of hot coals while the patient lies down on his healthy side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And press your hand firmly upon the dish of hot coals.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour boiling water between the two rings that has been heated over the fire for a short time. Hold it there for about an hour while the patient endures its bite and burning. The pain will subside once the biting sensation stops.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then raise your hand with the instrument, and wipe off the hot water from the dish entirely with fresh water. Then let it rest for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And apply butter to it until the blackness of the burn disappears. Then leave it alone for several days until pus begins to flow from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	For it is the final step in healing.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointments until it heals.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	But if the pain extends to the hip or thigh, make for him a plaster containing water, just as you did for the ankle joint.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the method of hot water application, which I have already written about in my treatise on the correction of medicines.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take an equal portion of quicklime and unslaked lime. Grind each separately and place them in a new pot with a small hole at the bottom according to the amount that will enter it. Place another earthenware pot underneath, and pour over the quicklime and slaked lime enough water from a stream to immerse both by one finger's breadth. Then press them with your hand using good pressure, and leave the pot until the sharp water drains into the lower earthenware pot.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then collect all that water and pour it over more lime. Repeat this process until the water becomes renewed (i.e., reaches a desired temperature).
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	For then it will be very strongly acidic, and is administered in many operations of medicine and in the cauterization of other limbs.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	Because it performs the operation of fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And among medicines with which ankle joints and also hip sockets are cauterized, honey of almonds and lime mixed with soap are used, each being mixed thoroughly.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	And indeed, Galen recounts the story of a certain man from ancient times who was cured of pain in his ankle joint and sciatic vein by means of this treatment, which he greatly praised.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	And he said that he did not require any other treatment and that he was cured with one application only. He then said perhaps that after entering the bath carried by others, he came out of it already healed.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And it is to be taken from the green seetarag iris; and if not found green, take dry, fresh: and grind much with some fat, and apply it on achmus where there is pain, or leg, or thigh: and bind it, and leave it for a quantity of three hours, or until the patient feels relieved from the burning sensation.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then let him be put into a bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When therefore his body becomes moist, then let him be put on a seat.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain ceases and he is healed.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And know that no one should use a cautery with these medicines unless after evacuating the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides also said that goat dung, when cauterized with it, benefits the sciatic vein; and a cautery is made in this manner.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Take wool and soak it with old oil, and put it on the deep place which is between the thumb of the foot and the heel, closer to the heel.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take dry goat dung and burn it in fire until it becomes charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then place it on the wool, and leave it until it is extinguished.
Deinde itera illud.	Then repeat this process.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	Do not cease doing this until the sensation reaches to the ankle and the pain ceases.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this method of cautery is called the 'Goat's cautery'.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	¶ On cauterizing a backache
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	Sometimes pain occurs in the back due to various causes such as accident or injury, or evacuation of excess matter and similar things, from the infusion of cold and moist matter. And cautery is indeed not necessary except in this particular case which arises from the infusion of cold matter.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	Therefore, after evacuating the patient with foul-smelling pills and similar things, three lines should be made according to the width of their back where the pain is. Then signs should be marked with a hot iron in every line five cauteries, or more depending on the amount that comes from the tolerance of the patient's strength. And cauterization should be performed with cautery points.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, cauterize with three or four cauteries using the middle nail cautery, in this shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	Chapter: Method of Cauterizing at the Beginning of a Tumor
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This ailment often occurs in young children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of its beginning in children is that there occurs upon them a constriction with panting upon elevation and movement. And you will find on the last vertebra of the back and its nodes that it has already begun to rise above the rest of the vertebrae.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When you see this [tumor], and wish to treat it, then cauterize it with a cautery that is circular in this shape.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And let the cautery be placed evenly over all parts of the vertebra. And if you wish, cauterize around the vertebra with the cautery point two or three lines, and let the points be close together.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then treat the place until it is healed according to what we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And take care not to administer a cautery to a tumor that arises from nerve spasm.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	Chapter: Method of Cauterizing in Gout and Joint Pains
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When pains in the joints are caused by cold moistures which flow to any part of the body, then when such pains occur in the feet, it is customary among physicians to call that Podagra properly.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	Therefore, when Podagra is treated with remedies for cold causes and the pains are not removed, then a cautery removes them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is, that one should cauterize him after evacuation around the joint of the feet with many cauteries; and let the cautery be olive-oil.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its shape.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you wish to make points on the surface of the foot, then do so with a cautery.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	But if the pains ascend to the knees or other joints and this happens often, then cauterize him on all sides of the knee with three cauteries or four, using the same cautery as before, that of Claudianus.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	But if more cauteries are necessary for you, then cauterize him accordingly.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	And do not immerse your hand with the cautery, but let it be about the thickness of the skin only.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	But if the pains ascend to the knees and the back, then administer what we have said concerning the cautery in its own chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	And if the pains are only in the hands, then make points around the wrists as two lines revolve.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	But if the pains remain in the fingers, then make points on each joint and on the palm of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If however the pains ascend after some days to the elbows or shoulders, then cauterize both sides on all parts.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not evacuate the patient from good regimen or from taking medicines.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if a good regimen is followed and phlegm is evacuated, he will be cured with the help of God using this cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	About the manner of cauterizing in Ruptures
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When rupture occurs in the groin and an intestine or a hernia descends to the testis, and it is just beginning to become noticeable, then you should order the patient to refrain from food on that day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And let him use gentle laxatives so that feces may descend from his belly.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Next, have him sit with his back on your hands: and order him to hold his breath until the hernia or intestine emerges or becomes apparent.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then reduce it with your fingers and mark with a cautery below the rupture on the pubic bone, making a mark whose upper end is like half of a circle.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then heat the cautery, which has this shape, until it turns white and sparks fly off.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then replace the intestine or hernia into its cavity.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then have an assistant put his hand on the spot so that the intestine does not come out again: and you shall now spread the legs of the patient and place a cushion underneath him, and another servant shall hold down his thighs, while another holds his chest, keeping his hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then place the cautery on the mark with your hand holding it upright.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold it there until you have burned through with it to the bone: or repeat the process again if you did not reach the bone on the first attempt.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And carefully watch during your cautery to ensure that you do not burn the intestine and cause harm or death to the patient.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	Know this: if you do not reach the bone with the cautery, your operation will be ineffective.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is necessary that the cautery for children be thin according to their size.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then dress the wound with the rest of the ointments until it heals.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And the patient should lie on his back for forty days until the wound is completely healed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	It is necessary that you give the patient food during his time of recovery which will gentle his belly so that the intestine does not protrude during defecation.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when he wishes to rise after forty days, then apply a well-made bandage and hold it in place for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And let him be spared from labor, excessive eating and drinking, and violent coughing.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when he follows this regimen, then he is healed with a complete recovery.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I will speak of the treatment of ruptures with incision in its own chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	But when ruptures occur in the rest of the belly and are beginning to grow worse, and you wish that they not worsen, then cauterize the rupture with a round cautery according to its size: let what is burned be like a third part of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then treat it with what we have said, and it will not worsen.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And some first authorities have said that a rupture should be cauterized with a triangular cautery in this shape:
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	After it is marked with the cautery, draw two lines across its width on the upper side of the rupture, and one line below that.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And place your hand in the middle with a claw-like cautery.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But the first cautery is easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	Chapter: On the method of cauterizing pains caused by a fall or blow.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter 48
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When pain occurs in certain limbs due to a fall or blow and persists for a long time without being helped by medical treatment, then it is necessary to cauterize with a puncture cautery.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And let the cautery be of a size suitable to the magnitude and thinness, weakness and strength, and location of the twist and pain caused thereby in each member.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If he is healed by the first cautery, that is well.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not, then repeat the cautery on top of it.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	For it is customary for these pains to migrate from one member to that which approaches it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Therefore you should pursue them with a cautery until the patient is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in Leprosy
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLIX.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	Leprous patients are sometimes benefited by cautery, a very great benefit.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the kind of Leprosy which is caused by the corruption of phlegm and melancholy: therefore when you wish to cauterize it, consider this.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If therefore the Leprosy is beginning, and you have treated it with what we said in division [of the book], and it does not go down nor remain still: and you fear that corruption will spread over the whole complexion of the patient: then cauterize him on the head with five cauteries: one in the middle of the head, and a second below that towards the forehead at the end of the hair, and two on the two horns [of the skull], and one behind on the nape of the neck.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And press your last hand with the cautery for a short time until it makes a small impression on the bone, and the skins are separated from it: so that the expiration of thick vapors may be alleviated from it, and cauterize the spleen also according to what preceded.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	But if the Leprosy is already spread over the patient and appears manifestly: then you should cauterize with those cauteries which we said for the head, and one on the tip of the nose, and two on the two jaws, and two on the shoulders of the neck, and six on the shoulders of the back, and one large one on the buttocks at the great tail, and one above it in its hollow: and two on the hips, that is on all the hip with one, and two on the knees, one on each knee, and two on the arms, and two on the softness of his chest, and cauterize him on every joint from the joints of his hands and feet, and cauterize over all the heels of his feet and the palms of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And take care not to burn the nerves that are on the back of the heel.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	And sometimes he is cauterized with a cautery over the breastbone, and another over the stomach bone, and another over the liver.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	Know that the more you add to the cautery, the greater is its benefit and help.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And know that the patient does not find pain in the cautery as healthy people do; because his body is already stunned.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And it is necessary that the cauteries be of such size and thinness according to the members and joints as has been mentioned concerning the kinds of instruments.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then prepare the cauteries with flour of barley mixed with honey, and the rest of the preparation until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	On the manner of cauterizing in stupor
Caput L.	Chapter 50
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When any limb is stunned and treated with medications, oils, plasters, and yet it does not heal, then cauterize the stunned limb with cauteries according to its size or smallness.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	Make sure your cautery does not penetrate deeply into the thickness of the skin for too long.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment until it heals.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And sometimes when a limb is stunned and paralyzed, it may be due to pressure on the nerves that move it, found at the exits of the spinal cord; cauterization can relieve this paralysis.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But let not one presume to perform this unless he is wise in the anatomy of limbs and the exit points of moving nerves.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	**On the Method of Cauterizing a Hemorrhoid.**
Caput LI.	Chapter 51
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When a hemorrhoid becomes old and does not respond to any medical treatments, then cauterize it with a deep cautery for a short time according to the thickness of its skin until the whiteness disappears and its color changes.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with flour of barley and lentils cooked in rose oil, along with leaves of arnoglossa, dove's blood, and starling's blood; take equal parts of each ingredient, mix them all together, apply the mixture on a cloth and let it adhere to the affected area until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	**On the Method of Cauterizing a Cancer.**
Caput LII.	 When a cancer appears on any part of the body, if it is small and fresh, cauterize it with a hot iron immediately to prevent its growth.
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When cancer is just starting and you wish to stop it, then cauterize around it with a circular cautery, going all the way around it.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	But wise men have said that it should be cauterized lastly in its center.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	However, I do not think this way because I fear that it may ulcerate, as I have seen it happen many times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	And it is better to cauterize around it with a circular cautery, as we have said, or with many cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	Chapter on the Method of Cauterizing in Adubelat.
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When someone has an Adubelat and is delayed in its healing, either due to excess moisture causing it or because of the patient's age, if they are elderly with little blood, or due to time constraints wishing to hasten the maturation of the Adubelat, then cauterize around it using many small cauteries with repeated punctures.
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then leave it alone.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For it will hasten its maturation on its own.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	But if you wish to make a hole in it with a cautery, then heat the cautery whose shape is as follows.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it in the middle of the Adubelat until it pierces the skin: let the cautery be as long as the following finger of the patient, so that the flow of pure matter may be relieved.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	Chapter on the Method of Cauterizing in a Corrosive Evil.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 54.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	Corrosion is nothing but corruption that moves about in a limb and consumes it, like fire consuming dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	Therefore, if you see a corrosion in a place that can tolerate a cautery with fire, then heat many cauteries, both small and large, depending on what suits the location where the corrosion is.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize it from every side until you erase all corruption, leaving nothing of it whatsoever.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then leave it alone for three days, and apply ground sulfur mixed with oil to the cauterized areas until all scabs and corruption are erased.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then care for it with flesh-generating ointments.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	If you see that after three days healthy flesh is born without corruption, then it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not, then repeat the cautery on what remains of the corrupted areas.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	Sometimes rotting flesh is healed with sharp medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	Indeed, it rises in the place of the cautery.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	Yet, a cautery with fire is quicker to heal. I have already spoken of cauterization with sharp medicine for division; therefore take it there when you need it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	Chapter on the method of cauterizing claws and warts.
Caput LV.	Chapter 55
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	It often happens in the lower parts of the feet that there is a painful condition: it is a thick, filtred matter that harms the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And there are two methods for cautery in these cases: cautery with fire and cautery with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	Regarding cautery with fire, make a cautery like an auger similar to a vulture's feather made of iron according to the size that contains the claw from every side and has sharp edges.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then place it hot upon the claw.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then roll your hand with the cautery around the claw until it reaches the depth of the claw, and leave it for three days until it begins to discharge pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then apply a plaster with powdered forest mallows mixed with salt, and leave it on overnight.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	For it will eradicate itself from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the place with a fatty ointment for the flesh until it heals.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	If they are not turned over and often occur on the surface of the body, especially in hands and feet, then apply cautery with hot water. Take a cannula made of bronze or iron or from a vulture's feather and place it upon the claw orwart.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then pour a little hot water into the cannula and hold your hand while you roll it with slight pressure so that the edge of the cannula impresses upon the root of the claw, allowing the hot water to reach its depth. Let the patient wait for about an hour until the biting sensation of the hot water subsides.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then let him go, for the nail will be removed with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	Do this one after the other until you have come upon all those that are in his body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then care for them after they have been removed, using ointments that promote flesh growth.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	On the method of cauterizing tremors
Caput LVI.	Chapter 65
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When trembling occurs in someone due to coldness of the nerve or quartan fever or any other cause, then you should cauterize it with four cauteries or five over the shoulder blades, one between each pair of them and also one on the chest and one on the stomach.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	For trembling ceases with an oil cautery, and health hastens the recovery from cold ailment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	On the method of cauterizing a bathur
Caput LVII.	Chapter 66
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	Sometimes foul bathurs are expelled from the body, namely boils, which are caused by decay of coarse matter.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	Therefore when they first appear, they should be cauterized with a fine cautery made of juniper wood, the tip of which is set on fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or with the root of long aristolochia
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or with a lenticular cautery
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	And sometimes they are cauterized at the beginning of their eruption according to this method: and they do not increase; and the excess that causes them is broken up, and healing occurs from them.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	But it should be done after evacuation with bloodletting
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	On the method of cauterizing bleeding from an artery wound
Caput LVIII.	Chapter 58
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	It often happens that blood flows from an artery which has been cut at a wound made externally, or during the incision of an abscess, or cautery of a limb, and similar cases; and it is difficult to stop it.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	Therefore, when this happens to someone, then quickly press with your hand on the orifice of the artery and place your index finger over it; and press it hard until the blood is blocked under your finger and no more flows out from it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Next, place on the fire a small oil-soaked cautery, and many others; and blow on them until they become very hot.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take one of them, either small or large, according to the wound and location where the artery is disrupted, and place the cautery on that vein; afterwards quickly remove your finger and hold the cautery until the bleeding stops.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	But if blood is expelled when you lift your finger from the orifice of the artery, and extinguish the cautery, then quickly take another one that has been prepared on the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Do not stop doing this until the bleeding stops.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And be careful not to burn the nerve that is there, lest another harm befalls the patient.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from an artery, it is not possible to stop it, especially when the artery is large, unless by one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with a cautery, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or with extraction, when it has not been extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, its extremities contract and the bleeding stops.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it can be tied with a strong ligature using thread.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or medicines of appropriate properties may be placed on it to stop the bleeding and then bound with an appropriate compress.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	But whoever performs the cutting of it with a ligament, and binding with cloth, or applying burning substances, and similar things, confers no benefit upon him except rarely.
