Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	But if this happens to someone and there is no physician present nor medicine: then he should begin by placing his index finger over the opening of the vein as we have described, and binding it very tightly until the blood from above the wound is stopped, and pressure is applied on the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger should not be moved from above it with cold water of intense coldness until the blood is frozen and solidified and cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	Meanwhile he should consider what is needed by way of cautery or medication.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	End of Book One.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis Part Two.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On Cutting, Piercing, and Bloodletting in Wounds and Similar Conditions.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have already spoken in the First Chapter about every ailment in which it is fitting to use fire cautery and burning medicine, and their occasions, causes, instruments, and forms of cauteries.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I placed there chapters from head to foot.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I will proceed in this chapter along the same path, so that he who seeks may find what he is looking for.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin this, know this, O sons: that what is in this chapter about cautery is drawn from the fear of what was mentioned in the first chapter on cautery.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And therefore it is necessary that there be greater caution in this, because in the operation which is in this chapter, there is often evacuation along with blood, with which life stands at the opening of a vein, or incision over an abscess, or opening of an exit wound, or treatment of a wound, or extraction of an arrow, or incision over a stone, and similar things: from all of these trembling and fear arise, and many die because of them.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you that you may not fall into that which causes hesitation, for sometimes people with various modes of behavior come to you in this art along with various illnesses.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	Among them is the one who becomes angry with his illness and is light about his death: because of the vehemence of what he finds from his illness and the length of its wickedness.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And there is fear along with illness which signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And among them is the one who gives you his consent and stays with you hoping for healing, but his illness is fatal.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore it is not necessary that you consent to him who comes to you from among them whose way of being is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let your caution be greater than your greed and avarice.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume upon anything from him unless after certain knowledge which verifies that his outcome has been successfully praised by you.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And use in the treatment of all your patients prognosis and indication as to what is suitably healthful for them.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	In that is your aid towards acquiring fame and glory, memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, O sons, with His understanding, and may He not take away from you guidance and inspiration: for that is in His hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And indeed I have arranged this Chapter by distinguishing it into chapters according to what has preceded in the chapter on Cautery from the neck down to the feet so that you may easily find what you seek and need from it.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	On the treatment of water collected in the heads of children.
Caput I.	Chapter 1.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	Know that this illness often happens to children at birth, or when the midwife squeezes the child's head without gentleness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And it also happens sometimes for an unknown cause which is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And indeed I have not seen this illness in anyone other than children, and it quickly led to death in every one that I saw. Therefore, it seemed to me advisable to omit the operation on it.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And indeed I saw among them a boy whose head was filled with water and the head became larger every day until it could no longer sit up due to its size. And the moisture increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this moisture collects either between the skin and bone or underneath the bone above the fontanelle.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And if the operation is necessary for this moisture when it collects between the skin and bone and there is a small abscess, then you should make one incision of about two fingers' width in the middle of the head until the moisture flows out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	This is the shape of the opening.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If the moisture has increased further and there is a larger abscess, then make two incisions following this shape.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the moisture is under the bone and its sign is that you see the sutures of the head opened on all sides, and water flows out when you press it with your hand towards the inside, then you should make three incisions in the middle of the head in this way.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision, remove all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then close the incisions with bandages and cotton wool.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then dress it from above with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then remove the bandage, and treat the wound with dressings and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not leave the head tightly bound unevenly.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the patient with dry food of little moisture until the limb is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	Another method of incision is to observe where the size of the swelling appears and the collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	For sometimes it is more at the back of the head, or on the forehead, or on the right side, or on the left side.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Therefore, make an incision where you see the swelling and collection of water: and cut it according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe that you do not cut an artery, lest there be a flow of blood and the patient dies from that flow with the evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	Paragraph: On the Incision of Arteries which are behind the ears.
Caput II.	Chapter 2
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When catarrh occurs in someone's eyes or chest, and it becomes chronic and not improved by medical treatment, then the last resort is to cut these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore, when you wish to cut them, make sure the patient shaves his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then rub the area with a rough cloth so that the arteries become visible.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then let the patient tie his neck with any cloth he has.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then observe where the vein pulsates.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And their locations are the areas behind the ears which are depressed: and they are rarely hidden except in some people.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark each with a cautery on both sides: and cut both with an acre-wide incision on either side until it reaches the bone: and let this be done across the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, insert a spatula under the artery and cut it towards the top with an incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be about two joined fingers.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when a vein is cut, blood flows out in pulsing jets which leap frequently toward the interior.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	But if the artery does not appear to the senses, then it is necessary to measure from the ear the quantity of space of three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with a cautery and find until it reaches the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And that which ought to be emitted from the blood is six drachms, but perhaps you emit more or less than this.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All of that according to the quantity which appears to you from the strength of the patient and the fullness of his artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	If there remains anything on the bone from the incision, then cut it off so that no hot abscess occurs; then bind the wound with linen bandages.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment until it heals.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	On the extraction of arteries that are in the temples.
Caput III.	Chapter 3.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When a person has an old headache or acute catarrh due to acrid humidity and heat in the temples, or chronic soda and similar conditions, and it is treated with medical methods without improvement: then we have found that in these illnesses, extraction of the arteries from the temples or cauterization of them, as we have described.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of operation for extracting them is: shave the hair from the temples of the patient and expose the visible artery in the temple.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	For indeed it appears to you by its pulsation, and is rarely hidden unless in a few people or with great coldness.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	But if it is hidden from you, then the patient should bind his head with any cloth of his, and then rub the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or warm the place with hot water until there appears before you a clear manifestation.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take the scalpel which I formed earlier.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then strip away the skin with it easily until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then cast a hook into it and pull it out upwards until you have extracted it from the skin, and make it come out from its sheaths which are beneath it on all sides.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	But if the artery is small: then encircle it with the tip of the hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut off from it a portion according to the amount by which its ends will extend and contract, and so that there is no bleeding.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not cut nor severed, blood cannot be drawn out completely.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then express from the blood six ounces up to three.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	But if the artery is large, then it is necessary to tie it in two places with a strong doubled silk thread or animal sinew so that putrefaction does not come upon it before the wound has healed, and so that there is no bleeding.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut off the excess tissue which is between the two ligatures.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do this at that hour or another hour later.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with a cautery up to the bone with a lancet cautery until its ends are sealed and the wound will remain in its place.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And this is better unless the patient has a fever or is of hot temperament.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	For cautery is one of those things which help to finish off dampness.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is better help.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And after the extraction of arteries, it is necessary that the place be filled with old wax and that powder made properly be placed upon it.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And afterwards, care should be taken with dry medicines which cause flesh to grow, and with bandages until healed.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if meanwhile during the operation there occurs bleeding from an artery, then quickly apply a cautery to cut it off, or fill the place with wax, and press your hand until the bleeding stops.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	But if none of these is present to you, then put your finger on the place until the blood coagulates.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And cool the place with water of intense coldness until sharp pain subsides and it is bound as necessary.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And for an easier and lighter extraction of the artery, use this cautery which has two blades: let the sharpness of both blades be like an Almagest.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	But they are much less sharp than the two blades themselves.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	For if they are as sharp as the two blades, both become cold quickly and do not cut flesh swiftly.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	Therefore, since there is some thickness in them, the heat of fire is retained within them and flesh is cut quickly. Therefore this method is better than any other, easier, and lighter.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space between the two blades be equal to the thickness of a finger. After you have marked two places with the cautery, place both burning blades until they reach the bone and cut the artery in two places so that it may lengthen between its ends.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For they are not completely sealed by this cautery.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the shape of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	About treating the frequent and sharp pain in the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When tears are frequent and their flow comes from veins on the outside of the skull, and no cure can be effected with medicines, and you see the face of the patient already reddened, and he feels a crawling sensation on his forehead like that of ants, and his eyes are wasted, wet, so that the lashes have become worn away by corrosion, and his eyelids are hot from the sharpness of the tears - then the ancients resorted to this operation for their cure, which they called "cure with the knife.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	Then it is necessary to order the patient to shave the hairs on his forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three incisions on the forehead equidistant from each other along its length; let each incision be about two fingers in length. The first should be evenly spaced with the length of the nose at the middle of the forehead, and the second slightly towards the temple, while the third is on the opposite side. Take care not to cut the arteries present on both sides. Keep your hand away from the continuity of the two jaws, ensuring that the total length of all incisions equals the breadth of three joined fingers. Have a piece of sponge or dry cloth ready to absorb blood and wipe it dry.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then insert a spatula with two sharp ends, shaped as follows:
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision at the temple to the second one, scrape off with it all the skin that is between the two incisions down to the bone.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do the same from the middle incision to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Next, remove this spatula and insert into the first incision another tool called a sharp scalpel with one side blunt and not sharp.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape:
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	Place the sharp side of it facing the flesh attached to the skin and the blunt side towards the bone. Push it until it reaches the middle incision and cut all vessels that descend from the head to the eyes with it, except for those that continue along the incision up to where the skin appears.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do likewise on the other side of the incision.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And after an equal amount of blood has flowed out, squeeze out the areas containing clots of blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place a linen strip made from old cloth into every incision and put on top of them lint soaked in wine, oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And see to it that no hot abscess occurs.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	On the third day, remove the stitches and apply a lot of warm water infusion.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with balsam ointment and other remedies used for wounds until it heals.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	Chapter on the treatment of acute weeping and inflammation of the eyes coming from inside the head
Caput V.	Chapter Five.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When acute cataracts occur with sharp and persistent pain, and you see the eyes becoming thin, small, and their appearance weakened; and the eyelids are ulcerated, with hairs falling out from them, and there is sharp pain in the deep part of the head with subsequent sneezing: then know that these materials and cataracts do not come except from many veins.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And the best treatment for them is this:
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	Moreover, you should order the patient to shave their forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Next, make one incision in the middle of the forehead, or slightly broader on either side, and begin from the left ear to the right ear: let the incision reach down to the bone. Extend your hand away from the temple muscles that move during mastication until you expose the bone. Then dry up all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate the two lips of the wound using cooked wool or linen cloths.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Next, tie above with cotton pads. Soak the cotton pads in wine and oil to prevent an abscess from forming.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you release it, if you see that the hot abscess has decreased, then you must continue to scrape the bone until flesh begins to grow on it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then treat it with a drying regimen that promotes flesh growth, like this: Take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony, prepare an ointment from them, and apply it to the place where the flesh has grown on these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	And regarding its treatment if it falls into the ear.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Anything that falls into the ear is of four kinds: either a mineral stone, or something similar to a stone like iron and glass; or it is from a plant like chickpeas and beans; or it is a liquid thing like water and vinegar and things like them; or some kind of animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When a stone or something similar that does not stick to nor grow in the ear falls into it, expose the ear to the sun. If you see the stone, then drip some violet oil or mustard onto the ear.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then perform the extraction and make them sneeze with powdered spikenard. Plug their nostrils at the onset of sneezing, after you place pieces of cloth or wool around the ear and extend it upwards.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	For many times it exits with this treatment.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	But if it does not exit, then perform the extraction using tweezers called 'Gestii,' that is, fine forceps. Its shape is as follows:
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If it comes out with the forceps, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then perform the extraction using a fine crooked hook with few loops.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If it does not come out through that, then make a tube of bronze and insert the tip of the tube into the ear as far as possible. Then fill what is around the tube with softened wax mixed with oil so that there is no path for wind except through the tube; then draw it out with your strong breath.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	For oftentimes it comes out with that which we have described.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	But if it does not come out this way: then take a little of 'helkalimbat' or prepared glue used to catch birds, and place it on the tip of a reed that has been covered with cotton; then gently insert it into the ear after you have dried it.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	But if it does not come out despite all that we have described, then hurry to cut into it before a hot abscess or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	The method of cutting is as follows: first bleed the patient from the cephalic vein and draw out blood according to their strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then have the patient sit between your hands and turn their ear upwards. Make a small crescent-shaped incision at the root of the ear in the fatty tissue where it is depressed. Then extract with the instruments available what you can from the stone.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then sew up the wound quickly and carefully until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	But if there is something falling into the ear from a grain that grows and swells: then perform its extraction.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	If it does not obey you to come out, then take a fine, thin spoon made in this shape:
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And use it to cut off that type of grain that falls into the ear. Do not attempt this if you think that the grain is already moistened by the vapor of the ear until you have placed many fragments on it; then extract them with hooks or fine forceps, or through suction as we have described, for its extraction will be alleviated.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	But the water that enters the ear, the patient should use sneezing first of all. After filling his ear with some warm old cooked water, he should lie down on that ear.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If it comes out through there, then it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not, then take many stones of the length of a finger, thin and soft, heat them slightly with fire. The patient should insert one of these into the hole of their ear and jump on one foot on that side, striking the stone in their ear with another stone.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	So he should not cease doing this with stone and stone until all the water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And now that the water comes out thus, take one of a feather or a rush, and insert its one end into the ear, lighting the other end with fire until it burns greatly.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then repeat with another rush and do this many times until all the water comes out. Then extract it with a cannula as described on the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	But in removing an animal that has entered into it, if it is small-bodied, like a louse, and similar ones, treat it as I have said in division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is of large body that appears to the senses, then use forceps and hooks for its removal. And this matter is easier than all those held in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	But in the removal of a worm generated in the ear, when you treat it with what we have said in division and in the treatise on distillations, and your treatment does not help, then you should look at the ear in sunlight.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If something appears there from worms, then remove it with forceps or with fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	But if nothing appears there, then take a cannula of this shape - narrow at the bottom, wide at the top - and insert its fine end into the ear according to what the patient can tolerate. Then suck out with strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do this many times until all the worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	But if they do not obey you to exit, then seal around the cannula with wax, as I said on stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	But if they do not come out with what we have said, then administer the distillations which the ancients have proven effective against worms, and you will find them in the treatise on distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your pouring be such that when you pour oil and medicines into the ear with this instrument, its shape is as depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	Make it like this out of silver or bronze, narrow below where there is a small hole, wide above.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	So let the pusher that is inside the concave part of the cannula be made of well-made bronze.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a rod and wrap cotton at its end in a suitable wrapping. Then throw oil or juice, or whichever of these medicines you want into the cannula, and let it be in the ear. Then insert the rod with cotton from above and press it with your hand using moderate pressure until the oil is forced into the concavity of the ear, and the patient feels it inside. And the medicine that is poured into the ear should have been warmed for a short time with fire, and be careful not to use something very cold to distill, because medicines do not tolerate this.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	On the treatment of accidental discharge from the Ear.
Caput VII.	Chapter 7.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Sometimes infants are born from their mothers' wombs unperforated.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it has also happened that some people have had an obstruction in the ear due to a wound or flesh growing inside it.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And sometimes this obstruction occurs deep within the ear canal and cannot be seen, but at other times it occurs near the entrance of the ear canal and can be seen.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	Therefore, obstructions that occur deep within the ear and cannot be seen are difficult to treat in most cases.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And for those obstructions that can be seen, place the patient's ear in the sunlight and examine it. If you see an apparent obstruction, open it with a fine, curved instrument whose tip has a small width with one part sharp, while the rest of the instrument is smooth on both sides so as not to harm the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If the obstruction is due to flesh grown inside the ear canal, then grasp it with a fine hook and cut it with great care until all of the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	But if the obstruction is deep within the ear, then take a fine, smooth rod and warm it briefly with fire. Then insert it into the ear canal.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If you feel that the obstruction has been reached and the patient feels discomfort in their hearing, then try to open it gently. Be careful not to injure the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Next, place a linen pad into the ear according to the size of the opening you have found, soaked in Egyptian ointment. Do this for several days until you are confident that the wound has healed.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take a linen cloth, soak it in rose water, powder it with ground frankincense, and apply it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you see that the ear is already inflamed, then remove the linen pad and let it rest with another one soaked in a plaster made with olive oil and rosewater until the inflammation subsides. Then continue to treat it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If there is bleeding from the ear, then soak a sponge or cloth in cold water and place it on the ear. Then use the other treatments mentioned in this book to stop the bleeding.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	On the treatment of inflammation of the eyelids.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	Eyelid inflammations can sometimes be moist and sometimes dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore, you should hold them with tweezers or forceps and cut them from their roots using curved scissors.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then apply ground frankincense powder to the area.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	If there is bleeding from them, then cauterize with a small round cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	It is better to cauterize after cutting.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For often they return when something remains from their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burnt and do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	On the treatment of prolapsed eyelids
Caput IX.	Chapter 9
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Very often there occurs in the eyelids something similar to a hard lump or growth, which is called a "hailstone" because it is a collection of thick moisture in the upper and lower eyelids.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	Therefore, the operation is as follows: first consider whether there is a hailstone present that appears on the eyelid and moves easily to all parts of it.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Make an incision along its width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then peel it off from every side with ease until it comes out completely.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend it with a hook and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	But if you cannot remove it unless after piercing the eyelid with a small incision, then this will cause harm to the patient in some way.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If the incision is large, then close it with sutures and care for it until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, no harm will come from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	For the ointment restores it and causes it to heal over.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if the hailstone leans towards the inside of the ear on the inner surface of the eyelid, then turn over the eyelid and suspend the hailstone with a hook. Additionally, you may need to make an incision and press it from all sides.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	But if the eyelid lengthens due to the incision, no harm will come of it.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then rinse the eye after removing the hailstone with saltwater and care for the area with something that promotes healing until the patient is recovered.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	On the treatment of "axirnath" (i.e., a sty) on the eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter 10
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	A sty is a kind of fat that forms on the eyelid of the upper eyelid, and this happens most often in children. It causes their eyes to be painful and they suffer from morning catarrh and cannot look directly at sunlight because tears flow towards them. This makes them always lie down on their faces and sleep like that, with their eyelids moist under the eyebrows due to swelling. You can see the prominence of the sty and feel it between your fingers when you press the area.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	The manner of its procedure is that the patient should place their head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Next, take a linen cloth and prepare from it a thread, then make from that thread a circle according to the size that contains the sty on all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place this (circle) upon it (the sty), and press with your fingers from all sides so that the sty may gather in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then make an incision with a scalpel at the midpoint of that moist area, splitting it lengthwise, but do not make the cut too deep as is done in bloodletting.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Otherwise, you must cut the skin entirely until you reach the sty, for often it protrudes from the slit like a piece of white fat.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Then extract it with the cloth that you inserted between your fingers on the outside and turn your hand to the right and left until it is completely dispersed. Be careful not to push too far into the slit with the scalpel so as not to harm the eye.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	But if the sty does not appear at the beginning of the incision, gently push further into the slit until the sty comes out.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract it, as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Next, soak cloths in vinegar and water, place them on the area, and then bandage it with gauze.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	Some people grind salt and put it into the hollow of the incision so that any remaining moisture may dissolve.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	If a hot abscess happens in the location, then treat it with soothing plasters until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	Concerning methods of treating strabismus of the eye, that is, when the eyelid becomes relaxed causing the eye to squint as it should not.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When hairs are born in the eyelids of the eye beyond their natural course and grow thickly, then they harm the eye and cause continuous tears, relaxation of the eyelids, and whitening until it becomes a cause of destruction for the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And strabismus of the eye is treated according to four methods.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cautery with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with sharp medicine, as it was mentioned in the chapter on cautery.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or strabismus is treated by incision and suturing.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or by means of weights, as I shall explain.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	You should place the patient's head on your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If it turns well, that is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	But if it does not [turn], insert a needle into the eyelid where there is thread from the lower part of the eyelid, and make the needle penetrate with the thread from above, and let it be near the hairs themselves, that is, near the edge of the eyelid where the hairs are born. Then pull the thread upwards with the eyelid, and turn it with forceps.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find the extra hairs on the inner part of the eyelid using tweezers, starting from the greater lachrymal duct up to the lesser lachrymal duct.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then pull out the thread and place a small cotton wick or piece of cloth under the eyelid. Then mark the eyelid with cautery in the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However, the figure should be made according to the size and elevation of the eyelid: for it varies greatly among humans.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	For there are those who require that much flesh be cut from the eyelid, according to the amount that is swollen by it.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then with scissors find the midpoint between the two lines you have marked and begin from the larger tear duct to the smaller one, and make a single incision close to the natural hairs, so that it is as thick as a reed.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert a hook into one of the two corners of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then peel off the entire skin.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then sew together the two lips with a needle and fine wool thread: wipe away the blood, and make it adhere by tying the excess threads over the eyebrows with some adhesive material if you wish to do so; but if not, do not bother.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then leave the stitches and threads in place for three or four days, then care for it afterwards.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, leave the wound without stitching and treat it with something that dries and contracts it.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid will be raised during the cauterization of the wound and its closure, but it will be better afterwards.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	This method of treatment was taught by the ancients called Attaxmir.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	However, there is carefulness over the patient involved in this procedure, and it comes from good practice, without fear.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And there is another method in Attaxmir: which is to mark the eyelid with a figure like that of a myrtle leaf, as we have described.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then raise the eyelid with three hooks separated or joined together according to this shape: then cut off the excess with small scissors according to this shape with equal depth of incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	But if it is not possible for you to hold the hook and it does not fit: then take a needle with thread attached, and insert it into the middle of the shape; and insert another thread near the larger tear duct, and a second thread near the smaller tear duct; and bring together the threads between your fingers with equal tension.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then raise your hand with equal elevation and raise the skin over which the cut is marked, as we have described.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join together the two lips of the wound with a suture and care for it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	But if swelling occurs at your incision or wound: lance that swelling with a cautery and similar instruments using soothing ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And sometimes it happens that the eyelid also turns inward so that its hairs do.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	Therefore you should use for this what we have said regarding incision, but especially an artificial suture for both (lips of the wound).
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	Chapter on the treatment of Asthma with Cantharides
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And it is necessary to turn back the eyelid and cut open the wound that is inside according to what I have described.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then skillfully make two cannulae or two slender pieces of wood: their length should be according to the length of the eyelid and their width less than the width of a grain of barley; and you have already cut them at both ends where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then carefully place both cannulae on what is protruding from the eyelid of the eye and tie them tightly at both ends with strong thread, leaving them in place for a few days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For the skin being thus tied will die, blacken, and decay until it falls off by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	But if it is delayed, then cut it with scissors.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When it becomes firm, lift up the eyelid; and hairs will not prick.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the shape of two tubes which you should make according to this figure and size in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	Paragraph: On raising hairs that are causing irritation in the eye with a needle
Caput XII.	Chapter 12
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation is as follows: take a fine needle and insert into it a thread of fine silk, soft.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then tie both ends with a very fine knot: and let the length of the threads be one palm.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then place under it another fine thread and tie its ends if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then the patient should put their head on your lap, near to the sun so that the operation may be clearer, because it is a delicate or minute operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then insert the needle with the thread into the root of the eyelid and push it quickly through the eyelid until you draw out a natural hair from above.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then pull the hair up above the thread: and insert that hair into the thread if there is one, or two, or three, but not more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then pull your hand with it until the hair comes out of the eyelid along with the thread and the natural hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	But if the thread is pulled and no hair comes out with it: pull the thread downwards along with the thread you composed in it until the thread comes out through the upper opening, and you can see it with your eye. Then pull both the thread and the hair and draw them both out and close the eye. Leave it closed for two or three days until the hair adheres to its place and flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	But if the hair is short, then either attach a longer hair from the natural hairs and raise it with that, or leave it alone until it grows long after some time, and then raise it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	Chapter on treating an injury to the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this happens to the eye, it is called "Leporina".
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this injury is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	Therefore, an accidental one occurs from the consolidation of a wound, or from a cut, cautery, and similar things.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the method of treatment for it is that you should find that consolidation and separate its lips, and put between them a linen wick, and tie it until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And it is not necessary to use in its treatment things that dry and constrict; for if you do so, Alxatrati will return worse than before. Rather, use things that soften, such as foentgraecum: and mix with water in which marshmallow has been cooked linseed: and anoint with diacylon ointment, melted with some oil: and wrap a linen cloth with it, and treat with it.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And your treasury of treatment is to strive by every means to prevent it from becoming consolidated again in its original shape.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And indeed this operation we have spoken of is only a kind of correction of Alxatrati so that the original form of the place does not return entirely.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	Chapter on treating Alxatrati that occurs in the lower eyelid, which is a wrinkle or contraction upwards to the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIV
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This Alxatrati which happens below is truly called Alxatrati.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is either natural or accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And an accidental one occurs from a wound, or slit, cautery, and similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the way of operating on it is that you should take a needle with a double thread and dip it in flesh, and make it pierce from the left lachrymal to the right lachrymal until the thread comes out at both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then stretch the flesh upwards with the needle, and cut it with a broad spatula.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If then the shape of the eyelid returns as it should be, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take a probe and place it in the slit, and turn the eyelid with it; then make two slits on the inner side of the eyelid, so that the ends of the two slits meet at the two angles of the incision, until they come together to form an angle: until when they are brought together, this figure is formed, which is like the Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh by the amount of its width, with its acute edge below, from what follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then bring together the separated parts: sewing them with a wool thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then treat them with the ointments we have mentioned and linens until they are healed.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if an ulcer occurs from the slit and suture or cautery, then you must make a flat slit under the hairs of the eyelid, even as it was before.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between the two lips with linen, as we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the summary of treatment for an ulcer when it is above or below is that the operation should run according to how it is prepared from the form of the ulcer.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For indeed it has many different forms and the skilled craftsman prepares his ingenuity with whatever means are possible for him until he makes the form return to its natural shape or near it, and the patient himself, according to what suits him from the operation and instruments in many arrangements.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	¶ On the adhesion of the eyelid with the conjunctiva or cornea
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	Sometimes this condition occurs in many people, so that the eyelid sticks to the white of the eye and prevents it from performing its natural functions.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore, you should insert the tip of a probe under the eyelid and lift it upwards: or extend it with a hook; then cut through the adhesion with a dull scalpel that is not too sharp: so as not to distress the patient during the operation, and remove the scalpel, lest it wound the eye with its sharpness: and your incision should be like scraping away the adhesion easily, until when the eyelid returns to its natural shape and the entire adhesion is healed.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour saltwater into the eye and wash it with water: or distill onto it from a sieve made from dissolved glass mixed with water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate the eyelid from the eye with a linen thread: and place over the eye wool soaked in egg white: and on the third day use the sieve again, along with poultices, until it is healed.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	¶ On incising the nail and removing the flesh of tears
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	Know that the nail is in two ways.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Either it is nervous and hard like a string;
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nervous and resembles frozen white moisture; which when touched by iron or tried to be grasped with a hook, breaks off without the hook sticking in it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both kinds do not begin until the large tear duct, gradually advancing until it covers the sight and prevents light and motion of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the manner of operation for incising it is: have the patient place their head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open their eyes and lift the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Next, grasp the nail with a small hook and pull it upwards.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a needle and insert into it a thread made from horse, ox or cow hair - make sure the thread is strong and double the end of the needle slightly. Then pierce the nail with the needle and suture it with the thread, pulling it upwards. Next, scrape off the side of the nail that follows the pupil using the thread as if you were closing it until you reach its end.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then make an incision in the remaining part of the lachrymal duct using a fine spatula or small forceps, taking care not to damage its natural tissue so that the flow of tears is not impaired.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And sometimes the nail can be extended with just a hook, or with a thread as mentioned earlier.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then scrape gently using a fine spatula, which has this shape:
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And beware that the spatula does not touch the corneal tunic and cause it to rupture or perforate the pupil.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then after the incision, sprinkle some crushed salt or powder made from saffron into the eye and leave it until the following day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with what is necessary until it heals.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	But if the nail is not nervous and you cannot insert a needle into it nor can a hook be fixed on it, then this type of nail should be treated many times with medications until it heals as described in its division.
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	If you wish to make an incision into it, then open the patient's eye and take a fine, gentle, blunt spatula with this shape:
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And shave the nail from above with great care.
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	If you see that it becomes thin and brittle and the razor impresses upon it, then instill into the eye from the time of shaving some saffron or red ochre powder or ground salt, and cover the eye until the following day.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then repeat this procedure until all of it is removed.
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	Unless there is a warm abscess in the eye itself: then leave it alone and treat the abscess until it heals.
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the procedure on it with caution until it heals.
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	The prominence of the lacrimal gland, if it causes great harm to the eye, should be suspended with a hook and cut off from its part without making the last incision, lest the flow of tears be obstructed.
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then instill into the lacrimal passage saffron or powder made from safflower until it heals.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	On incising an algourdane and flesh born in the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17.
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	A red fleshy growth sometimes occurs in the eyes of some people, covering or approaching the pupil, or drawing tight over the eyelids and even turning them outward; it resembles a sea-pink.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the operation for this is that the patient should place their head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open the patient's eyes and grasp all of that flesh with appropriate hooks, holding it with one forceps or tweezers.
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then cut into the flesh first until it is completely severed with a knife.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And be careful not to injure the eye during this operation. The cut should be made either with a sharp-pointed knife, as mentioned in the cutting of a nail, or with small forceps used for an eyelid, depending on how much flesh is present after the next chapter.
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.
