When the incision is complete and all of the algourdane has been removed, then fill the eye with ground salt or instill red ochre powder and similar corrosive medicines into it. Then place a white-hot copper disk on the outside of the eye to prevent inflammation.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	But if some algourdane remains and there is hot blood and fear of a hot inflammation, then leave the eye alone and treat it with remedies that cool inflammation.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the procedure until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	And do the same for any added flesh that occurs in the eye of this kind.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	Nevertheless, it is necessary that one should not undertake any treatment of a weak eye through the natural path or accidentally using an iron instrument unless you see that that member can tolerate such an operation.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	On the collection of sebaceous material from the eye.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	Sebaceous veins are red vessels that grow over the eye and obstruct its sight, weakening it with prolonged time.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	Therefore, first you must consider whether the eye with sebaceous material is strong and not affected by any other condition besides sebaceous material. Then collect its sebaceous material.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	It is necessary that you order the patient to place their head in your lap.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then suspend those veins with one or two hooks according to your discretion. Let the hook be of fine double-pointed shape like this, or let there be two hooks graded on a single body like this.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then carefully pluck those veins with fine forceps and wipe away blood hourly until you see that the veins have been removed from the eye and dissolved. And be careful not to injure the eye with the tips of the tweezers.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And perform the operation at midday facing the sun and be very firm in your operation so that you only cut those veins.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	And when you have finished, then apply in the eye either green or red collyrium so that its sharpness may corrode what remains of the scale.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	But if it is not possible for you to complete this in one session, then apply a plaster to the eye with something that soothes its pain; leave it alone for several days until the pain subsides and the heat has abated. Then repeat the process according to the same method until it heals.
Et haec est forma forficis.	And this is the shape of the forceps.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	Chapter on Reduction of Dislocation of the Nose
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	The physicians call Arissati a fistula which you treat with either the cautery or burning medicine according to its description.
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	And if it does not heal, then there is no cure for it except to make an incision over the abscess at its origin and extract all the moisture and pus that is within it until the bone is exposed.
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	When the bone is exposed and you see corruption or blackness on it, then scrape it clean with this instrument whose shape is as follows.
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	And it is called the "asper's head".
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	It should be made of bright iron and its head should be round like a pea, punctured with the point of a file or a very fine awl; place it on the corrupted part of the bone.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then roll it between your fingers and press your hand briefly until you know that the corruption has been scraped away. Repeat this several times.
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the area with drying astringent medicines.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	If the area solidifies and flesh grows there, and the flow of pus stops and remains so for forty days without returning or becoming inflamed, then know that it is now healed.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	But if not, there is no cure except to reduce the fistula back into the nostril according to this method.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	Then, you should bare the bone with an iron tool or caustic medicine; and once the bone is laid bare, take a trepan of this shape, its tip being iron and triangular, its wood being a slender pyramid tapering to the end as shown.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then place it on the bone itself near the tear duct; and hold your hand somewhat away from the eye.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then rotate your hand with the trepan until it penetrates the bone and the patient feels it; at this point you will know that air has begun to pass through from the nose when they place their hand over it.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore then dress the site with drying astringent medicines as I have taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	When flesh begins to grow and the site hardens, then the matter that was flowing outwards will return to the nose; thus it becomes easier for the patient.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	On the reduction of a prolapsed eye.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye protrudes entirely and there is no injury to vision or diminution of it, then you should loosen the patient; next perform phlebotomy on them; afterward apply cupping glasses to their neck without incision but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then apply over the eye a liniment made of acacia, aloe, olibanum, and tragacanth gum.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Then bind the eye tightly from above over the plaster with many bandages.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	And the method of bandages is this: take soft cloths, many in number, and fold each one four times; make many of them; then place them one over another according to the amount needed for the eye; finally bind them tightly with a hard cloth using strong pressure.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	And repeat cupping glasses with suction without incision.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Then remove the cupping glasses and leave the eye bound day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	If however the ligature becomes slack again, then it is necessary to tie it tightly; afterwards remove the ligature after a day and night, as we have said.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	If therefore you see that the eye has returned to its own tunic, it is good; but if not, then repeat the poultice, lint, binding, and cupping glasses until it heals.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	On the Incision of the Vein Tunic.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When a disruption occurs in the vein tunic, and then it becomes prominent and protrudes outside the eyelids like a grain of barley, causing disfigurement to the appearance of the face, and you wish to incise it: then this is the operation for that condition, according to what I shall describe. First insert a needle into the root of the vein from below upwards.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then insert another needle with a doubled thread attached on the side of the lachrymal gland, and make it penetrate; and let the first needle remain in its place.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then cut the location of the doubled thread and tie the vein around the needle with it tightly.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then withdraw the needle and place over the eye lint soaked in egg white; leave him until the thread falls off with the vein.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then treat the eye with what strengthens it until the wound heals.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And sometimes the vein is tied all around with a bandage of cloth until the eye becomes greatly prominent.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then pierce it with a fine trocar that reaches to the depth of the eye, and let the aqueous humor flow out, and the eye subside, and immediately enter: then bind it until it heals.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	On the Treatment of Trachoma
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This disease which is called trachoma is nothing but mucus that collects in the eye like descending water, and it is not itself.
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And the method of operating for this condition is to make the patient sit on a prepared or straight chair.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then, take hold of his head with your hands from both sides and move it until you see the blood flow towards the lower parts beneath your eyes.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then bind it and let it not descend; and let light be restored; and the patient shall see things as they were before. But if it does not descend below, know that there is water present.
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	But if there is no preparation of the descent of blood along with what we said, then make the patient sit between your hands.
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then take a sharp needle and pierce it slightly through the corneal conjunctiva at its junction with the tunic for a short distance until blood comes out.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When blood begins to flow, then instill warm water mixed with honey into the eye, or boiled water from fenugreek seeds and honey. Then treat as before until it heals.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	On the treatment of water that descends into the eye, or cataract.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	We have already spoken of the kinds of water and which is suitable for making an incision, now take that same water according to its healing properties.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then have the patient sit squarely between your hands facing the light near the sun. Tie his healthy eye and press it firmly. Then hold the eyelid of his affected eye with your right hand if it is his left eye, or your left hand if it is his right eye.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take an magnet with your right hand if it's the patient's left eye, or your left hand if it's their right eye.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then place the end of the magnet close to the cornea's edge near the smaller tear duct opening. Push the magnet with force while rotating your hand until you feel it reach the empty space inside the eye.
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	The length of the magnet's journey into the depth should be measured as the distance from the pupil to the end of the blackness of the eye. This is the circumference of the eye.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	For you will see it in the pupil itself due to the clarity of the corneal tunic.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then place the magnet until it reaches the location where there is water.
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then press it down once, then again.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	If the water descends immediately, then the patient will see at once what they opened their vision upon, and the magnet will be in their eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then pause briefly.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If water descends, then lower it for a second time, except that the magnet should not come out.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When it is fixed and does not ascend, then remove the magnet gently while slowly turning your hand.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve some clear salt of a gemstone in water and wash out the eye with it.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then place outside the entire eye a wick dipped in rose oil or wool infused in rose oil and close with it the healthy eye.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	But we, and those of our time, place over it powdered cinnamon mixed with egg white.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	If the magnet does not obey you and enter the eye due to its hardness, since it is made of human bone whose eye is very hard, then you should take a spatula called "Alberid," which has this shape:
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Therefore, pierce the conjunctiva only with it and do not put your hand all the way into the hole. And it is only necessary to create a path for the magnet's subtle place.
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then insert the magnet as we have described.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And towards the completion of your operation, prepare for the patient a decent sleeping place where they can lie on their back in a dark room; forbid them from all movements and coughing, and provide them with food that soothes their nature; let them not move their head to the right or left at all.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	And let the bandage remain in its place until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then remove it in that dark room and test his vision; make him look at things.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then replace the bandage until the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	And it is not necessary for him to do this at the time of treatment or immediately after the incision; rather, it should be done by someone else because water rises quickly through a strong gaze.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	But if a hot swelling occurs, then you should remove the bandage before the seventh day and treat it with something that reduces the swelling until it subsides; then without revealing his vision, place over his face an eye patch to guide his sight for several days while he remains in the dark room.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	Then let him gradually leave the house and return to his usual habits.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	And know that in surgery, the student is not excused from seeing things occasionally; then he should dare to perform operations.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And indeed it has reached us that among those from Alayrah, there is one who said that in Alayrah a cistern was pierced through which water was drawn.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	Therefore, I have not seen anyone in your land who has done this, nor have I read it in any of the old books; and it is possible that it is a new thing.
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	And these are the forms of species from the magnet, so that one who does not know them may stand upon them.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	They should be made of air and their ends should be sharpened like this with the same fineness, and the tip should be acute.
Formae magda.	Forms of the magnet.
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	On the treatment of a flesh growth in the nose.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	Sometimes various kinds of flesh are born in the nose, among which there is something that resembles a many-legged scorpion: and from it comes fleshy, stone-like, dark-colored flesh; and also that which is soft flesh, not dark-colored.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	Therefore, if it is that soft flesh which is not deceitful nor cancerous, you should make the patient sit between your hands facing the sun, and open their nostrils, and insert hooks into those fleshy growths: then pull them towards the outside, and cut what you have grasped from them with a sharp, fine spatula on one side until you know that all the flesh has been removed.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	But if something remains which cannot be cut away, then shave it with one of the fine instruments with ease until nothing remains of it.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	But if blood dominates you or a hot abscess occurs: then apply to it what is appropriate. Or if it is from evil abscesses, then hurry and cauterize him until the blood is cut off and all the flesh is removed.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then vinegar or water or wine should be poured into the nose after the incision.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	But if the nose opens and moisture proceeds from it to the palate, then know that he is already healed.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	But if moisture does not penetrate as it should, then know that there is flesh born on the upper bones of the nose inside it to which the instrument did not reach with the incision.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	Therefore, you should then insert a thread of linen which has some thickness and many knots in it: and place between each knot the amount of a finger or less. And let the patient insert one end of the thread into his nose with a reed or whatever is possible for him afterwards having made it like an awl: and let him draw in his breath until it reaches the upper part of the nostril, and comes out over his throat.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	Indeed, children often do something like this in schools: and it is easy for one who wishes to do so.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then place two ends of the thread, one end which emerges over the nose, and the other which remains in the nostril.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	Then bring a scalpel with knots tied to the thread.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Do this until you know that the flesh is now attached to the knots of the thread.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then remove the thread and insert into the nose, after wiping away the blood, a wick soaked in Egyptian ointment. Do this for three days or more until the ointment has consumed all that remains of the flesh.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then place at the end of the matter a leaden tube into the nose for several days until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	But if there is a need for treatment that dries up, use it.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	For making a head purge to draw out oils and other medicines into the nose, make it of silver or bronze, like a small lamp with an opening like a shell, and its passage likewise.
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	And if you wish to make a closed tube, like a reed cane.
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	And the shell of the instrument for making a head purge should be full and open, with a handle at its end with which to hold it when heating oil or other liquids and flowable substances within it.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	This is the shape of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	Chapter on the Treatment of the Nose
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	The nose often becomes enlarged at its tip and grows bigger with time until it becomes unsightly to look upon.
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	Therefore, it is necessary that you cut off the growth at its beginning when it first appears, and root out all of it.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then place upon the site either a caustic or a burning medicine to destroy it.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	But if the incision is delayed until it becomes large, then consider whether it is hard, rough, dark in color, and has few sensory perceptions; do not touch it with iron for it is a cancerous abscess.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	For I have seen many times that those who had this boil cut have subsequently suffered great harm from it.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	But if the boil is soft to touch, not dark in color, and you see that it can be cut completely, then drain the patient and cut it without fear or hesitation. Then treat the site with something that dries and constricts until it heals.
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	On stitching of the nose, lip, and ear.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	Know that when there is a disruption of continuity in one of these cartilages (nose, lip, ear), little can be achieved by surgery except in some cases.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Therefore, when such an injury occurs to someone, you should first consider if it is a fresh wound with blood. If so, then join the edges of the wound together with stitches and then treat it until it heals.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	But if the lips of the wound are already separated and each part has healed on its own, then you should cut away all the skin that appears to be dead until it bleeds.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then sew the two edges together with stitches and tighten them. Dust powdered dragon's blood and incense over it. Place a piece of plaster of diachylon on top and another of cohesive plaster. Leave it bound for two or three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then remove the dressing after two or three days, change the medicine, and leave it alone until the stitches fall out by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment until it heals.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	The method of suturing is as follows: either join the edges of the wound together continuously with needles, as we have described for abdominal wounds; or join them with a thread, as I have instructed you.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	On the Extraction of Swellings on the Lips
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Many people often get hard swellings similar to grains of barley inside their lips. Some are smaller, others larger.
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	Therefore, turn the lip and pierce it on all sides of every swelling, then hook it with a crochet needle and cut it completely around.
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then fill the place after the incision with powdered zinc until bleeding stops.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Then let it be bandaged with vinegar and treated with it, where there is astringency, until the wounds heal.
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	On the Incision of Congenital Flesh on the Gums
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	Often there is born above the gums an excess of flesh, which the ancients called "abuluss".
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	Therefore, hook it with a crochet needle or hold it with forceps and cut it at its root, allowing blood or pus to flow.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then apply powdered zinc or other drying astringents to the wound.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	If that flesh grows back after treatment, for it often does so, then cut it again and cauterize it; for it will not grow back after being cauterized.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	On the Extraction of Teeth with Iron
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	Sometimes the surfaces of teeth become rough and discolored from within and without, between the gums. They may turn black, yellow, or green, until decay reaches the gum and the teeth smell bad because of it.
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	Therefore, you should make the patient sit between your hands and place their head in your lap. Then scrape the tooth and gum where you see rough surfaces like sand until nothing remains of them. Do the same for blackness, greenness, yellowness, and other discolorations until they are cleaned.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	If what you remove first does not suffice, it is good. But if not, then repeat the scraping on another day, a second and third time, until you achieve your desired result.
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	Know that teeth require scrapers of various shapes and forms depending on the preparation for your operation. The scraper used to scrape the lower part of a tooth is different from the one used between teeth due to their differing shapes.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	And these scrapers should be prepared and kept with you for use as needed.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	Chapter: On the Extraction of Toothache
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	You should endeavor to relieve tooth pain with all diligence and be slow in extracting it.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	For once it is extracted, there is no substitute for it. It is a delicate substance until there is no other option but to extract it when the patient is compelled to do so. Then you should ensure that the painful tooth is firmly extracted and the patient feels certain relief from you.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	Pain often deceives the patient into believing that a nearby tooth is the source of pain and they extract it. However, the pain does not cease until the troubled tooth is extracted.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	We have seen this happen many times among those who practice bloodletting.
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	Once the painful tooth is positively identified by you, then you should cauterize around it with a spatula containing something medicinal until the gum becomes loose on all sides. Then move the tooth gently with your fingers or fine forceps little by little until it begins to wobble.
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then place large forceps properly on the tooth and put your patient's head between your knees. Once you have a good grip so that it does not move, pull out the tooth straightly, making sure not to break it.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	But if it does not come out, then take one of those instruments and insert it beneath the tooth on all sides with ease. Then try to move it as you did initially.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	But if the tooth is pierced or rotted, then you should fill its hole with a piece of cloth. Then tie it tightly with a thin silk thread so that it does not break when you squeeze it with forceps during tightening.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	It is necessary to perform careful cauterization around the gum on all sides extensively.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	Be mindful of your strength so as not to break it off and leave a part in the patient's mouth, which would cause greater pain upon removal.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	Beware of doing what ignorant bloodletters do out of haste and boldness when extracting it. Instead, follow the method that I have described.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	For often they cause serious illnesses in people which are difficult to heal because they break the tooth and leave its roots or some of them behind, or they pull it out along with some jawbones. We have witnessed this happening many times.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	After extraction, let [the wound] be washed with wine or vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	If bleeding occurs from the site (which happens often), then mash some gum Arabic and apply it there. If that is not available, cauterize the spot if necessary.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The fine forceps used for moving the tooth initially should have long points and a short handle. They should be thick enough so that they do not bend when pressed on the tooth. The handles should be like those of coarse forceps but not too thick to prevent them from slipping or bending when squeezed together. Their tips should be straight, made of good iron or well-made steel, with teeth arranged in such a way that some interlock with others and hold firmly when closed.
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	Sometimes the tips are shaped like the beak of a bird called the stork (ciconia), having strong gripping power.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	Chapter on the Extraction of Teeth and Broken Mandible Bones
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When a tooth that is about to be extracted remains firm, then you should apply a poultice of butter on the spot for one or two days until it becomes softened. Then insert a wedge made of wood or use forceps with tips resembling the beak of a bird called the stork (ciconia).
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	This is the shape of the forceps.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	Their tips should be made like a file on the inside, or like an awl (aliskilfeghi).
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	If the tooth does not come out with these forceps, then you should make an incision over the root and remove all surrounding flesh, and insert a small instrument called a "Palanca," which has this shape.
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	It should have a short point, slightly thickened at its end to prevent breaking.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	If the root comes out through it, that is good. But if not, you should help it with other instruments whose shapes are like these.
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The first has a triangular shape with some thickness at its tip.
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	The second has a thin, triangular shape.
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	And also use this instrument which has two branches and has this shape.
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with other instruments and tools mentioned earlier concerning teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	Also use this instrument resembling a large hook, having this shape with a twisted tip of some thickness to prevent breaking and not being blunt.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	And know that there are many instruments for teeth; likewise the rest of the instruments are not counted, and a skilled craftsman, subtle in his art, finds an instrument himself according to what the operation signifies and the diseases themselves.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	Because there are diseases for which previous authors did not mention an instrument due to the diversity of their types.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	If however the bone breaks from the jaw or from other bones of the face, or becomes gangrenous: then examine it over its location with whatever is suitable to it among the instruments and forceps which I mentioned for tooth extraction, and treat it with such gestures whose form is as follows.
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	It should have some thickness gradually so that it can be tightened or held with the bone and not slip away until the bone comes out: and restore the place with suitable medicines.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If however there is a small amount of gangrene in the bone, then shave it off from its gangrene and treat it until it heals.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	On the extraction of prominent teeth above others.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When teeth protrude not according to their natural course, it results in an unsightly appearance; and this is particularly true when it occurs in women and girls, that is, those who are visible.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	Therefore you should consider
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	For if a tooth is born after another and does not fit in place or it is possible to extract it but not grind it down: then remove it. And if it is attached to another tooth, then cut it with this instrument whose shape is as follows.
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It resembles a small beak and is made from sharp-pointed hard iron.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And make your incision over many days, and because of the hardness of the tooth, so that it is not disturbed by any other tooth.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	But if it is prominent and exposed to grinding: then grind it with a file made of hard iron whose shape is as follows.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	Let it be entirely of iron and its handle covered with small puncture-like holes like the file used for making needles. Grind the tooth gradually over many days with ease so that it does not move nor fall out. Then polish it gently, finally shave it with some razors.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	But if it is a tooth from which a part has broken off and harms the tongue, then you should file it down until the roughness of that fracture is removed and smoothed out so that it does not harm the tongue nor interfere with speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	On the extraction of teeth using gold wires.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When a concussion and injury occurs to the front teeth due to blow or accident, and the patient cannot chew without dropping food, and you have treated them with styptic medicines without success, then it is appropriate to bind them with a gold wire because silver turns green and rots after some days, but gold never changes.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let the wire be of medium fineness and thickness according to the quantity that fits between the teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the method of extraction is as follows: Take a wire and insert its doubled end between two healthy teeth. Then wind both ends of the wire around the moving tooth or teeth until you reach a healthy tooth on the other side.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Then repeat the winding until you reach the point where you started. Hold your hand with gentleness and wisdom so that it does not move at all, and let your grasp of the wire be at the roots of the teeth so that it does not slip out.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Then cut off the excess ends of the wire with forceps and join both together. Bend them towards each other and hide them between the healthy tooth and the moving tooth so that they do not harm the tongue. Then let it remain bound in this way.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If it becomes loose or is cut, bind them together with another thread and it will remain stable thus for the entire period of time.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	This is the form of teeth: and the figure of retention of two healthy teeth and two moving teeth, as you see it.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And sometimes it happens that one tooth or two return to their places after having been displaced and are retained as we have described, and they remain there. And this is done only by an experienced and skilled craftsman.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And sometimes a piece from cow bones is prepared and shaped like a tooth and placed in the gap where it supports and holds the tooth, as we have said. And it remains there for a long period of time.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	About the cutting of the ligament that occurs under the tongue and hinders speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	Sometimes this ligament that occurs under the tongue is either natural, with which one is born, or accidental, resulting from an already healed wound.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	The operation for this is as follows: open the mouth of the patient and elevate their tongue. Then cut through that ligament with a scalpel until the tongue is freed from its constraint.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	But if there is some hardness and knotting present, resulting from the healing of a wound, then use a hook to find it and cut through it widthwise until you have severed the ligament and released the knot.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And beware lest there be a deep incision in the flesh and you cut into an artery there, causing bleeding to occur.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then rinse the wound with rose water, vinegar, or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then place under the tongue a linen bandage which the patient should hold in place throughout the night so that it does not heal again.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	If bleeding occurs, then apply powdered myrrh to the wound site.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if blood overcomes you, then cauterize the spot with a lentigo cautery that is suitable for it; then treat it with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	On the Extraction of a Cyst That Forms Under the Tongue.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	It sometimes happens that a swelling resembling a small toad appears under the tongue, preventing it from its natural movement, and may even become so large as to fill the mouth.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	And the operation for this is to open the patient's mouth before the sun and observe the swelling.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	But if you see it as dark-colored or black, hard, without sensation for the patient, do not touch it, for it is cancer.
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	But if it is inclined towards whiteness and has moisture, then introduce a hook into it, cut it with a fine bistoury, and free it from all sides.
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	But if bleeding overcomes you during the procedure, then apply powdered myrrh to it until the bleeding stops; then return to your operation until you have removed it completely along with its base.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then cauterize it with vinegar and salt and treat it with the appropriate care until it heals.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	On the Treatment of a Swelling of the Two Glands.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	Sometimes swellings occur between the throat and the gullet (i.e., the glands) which resemble almonds that appear externally and are called the two tonsils. When you treat them with what we have mentioned earlier, but they do not heal, then observe them.
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	But if the swelling is hard, dark-colored, and has little sensation, then do not touch it with an iron instrument.
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	Moreover, if the swelling is red in color and its root is large, do not touch it even with an iron instrument for fear of bleeding; indeed, leave it alone until it ripens.
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	And then you should pierce it: or else it will burst on its own.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	If it is white in color, round, and has a fine root, then it should be incised.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the procedure is as follows: before performing it, consider whether the abscess has completed its development with quiet heat, or has decreased somewhat in size. Then make the patient sit facing the sun, and hold their head on your lap; open their mouth, and let an assistant take a tongue press between both hands and press down on the tongue below with an instrument of this shape:
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	It should be made of silver or bronze, thin like a knife.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	When you press the tongue with it and the abscess becomes visible, then take a hook and fix it into the tonsil; draw it out towards the outside as much as possible, except for what you pull out along with its coats.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then cut it open with an instrument of this shape:
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	It resembles forceps, but its ends should be curved so that the opening of each is directly opposite the point of the other. Therefore take care that it is made of pure iron or steel.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	If such an instrument is not available, then cut it open with a spatula of this shape:
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	It should be sharp on one side and not sharp on the other.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And after you have cut open one tonsil, cut open the other in the same way.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then let the patient gargle with cold water or with vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if bleeding occurs, let him gargle with water in which pomegranate rinds have been boiled, or with leaves of myrtle and other astringent herbs, until the bleeding stops; then take care of him until he is healed.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And sometimes other swellings are born in the throat besides the two tonsils.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	So cut them as I said in the incision of the two tonsils equally.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	And indeed I had already treated a woman for an abscess that was born between her throat which pulled towards the swelling, few sensations, which had almost closed her throat. And the woman breathed through a narrow passage, and eating and drinking water had been prohibited to her, and death would have reached her within one or two days if it had remained untreated.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	And the abscess had risen so much that it emitted two branches until they exited through both nostrils.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	So I hurried and fixed one of them with a hook.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	Then I pulled it out and a large portion came out with it.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	Then I cut off the part that protruded from the nostril.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	Then I did to her what had emerged from the other nostril.
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	Then I opened her mouth and pressed down her tongue. And afterwards I fixed a hook into the abscess itself; then I cut off a part of it and only a small amount of blood came out from it. Therefore the woman's throat was healed and she immediately began to drink water, then she took some food.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	So I did not cease cutting into that abscess many times over a long period of time. And the abscess kept recurring in its place where I had cut it until it became excessively prolonged along with it.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	I sewed up and cauterized the abscess between the throat.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	So it stopped increasing. Then I left her side and did not know what God did with her afterwards.
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	On the Incision of an Abscess on the Throat.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37.
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When mucus descends to the throat and becomes inflamed, forming an abscess that is elongated, it is called a "perpendicular"; but if it is thick and round at its lower part, it is called a "grape.
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When treated with the method we described in division and improvement does not occur, and you observe that the abscess has become warm and thin, then it is necessary to make an incision.
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And if the mass gathered around it is round and not elongated, and is bloody in color, or dark, and has no sensation, then it is necessary to avoid making an incision.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	For there is fear of harming the patient.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	Therefore, when you see it according to the manner I described, with its whiteness and length, make the patient sit facing the sun. Press down on their tongue with an instrument, which will be mentioned later. Then insert a hook into the throat and pull it downward. Finally, incise the abscess with one of the two instruments mentioned for the incision of the tonsils.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And you should not make an incision beyond its natural boundary without adding anything to it.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	For if you cut into it too deeply, you will injure the voice and speech.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then, after the incision, use the method we described for the incision of the tonsils, and treat it until it heals.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	But if the patient is afraid of an incision, then you must use your skill to cauterize it without causing fear or fright.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the method of cauterizing it is only with acid water, and you should place your hand on the patient's head during the procedure.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then press down on their tongue with the instrument we mentioned earlier.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take some of the water I mentioned earlier for cauterization, and soak a not extinguished lime in it. Then place it on top of this instrument, which has this shape:
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	The depression at its end where the medication is placed should be shaped like the cavity of a snail's shell.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	Place the instrument with the medication on top of the throat itself; and let the patient lie on their side so that the medicinal saliva flows out of their mouth from the inside medicine, so that nothing descends into their throat and harms it.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then hold your hand over the medication.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you should keep it on the throat for half an hour until you see that it has turned black and the bite of the medication has subsided.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to take cotton and wrap it around the end of the probe, and pour the medication onto the cotton, and insert the probe with the cotton into the cannula from above until the cotton adheres to the throat.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Repeat this procedure many times until you achieve your desired result in cauterizing the wound.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then leave it; for it dries up and falls off on its own after three or four days.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	But if you need to repeat the medication, do so. And after cauterizing, wipe around the wound with cotton soaked in butter, and clean it with what remains of the medication around it; then rinse it with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And let it be treated externally with poultices and internally with gargles until it heals.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	Thus this method of treatment is healthier than incising and farther from causing fear.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And sometimes the throat is also treated with something gentler than cautery or incision; for it is treated by inhalation in this manner.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take mullein, hyssop, oregano, rue, asafoetida, chamomile, and similar herbs such as abrotanum. Combine them all in a pot with vinegar, and let them boil. The pot should be well-covered with clay and have a hole in its center over which you place the concave instrument thus shaped.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let it be made of silver or bronze; and insert the end with the pomegranate shape into the patient's mouth until steam rises to the throat through the tube, so that the throat becomes greatly obscured.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat this process many times until it dries up.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And beware that you do not perform this treatment at the onset of an inflammation.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	For often pus is added (to the wound), and it is not proper to do this unless the inflammation is on the decline and hot.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	But if this instrument is not available to you, then take a reed and attach an eggshell to its end so that the patient's bone does not burn. For the eggshell prevents the heat from burning the bone. This is good treatment with safety.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	¶ On the removal of thorns and bones from the throat
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Fragments of bone or fish spines often adhere in the throat.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Therefore, you must remove what is visible among them upon which the sight falls after pressing the tongue with an instrument towards the sun, and it becomes clear to you what is in the throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And that which does not appear to you and is hidden in the throat, it is necessary to make the patient vomit before digestion begins in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	For perhaps the attached thing will come out through vomiting.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or the patient may swallow a piece of radish root or lettuce root, or dry breadcrumbs, or take a piece of dry soft sea sponge tied on a thread and then swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	And when it reaches the place where the spines or bone are located, and is pulled out, then they will come out.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If therefore it does not come out with what we said, then use an instrument made of lead in this shape
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Make it somewhat thicker than the radius bone for a brief moment and at its end make it curved so that you can insert it into their throat easily while keeping your head raised upwards.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And take care not to touch the patient's epiglottis so that they do not cough, and push it with the bone or spine, or insert it into the throat using one's hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	But it is better for the patient themselves to insert it, due to their knowledge of the location of the attached object: and they should push downwards or pull their hand upwards with the instrument, entirely according to the length that has been prepared for them until it comes out.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	Chapter on Removing a Leech.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When you treat the leech with the medicine I mentioned in the division on treatment using medicines and it does not help, then examine the throat of the patient in front of the sun or facing the sun after pressing their tongue with the instrument I told you about.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your gaze falls upon the leech, remove it using a small hook or with gentle tweezers appropriately.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	But if it is not possible with these [tools], then take a hollow cannula and insert it into the patient's throat up to near the throat, then insert into the hollow of the cannula a red-hot iron with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this repeatedly until it is removed, and the patient should refrain from water all day long.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then have them take a cup full of cold water and open their mouth in it, and hold their mouth with it without swallowing any of it, and move the water once an hour with their hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For the leech will immediately fall when it senses the water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if it still does not come out with what we have said, then fumigate the patient with dried beetles or frankincense using the instrument I mentioned for fumigating the throat.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this many times until it falls out.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	The manner of performing fumigation is as follows: Take a pot containing live coals and place it on top of the cover, with the narrow end of the instrument placed over the hole.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then throw the fumigation into the pot, and have the patient place their ear at the end of the tube. They should close their ear so that no smoke escapes until you know that the smoke has reached the bloodsucker.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the leech will immediately fall out.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	But if it does not fall out, then repeat the fumigation many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And the patient should endure thirst, eat salty food and garlic, but drink no water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	Therefore it is necessary that he should discharge with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the shape of the instrument with which the leech is extracted from the throat when it falls on top of it upon sighting.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It resembles forceps, except that it has this curvature which is inserted into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its tip is like the beak of a bird called a pelican, which has the roughness of a file; when it grabs something, it does not let go at all.
