¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	On Opening Abscesses, Their Incision, and Treatment in General
Caput XL.	Chapter 40
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many kinds of abscesses, with various forms, according to the recollection of them, that is, one, and one in this book. And they differ in their perforation and incision from two ways.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One way is based on the type of abscess itself and its inclusion of moistures.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second way is due to the locations where they occur within the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	For an abscess occurring on the head is different from one occurring in the anus; and an abscess occurring in fleshy tissue is different from one occurring at joints. And each of them has its own judgment based on its operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	Among abscesses, there are those that should not be incised except after the matter within them has ripened and gathered; and among them are those which should be incised while they are still raw and do not ripen fully.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Like abscesses which are near joints
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	For when an abscess occurs near a joint and extends its length until the surrounding tissue becomes gangrenous, it may cause damage to the ligaments or nerves of that joint. Therefore, it is a closer cause of contraction in that limb.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or there may be an abscess on the main member: for if you delay its incision until it ripens, it will harm either that [member] or through it the main member.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or if it is near the anus, incise it even while still immature; but do not incise a raw abscess that has not fully digested, except for one near the anus, lest it should decay deeply and extend to the interior of the anus and cause a fistula or result in an unhealing ulcer.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	You should know the proper time to incise an abscess that has ripened fully according to its gathering. It is indicated by the cessation of pain, reduction of fever, decrease in redness and throbbing, sharpening of the head of the abscess, and other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And you should make the incision in the lower part of the abscess, at its most prominent point. The incision should be long enough to reach down to the body of the abscess if it is located on the hands, feet, arms, or other parts where there are muscles, nerves, arteries, and especially in any flat area where there is no reflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	But in those that have a convex surface, make the incision along the length of that member.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	However, when an abscess is in fatty areas, it's better to leave the incision open until its digestion is completed, as we've previously stated.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you open it beforehand, the flow of pus will be prolonged from it, and there will be much foulness and filthiness, and perhaps its lips will harden and deepen.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	Some abscesses should be opened according to the width of the body where necessary, or along the length of the affected limb.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary to make a small incision for small abscesses and a large one for big ones; or multiple incisions according to the size of the abscess.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	There are also abscesses where the skin should be undermined and incised when it has become like a rag and is ready to burst, such as those that occur with boils and buboes.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And among these are some that should be opened with an incision having three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	Among them is one that should be incised like the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Such as a groin abscess.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And among them are some where a round and crescent-shaped incision is made, along with similar incisions.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	But those without a head, such as superficial soft abscesses, should be opened with a superficial or flat incision.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	When an abscess is large and has collected much pus, it's necessary that when you open it, you don't hurry to squeeze out all the pus at once; rather, take out only a portion of it.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then pack the abscess until the following day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then squeeze out some more pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this repeatedly in increments until all the pus has been expressed, especially if the patient is weak in vitality, or a pregnant woman, or a young child, or an elderly person. For sometimes the vital spirit is exhausted along with the discharge of the pus, and perhaps the patient may die without you realizing it.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore, beware this chapter with great caution
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	After making your incision to drain the abscess, you must cleanse the wound and observe carefully.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If the wound from an abscess is small or if the incision was smooth, then apply a bandage made of linen or old cotton.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	But if the abscess is large and there are many incisions, then you must insert a bandage into every incision until they meet.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if you have cut off a part of the skin around an abscess or hollowed it out, then fill this area with old cotton, like when sewing cloth together, or shave linen wool without moisture and bind it tightly for three days.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then remove the bandage and treat the wound with the appropriate ointment until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	But if there is bleeding during your operation, then apply cold water and vinegar, after soaking a cloth in them, to the site of bleeding repeatedly.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	However, if the bleeding persists, then you must apply treatment and powders as mentioned in many places throughout this book, including those under the heading of "division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	But if it is wintertime and the abscess is located near many nerves, then you must apply a poultice made of fine powders mixed with warm wine and oil to the area.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is summertime and the area is fleshy, then apply poultices soaked in cold water, oil, or wine mixed with oil.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until the third day has passed, as we have said, then you must open the abscess, cleanse it, and apply appropriate treatment until it heals.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is therefore what is necessary concerning the general knowledge of treating abscesses.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	But in accordance with the path of division, I have already spoken about every abscess, how each one is treated individually.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	On the Incision of Abscesses that Occur on the Scalp
Caput XLI.	Chapter XLII.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small abscesses occur on the scalp, and they are of the kind called nodes, which are contained within sacs that resemble pouches: as if they were swallowed by a hen.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And their kinds are many.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Among them are fatty ones; and among them are those that contain moisture like mud; and among them are those that contain moisture like fried foods and pulses; and similar to these, there are also stone-like hard ones.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the incision of all of them, and their removal, there is no fear, provided that an artery does not oppose such incision.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation for incising them is that you should try it with an instrument, of which the form comes later, called "the introducer," until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it contains moisture, then incise it lengthwise with a superficial cut according to this shape.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin the incision from point B to point G. When the moisture has been evacuated, then scrape out the skin that contains it, leaving nothing behind.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For indeed it returns many times if anything remains of it.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the skin in Egyptian ointment if it is available; and if not, in water and salt. Fill the wound with this mixture and leave it until the next day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For it will dissolve what remains of the cyst.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the application of Egyptian ointment to the skin a second and third time. If it dissolves, continue treating the wound with ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If the boil contains a fatty node, then cut it in this shape, with an incision shaped like a cross. Insert hooks between the lips of the incision and remove it from all sides. Then strive to extract its containing membrane.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	But if the artery resists you, then do what I will tell you afterwards.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	Similarly, act with respect to a boil that is stony, by performing an incision and treatment as mentioned before.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the incision over a stony boil is easier, because it contains little blood or moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	Sometimes there are boils of this kind that occur on the head of certain individuals which have no moisture at all.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	That is to say, I once made an incision on a boil on the head of an old woman and found the boil to be like a solid and hard stone, rough and white, which could not be broken even if someone threw something at it. It would wound whoever struck against it.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	But in the case of other boils that occur on the head, except for those which occur on children's heads and at the roots of ears, all such boils should be made with a surface incision only.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or make their perforations always from below them, so that the flow of pus may be alleviated downward.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then treat these with whatever is suitable for them in treatment.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	Chapter on the Incision of Swellings in the Neck
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	Swellings of this kind often occur in the neck, shoulders, and groin, but they can also happen elsewhere on the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And those swellings that occur in the neck are either single or multiple, and they arise from one another. Each swelling is enclosed within its own membrane, like knots and boils on the head, as we have described.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And there are many kinds of these swellings.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	Among them are the stony ones; and among them are those that contain fluids; and there are also malignant ones that do not yield to treatment.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	Therefore, if you see among them one that appears well-formed to the touch, has a visible color similar to the skin's, moves easily in all directions, is not attached to any of the neck's nerves, glands, arteries or veins, and is superficial: then you should cut it open from top to bottom along its length using a scalpel, extend its two lips of skin with a hook or hooks if necessary, as we have mentioned for boils on the head, and remove it gradually.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is important to be cautious so that no vein or nerve is cut.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And the scalpel should not be too sharp, lest your hand slip during the incision or disturb the patient unnecessarily.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	But if you cut a vein or artery and this hinders the operation, then place on the wound powdered myrrh or some powder that stops bleeding, and bind the wound. Leave it alone until the swelling subsides and the wound softens or begins to suppurate.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For blood will be cut off from its sheath, so return to your operation until you complete it.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then examine with your index finger if any small swellings remain; if they do, cut them and cleanse them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	But if there is a large vein at the root of the swelling, then you should not cut the swelling from its root; rather, you should tie it with doubled, strong thread and leave it alone until it falls off on its own without harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound with old cotton, which you have previously immersed in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then take care of it.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the swelling is completely cut, then you should approximate the two lips of the wound and sew it immediately, once you see that there is no excess remaining.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	But if you see that there is excess remaining due to the size of the swelling, then you should intend to cut its root and remove it, and perform the suture which we have mentioned.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And when a swelling contains fluids, pierce it with a superficial perforation so that you may see the place of its ripeness, and make the perforation below what follows on the body, as we have said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then apply after the perforation a lint with ointment and similar things so that it may corrupt what remains from the decay until when you see that the wound is already cleaned; then take care of it with flesh-generating ointment until it heals.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	On the section of the epiglottis caused by an obstruction within the throat.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients said that this procedure should be performed on the epiglottis, but I have not seen anyone in our land who has done it. This is what they wrote:
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	But in cases of synanche (choking), the section of the epiglottis should be avoided since no relief can be obtained through it because all veins and lungs are weak.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	But in those who have a hot swelling in the mouth or throat or both tonsils, when there is no inflammation in the canal, it is necessary to perform the section of the epiglottis to escape from the danger that would result from suffocation.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore, when we wish to cut the epiglottis, it is necessary to make three or four small cuts around its circumference, in the intervening space between two circles, so that the cut may be made in flesh and not in cartilage: this place is suitable for cutting because it is devoid of flesh and the blood vessels are far away.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	But if the surgeon is afraid, then he should stretch out the skin of the throat with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he should carefully open the skin until it reaches the canal; he should avoid blood vessels, if any are visible.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then cut the flesh that we have mentioned; and it is indicated that there will be an emission of phlegm from the canal at the time of the cutting, along with what bursts forth and the loss of voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And leave the wound open for some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When the time during which suffocation is feared has passed, join together the two lips of the wound of the skin and heal it alone without the cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then apply medicines that promote the growth of flesh until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis.	This is what Albucasis says.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The summary of this discussion which we have narrated is that it is not necessary unless they see that one of these swellings has already closed up the throat of the patient and the patient has been raised up towards death and wants to cut the epiglottis so that the patient may breathe over the place of the wound with a certain respiration, and thus be saved from death. And for this reason they have ordered that the wound should be left open until the malady is consumed, and its malady lasts for three days and two nights. Then they have ordered that the wound should be sewn up and treated until it heals.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And I have seen with my own eyes that a certain maidservant took a knife and inserted it into her throat and thereby cut part of the windpipe.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	I was called to treat her and found her groaning like one who is dying.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	So I dissected from the wound, and I found that the blood which had flowed out of it was small.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	I became assured then that she herself had not cut the vein nor the artery, and wind (air) was escaping from the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	So I washed her wound and treated it until it healed. And nothing happened to the maidservant except hoarseness of voice, and she returned after several days to a better state of health.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Therefore I say: that there is no fear in cutting the epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	Chapter on the Incision of a Hernia of the Throat.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 42.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This swelling called a hernia of the throat is a large swelling, similar in color to the body itself, and it occurs very frequently in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it occurs in two ways: either it is natural or it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	Certainly there is no defect in the natural one.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	But the accidental one occurs in two ways, one of which is similar to fatty tumors.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other way is similar to swellings that occur from the bursting of an artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And in this [case] there is fear, and it is not proper to make a presumption about it with iron, unless it is small. You should probe it and investigate it with an introductor.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If you find it like a fatty tumor and not suspended with any veins, then cut it like cutting knots; and draw out the tumor along with what contains it from the quistera (cyst), if it is in the quistera. And if not, then examine all of its parts.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat the place with what is necessary for healing until it heals.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	On the Incision over Tumors.
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of tumors, and I have already spoken about all their kinds in the division. And it is necessary for me to mention here the difference between a tumor and an outlet, as there is doubt between them.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say therefore that when the outlet is hotness and fever with severe pains until the boiling over of excess fluid is seated and the putrefaction is completed, then fever and heat become quiet.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	But with a tumor there is no hotness nor fever nor pains, and it contains them in its own sac called kistis sifachin, which is proper to them. And they begin like chickpeas, and they become like bubbles, both large and small.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And there are two kinds of them: either fatty or containing moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	The colors of the moisture are many, as I have said in the division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	It is therefore necessary, when you come to the treatment of a tumor, that you examine it and inquire about it first with an instrument called an introductor, according to what will come in the form of it in the chapter which follows this.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the method of examining swellings and tumors is to take this instrument and introduce it into the wetter place which you find in the swelling. And you should slowly turn your fingers with it until you know that the instrument has pierced the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then, measure the size of the swelling with your hand.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Next, remove what has been inserted and observe what emerges from its trail.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If a running dampness of any color comes out, then cut it with a superficial incision, as I said in the case of other swellings.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	But if no dampness comes out along the path of what has been inserted, then know that it is a fleshy swelling. Therefore, cut it with an incision in the shape of a cross, following the form which I have shown you: and suspend it with hooks, and peel off the skin from all sides easily: and if you can, guard the stitches over it so that you may extract it whole with the tumor.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	But if the cyst bursts during the operation and it is not possible to extract it whole, which often happens, then remove it piece by piece until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if some part of it, whether a little or much, remains, the tumor will return for the most part.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if it defeats you and leaves some part behind, then fill the wound at its completion with certain sharp corrosive powders, and bind the wound, and apply something warm to sit upon the swelling, and treat it with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If the tumor is large, then stitch up its two lips and treat it as if it were flesh.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	But if there is a contrary pulsating or non-pulsating vein, then hurry and fill the place of the cut with bruised material, and leave it bound for two or three days until the wound rots and the blood ceases to boil. Then return to cutting what remains of the tumor.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	On instruments used for cutting and piercing.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	The probes are of three kinds in form.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	There is a large one among them, and there is a medium one among them, and there is a small one among them.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	They should be made of iron with square ends well-cut, so that they may easily enter into an aperture.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of instruments used for piercing or boring holes; one of them is called a 'beris', that is to say, a borer, and they come in three sizes.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	For there is a large one among them, and a medium one, and a small one.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They are suitable for investigating through them fistulas, passages, and boils which are between the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are made round, smooth, and polished like large needles with which the joints are treated, made of bronze or iron or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And those that are made of bronze are better among them.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And instruments made of black lead are also used for probing those fistulas which have reflections within them, so that they may gently touch these reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And once again there are three sizes among them.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For there are long ones among them, medium ones, and short ones according to the width and constriction of the fistula.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The forms of hooks are many in kind.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For there are simple ones among them, that is to say those with one curve; and they come in three sizes as you see: large, medium, and small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And among them there are also blind hooks which come in three sizes.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And among them there are hooks with two curves and three curves each coming in three sizes; all of these are necessary in their proper places.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	The forms of the scalpels used for cutting and scraping nodes and boils are three in number, namely large, medium, and small.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their cutting edges are sharp, the others blunt. They are not used like this unless when scraping nodes there is fear of cutting a vein or nerve, so that the patient may be healed and find temporary tranquility from cauterization instead of what is found in scraping.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are the types of cauteries, and they come in three varieties.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	These are made of iron, resembling brass with which alcohol is made. At the wide end there is a hidden point like a needle's eye through which it can be directed inwardly or outwardly as desired.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	Three sizes of needles hidden between the fingers for perforating boils so that patients are unaware: large, medium and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The forms of the bloodletting cupping glasses used to stop bleeding. They come in three sizes: large, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	Made of copper or glass, round and short in length as shown here, they should be made with precision.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And you should have among your instruments large and small bloodletting cups so that you may quickly let blood when necessary, especially in the absence of medication.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However, do not use them for bloodletting everywhere on the body but only in fleshy places such as the arms of the legs and thighs, arms, breasts, belly, groin, and similar moist flesh.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	Sometimes small instruments similar to the rinds of figs are made from these, according to their shape, for letting blood when it flows from the site of phlebotomy or after incision of a vein or artery. Sometimes they are made round like this.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	Concerning the treatment of male breasts, which resemble those of women.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVI
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the breasts of certain men become enlarged at the completion of sleep (that is, when they begin to grow turbid during sleep), resembling those of women; and they remain foully festered.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	He therefore who dislikes this (enlargement), it is necessary that he make a crescent-shaped incision above the breasts according to this line, below to the line, and then scrape away all the fat.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then fill the wound with an embrocation for flesh wounds.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then approximate the two lips of the wound with stitches and care for it until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If however the breast hangs downwards and becomes flaccid due to its size, as happens with women: then it is necessary that it be cut in two on its upper sides with two incisions similar in shape to a crescent moon, each contained with the other at their ends so that there is one larger line containing a smaller one according to this form from line, b. to line, g. Then remove the skin that is between the two lips and excise the fat, and apply what we have said about stitches and powders, which is necessary for healing until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	But if you do not complete the incision that you ought to make because of the patient's discomfort or because of bleeding: then it is necessary that you fill the wound with cotton soaked in a corrosive ointment and leave it until it corrodes what remains of the fat.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	Concerning the incision of an abscess that occurs in the armpit.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter 48.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These abscesses that occur in the armpit are from hard species of roughages (strophulae) which contain cysts and those which contain humors.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	It is necessary that those which contain humors be opened with a crescent-shaped incision along this line from b to g. Then, when all the pus has been evacuated, fill it with old wax and leave it until the next day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then remove the wax, and treat it with a suitable ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	But if the abscess is of the species of nodes (strophulae), then cut upon it as we have said in the case of an equal division for strophulae.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	But if the wound extends so as to emit pus, then apply a causterization to it according to what has been said before.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	Concerning the incision of an abscess that occurs due to an artery and vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery is ruptured and the skin above it solidifies, often an abscess occurs from it. Similarly, this also happens with a vein, so that an abscess and swelling occur.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it can be recognized that an abscess and swelling are due to an artery or vein are these: for when an abscess is due to an artery, it is long and collected deep in the body; and when you press the abscess with your fingers, you feel as if there is a hissing sound.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is due to a vein is round and manifest on the body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	An incision upon this abscess is an error, especially when it occurs under the armpits, groins, neck, and many other parts of the body. And it is very large indeed.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore, its treatment should be avoided with an iron (scalpel), and that which is also on the extremities or head should be avoided.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Therefore, concerning that which is caused by them from swelling of the arterial opening, you should find it out in the skin by making a lengthwise cut.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the incision with hooks, afterwards the artery; and free it from its sheaths until it is exposed.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then insert a needle underneath it and make it penetrate until the other side, and tie the artery with doubled thread in two places, as I have taught you regarding the extraction of the two arteries that are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then prick the place between the two ligatures with a fine probe until all the blood contained within it emerges and the abscess is resolved.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then apply treatment that generates pus until the ligatures fall off; afterwards treat it with suitable ointments until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	But if it is an abscess due to a vein incision, then you should hold back with your hand as much of the abscess as possible along with the skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then insert a needle under the place you held back with your hand and make it penetrate; and let there be doubled thread on it until you draw it out from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tie the abscess with a good ligature; as I have told you regarding the ligature of a vein, from two parts with two ends of thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	But if you fear that the thread might be drawn out, then insert another needle with another thread under the entire abscess at the incision of the needle; press and tie your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then cut the abscess in the middle of it until when what is inside it emerges; then incise the excess skin and let go of what is tied to it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then place upon it a little piece of bread which you have soaked in wine and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then apply treatment with lint and ointments until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	Concerning the condition that occurs due to the twisting of nerves.
Caput L.	Chapter L
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as an abscess can occur in an artery or vein, so too can an abscess occur in nerves: this happens due to impact or from excessive labor and similar causes; it often occurs at joints, such as the elbow or heel, and wherever there are articulations. And such an abscess is severe.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its color resembles that of the rest of the body, and it appears in most cases without pain; but when it is pressed with force, the patient feels a sensation similar to stupor.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not an abscess formed deep within the body, but rather under the skin; indeed, it can move in any direction and does not proceed to the front or back.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Therefore, those that occur at joints should not be incised with a knife.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	For otherwise, contraction might result.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	But for one that occurs on the head or forehead, find the skin with a probe.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If it is a small abscess, then grasp it with forceps and cut it off at its root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if it is large, then suspend it with a hook and excoriate it; then remove it and close the wound with sutures. And dress it until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	Concerning the incision of an abscess that occurs in the abdomen.
Caput LI.	Chapter LI
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	Some people often have, in their bellies and other parts of their bodies, swellings called "funguses" due to their similarity to mushrooms.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Their roots are fine, but their heads are thick; and their lips are inverted.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And among them there are some that are small, and others that become greatly enlarged.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And indeed I have seen a man whose belly had two such swellings that were more like mushrooms than anything else: there was no difference between them, they were white with small roots and inverted lips; they could be felt and moisture flowed continuously from them.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	I cut into them and found that one weighed about ten and eight ounces, and the other about six ounces. The operation for cutting them is as follows: first consider whether the patient is moist and the color of the swellings is white and humid with thin roots. Then cut it with a wide spatula, having cauteries ready in the fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For often much blood flows out at its cutting: therefore be prepared if it overcomes you with blood, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	But if you see the patient fearful and hesitant about being cut with a knife, then take a fine thread made of lead and tie it around the swelling. The manner of doing this is as we have described, and leave it for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add more lead to the binding.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	So do not cease tightening the lead whenever it presses on the swelling until it is severed and falls off by itself without effort.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	But if the swelling has a thick root, then there is some fear and anxiety in cutting it, especially those in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	Nevertheless, it is possible to cut half of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it so that it does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then treat it until the wound heals.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	But beware of cutting into a swelling that is of dark color, has little sensation, and is foul-smelling; for it is a cancerous abscess. And I shall speak more about cancer afterwards.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	On the treatment of an umbilical hernia.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	An umbilical hernia can have many causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Either it occurs due to splits in the navel, from which either bile or intestine protrudes, as happens with other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood flowing out of a vein or artery, according to what was previously stated.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or due to constriction of the windpipe therein.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	But if it is due to a split in the navel with protrusion of intestines, then its color resembles the color of the body and is soft without pain; and it appears in different positions.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is due to protrusion of intestine, then its position differs more violently than what we have described.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	But when you press it with your fingers, it disappears; then it returns again, and perhaps there is a sound with it; and it becomes very large at the entrance of the bathhouse, causing great pain.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	But if it is due to moisture, it is soft and does not disappear when you press it with your hand, nor does it contract or increase.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	If it is due to blood, then along with these signs an abscess appears towards the blackness of blue.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	But if it is due to born flesh, then the abscess is heavy, thick, hard, and measures about one unit.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	But if it is due to wind, its touch is soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the treatment of it is that you should then examine whether the prominence of the navel is due to blood from an artery or vein, or wind. If so, then you must forbear from treating it.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For there is fear and trembling in it, as I taught you in the chapter where I said that abscesses due to an artery or vein are feared.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If the prominence of the navel is due to intestine or hernia, then you should order the patient to hold their breath and stand still with arms extended.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then make signs around the entire circumference of the navel with a cautery.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Next, tell him to lie face down on your hands placed on his back.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then, encircle the navel with a wide bandage around the marked spot using hot wax.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Next, stretch out the center of the swelling towards its upper part with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then bind it firmly around with thread or silk cord tie: let the knot be tied tightly.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the center of the swelling stretched over the bandage.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If you find it captured by the bandage: then extract the tightened (ligature), and insert your index finger into it, and push the intestine towards the interior of the abdomen; and if you find a boil, then take it with a hook, and cut its excess.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	But if an artery or vein opposes you, then bind it tightly around it.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	Take two needles and insert two strong threads into them; then insert the needles into the circumference you made around the swelling in the shape of a cross, which you should penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tighten the swelling at four points over the needles: and if you wish, remove the needles and leave the area until the extended flesh rots and falls off on its own; or cut it when it becomes thin and rotten.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with what is necessary from ointments until it heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	But if there is a prominence of the navel due to flesh growing on it or moisture: then you should make the swelling concave as we have said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And remove blood or moisture that you find within it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then treat it with what will heal the spot.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	¶ On the treatment of CANCER
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already discussed the division of the types of Cancer, and how it is treated with medications; and we have warned about avoiding its treatment with iron so that it does not become ulcerated. We have also mentioned cancer generated in the uterus and the caution against treating it.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said that sometimes cancer is in a location where its removal is possible; such as cancer that is in the breasts or thigh, and similar ones located in limbs which can be completely removed. Especially when it is just beginning small.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	But when it has grown old and become large, do not approach it.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For indeed I was unable to cure anyone from this condition; nor have I seen any before me who succeeded in treating it.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation for one thus located, as we have described, is to cut into him and release him from black bile sometimes.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then perform bloodletting if you find it with obvious fullness.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the patient for preparation in which he will undergo the operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then cast hooks that fit into the cancer upon it.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then excise it on all sides with skin according to your inspection until there remains nothing of its roots. Then let blood flow freely and do not cut it off hastily but press the edges and wipe away thick blood completely with your hand or whatever instruments are possible there.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if you encounter difficulty with the flow of thick blood from the incision due to an artery or vein, then cauterize the vein until the bleeding stops.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the remaining treatment until it heals.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	§ On the Treatment of Dropsy
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 54.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	We have already spoken in the division of the kinds of dropsy and how water collects, and the signs of each kind and their treatment with medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And that which is treated with iron is only the species of ascites alone; it does not approach with iron the species of tympany, nor the species of hydrops completely, for that is deadly.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you have already treated this species of dropsy called tympany with medicines and it has not improved, then consider
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	For if the patient has already become weakened or there is another illness besides dropsy present, such as coughing or diarrhea, etc., then beware of treating him with iron for fear of harm.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	If you find the patient to be of robust constitution and without any other illness besides dropsy alone, and is neither a child nor an old person, then proceed with this method: raise the patient upright between your hands, and have an assistant press their abdomen from below upwards towards the lower chest.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a spina bifida probe of this shape.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	It is forked at two parts and has a sharp tip like a spatula.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	However, it should taper gradually towards the end so that you do not pierce through to the intestines and injure them during the procedure.
Deinde considera.	Then observe.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	For if the dropsy is due to a condition of the intestines, then you should lengthen your cut from the navel by three fingerbreadths downwards towards the lower abdomen.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	But if the dropsy is due to a condition of the liver, then your incision should be made three fingerbreadths to the left of the navel.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.	And if the dropsy is due to a condition of the spleen, then make your incision on the right side. Do not let it be on the side where the patient desires to lie down, so that no fluids run towards that weakened area.
Deinde perfora cum instrumento cutem totam.	Then pierce through the skin completely with your instrument
Deinde intromitte in illam sectionem, et eleua manum tuam cum Spatumili inter cutem, et sifac, quasi tu excories ipsum: et sit quantitas quae excoriatur quantitas unguis, aut circiter ilud.	Then insert the spatula into that opening and raise your hand as if you are scraping out something between the skin. The amount scraped should be roughly equivalent to the size of a nail or thereabouts.
Deinde perfora sifac, donec perueniat Spatumile ad locum uacuum: et est locus aquae.	Then continue scraping until the spatula reaches an empty space; this is where the water collects
Deinde extrahe ipsum, et intromitte in foramen instrumentum, cuius haec est forma.	Then remove it and insert into the opening an instrument of this shape
Et est simile cannulae: fit ex argento, aut aere, aut aurichalco, lene, tersum: cui in inferiori parte sui est foramen paruum, et in lateribus eius sunt tria foramina, duo ab una parte, et unum a parte altera: et facia est extremitas eius incisa, secundum modum incisionis calami, sicut uides: in extremitate eius superiore est armilla.	It resembles a cannula; it is made of silver, brass or bronze, polished and smooth. Its lower part has a small opening, with three openings on its sides - two on one side and one on the other. Its tip is cut like a pen nib, as you can see. Above it there is a ring
Nam quando instrumentum peruenit ad aquam, tunc ipsa descendit statim super instrumentum, ergo euacua ex aqua in hora quantitatem mediam.	When the instrument reaches the water, it sinks immediately and thus expels half of its quantity from the water within an hour.
Quoniam si tu euacuas ex ea plus quam oportet, in hora fortasse moritur infirmus per resolutionem spiritus sui animalis: aut accidit ei syncopis quae appropinquat morti.	For if you expel too much from it, the patient may perhaps die within an hour due to depletion of their vital spirit; or else a syncope may occur that approaches death.
Verum euacua ex ea secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius, et secundum quod significant tibi dispositiones infirmi ex uirtute pulsus eius, et ex bonitate eius.	But expel from it according to its quantity of strength and according to what the conditions of the patient indicate to you through the virtue of their pulse and their constitution.
Deinde extrahe instrumentum, et retine aquam.	Then remove the instrument and retain the water.
Quod est, quia retinetur statim propter cutem quae retinet foramen quod est super sifac: de quo narraui, ut perfores ipsum secundum illum modum.	This is because it will be retained immediately due to the skin that retains the opening which I mentioned earlier, and which you should pierce according to that method.
Deinde itera instrumentum die altero, si uides infirmum tolerare illud: et extrahe etiam ex aqua quantitatem paruam.	Then repeat the procedure on the second day if you see that the patient can tolerate it; and also remove a small quantity of water from it.
Fac illud diebus aliquot sine timore, et custodi te ab errore: donec non remaneat ex aqua nisi parum.	Do this for several days without fear, taking care to avoid error until only a little water remains.
Si autem times super infirmum, et dimittis ex aqua rem multam: tunc cura ipsum cum sepultura in harena calida, et sudore multo in balneo et sole, et expectet super sitim: et cura ipsum cum medicinis exiccatiuis, donec sanetur: et cauteriza super stomachum, et epar, et splenem, post extractionem aquae: secundum quod narraui in eo quod praecessit.	But if you fear for the patient and allow much water to remain, then treat them with hot sand burial and profuse sweating in a bath and sun exposure, and make them wait until they are thirsty. Then treat them with drying medications until they recover; and cauterize their stomach, liver, and spleen after removing the water according to what I have already described.
¶ De cura infantium qui nascuntur locis urinae eorum non perforatis.	On the treatment of infants born with unperforated urinary passages
Caput LV.	Chapter 54
Quando egreditur aliquis infantium ex uentre matris suae, et caput mutonis eius est non perforatum, aut est foramen strictum, aut in non suo loco.	When an infant is born from its mother's womb and the opening of its urinary meatus is not perforated or is too narrow or not in its proper place
Oportet ergo succurrere cum perforatione eius statim cum nascitur cum Spatumili subtili ualde, secundum hanc formam.	Therefore, one should immediately come to its aid with a fine Probe made of silver wire, shaped thus
Deinde pone in foramine clauum subtilem ex plumbo, et liga ipsum: et tene ipsum tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then place a thin lead clamp at the opening and bind it. Keep it on for three or four days
Quando ergo uult urinam emittere, remoueatur, et mingat.	When ready to pass urine, remove it and let it void
Deinde reduc ipsum.	Then replace it.
Et si tu non ponis plumbum, iam possibile est, ut urina quae incedit super locum, non permittat ipsum claudi.	But if you do not use lead, then urine that passes over the spot may prevent it from closing
Ille autem cuius foramen est strictum, medicatur cum plumbo, sicut diximus, diebus multis, donec amplificetur.	But one whose opening is too narrow should be treated with lead as we have described for many days until it widens
Illi autem in quibus est foramen in non suo loco, laeduntur.	Those who have the opening not in its proper place are harmed.
Quod est, quia ex eis qui nascitur, foramen est apud finem capitis uirgae: quare non potest mingere ad anteriora, donec eleuat uirgam manu sua ad superiora.	That is to say, in those infants born with the opening at the tip of the penis, they cannot void urine properly until they lift the penis by hand upwards
Neque est ei generatio, propterea, quod sperma non potest peruenire ad matricem secundum rectitudinem: et est aegritudo foeda ualde.	Nor can he father children because semen cannot reach the womb properly; and it causes great distress.
Et modus operationis in illo est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum.	The procedure for this is as follows: lay the infant on its back.
Deinde extende caput uirgae eius manu tua sinistra extensione uehementi, et incide caput capitis uirgae ex loco priapi, cum acumine, aut spatumili acuto: sicut est incisio calami, aut sicut tu radis aliquid, ut medium eius ueniat simile capiti uirgae: et ut cadat foramen in medio secundum quod oportet.	Then with your left hand stretch out the head of the penis forcefully and cut off its tip at the frenulum using a sharp knife or probe, just like cutting the end off a reed so that it resembles the head of the penis, and so that the opening falls in the middle as it should.
Et caue tibi apud operationem tuam a fluxu sanguinis.	Be careful during this procedure to avoid bleeding.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	For many times has this happened.
Oppone ergo ei cum eo quod abscindit sanguinem, et cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Therefore apply pressure with what has cut it to stop the bleeding and take care of the wound until it heals.
¶ De Albather quae accidunt in praeputio et capite uigae, et corruptione, nigredine, et adhaerentia.	On Circumcision which occurs on the foreskin and head of the penis, and its corruption, blackness, and adhesion.
Caput LVI.	Chapter 60
Multotiens accidunt istae Albather in uirga, et est eminentia carnis foedae.	These circumcisions often occur on the penis, with a prominent, foul growth of flesh.
Et ex ea alia est maligna, et alia non maligna.	There is also one that is malignant and another that is benign.
Non malignam ergo oportet ut suspendas cum uncino subtili, et abscindas eam, donec mundes eam totam.	Therefore, you should hang the benign one with a fine hook and cut it off until it is completely removed.
Deinde pone super eam cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio.	Then place over it cotton soaked in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud cum unguento dyafinicon, donec sanetur.	Next, treat it afterward with dyaphekon ointment until it heals.
Quod si Albather est maligna, foedi coloris, tunc oportet ut administres in ea cauterium post incisionem eius et ipsius rasionem.	But if the circumcision is malignant and of foul color, then you should apply a cautery to it after its incision and excision.
Si autem Albather est in praeputio captiui, non circumcisi, et est pars Albather inter praeputium, et pars eius extra: tunc oportet ut auferas Albather, quae est intus in primis, donec quando consolidatur, tunc cura ipsum exterius: quoniam quando tu curas eam simul, non securatur praeputium quin preforetur.	But if the circumcision is on the foreskin of an uncircumcised captive and there is part of it under the foreskin and another part outside, then you should first remove the part that is inside until it solidifies, then treat the outer part: for when you treat them together, the foreskin will certainly not heal without being perforated.
Et iam accidunt etiam in testiculis, et praeputio nigredo et corruptio.	And now such blackness and corruption also occur in the testes and the foreskin.
Oportet ergo, ut tu concaues totum quod iam denigratum est, et quod uult corrumpi, aut iam corruptum est.	Therefore, you should carve out all that which has already become blackened and that which desires to decay or has already decayed.
