Deinde line super ipsum post illud cum melle quod iam concussum est cum farina corticum granatorum, et herbi tritorum cribellatorum.	Then apply over it afterward a poultice made from honey that has been crushed with the powder of pomegranate rinds and sifted bran.
Deinde cura illud cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the remaining treatment until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra cauterium cum cauterio lunari, secundum hanc formam.	But if there is a flow of blood, then apply a lunar-shaped cautery with this shape:
Cauterium enim est iuuatiuum ad duas dispositiones simul, scilicet ad fluxum sanguinis, et uulnus quando corrumpitur.	For the cautery has two uses at once, namely for stopping the flow of blood and for healing when a wound becomes corrupt.
Quod si corroditur caput uirgae, et destruitur totum in hora: tunc oportet ut intromittas in meatum priapi cannulam ex plumbo, ut mingat infirmus super eam.	But if the head of the penis is eaten away and destroyed entirely within an hour, then you should insert a lead cannula into the urethra so that the patient can urinate over it.
In adhaerentia uero praeputii cum capite uirgae, et haec quidem adhaerentia non accidit, nisi in eo cuius praeputium est sanum, et non exigitur super ipsum circumcisio: et quandoque accidit adhaerentia propter uulnus, aut apostema: oportet ergo ut excories eam cum Spatumili obtuso, donec soluatur ligamentum, et liberetur caput uirgae ab omni parte.	But in the case of adhesions of the foreskin to the head of the penis - and indeed such adhesions do not occur except in one whose foreskin is healthy and has not been circumcised, and sometimes they occur because of a wound or an abscess - you should cut them away with a blunt spatula until the adhesion is loosened and the head of the penis is freed on all sides.
Quod si est difficile discernere ea exquisite, tunc oportet ut excories aliquid ex capite uirgae, et ex praeputio.	But if it is difficult to distinguish them when examined closely, then you should cut away some from the head of the penis and from the foreskin.
Quod est, quia praeputium quando est subtile, fortasse perforatur propter subtilitatem suam uelociter.	That is, because when the foreskin is thin, it may be punctured quickly due to its thinness.
Deinde separa inter praeputium, et caput uirgae cum panno lini subtili, qui iam madefactus est in aqua frigida, ut non adhereant iterum.	Then separate between the foreskin and the head of the penis with a fine linen cloth that has been soaked in cold water, so that they do not stick together again.
Deinde curetur cum uino stiptico, donec consolidetur.	Then it should be treated with an astringent wine until it is healed.
¶ De mundificatione infantium, et curatione ex errore eis accidente.	On the cleansing of infants and treatment for errors that occur to them.
Caput LVII.	Chapter 57
Circumcisio non est solutio continuitatis, sicut reliqua uulnera: uerumtamen cum sit ex operatione nostra, uoluntate nostra, et usus eius sit in pueris proprie, est necesse ut signemus in ea operationem meliorem, et uiam leuiorem perducentem ad salutem.	Circumcision is not the solution to continuity as other wounds are: nevertheless, since it is our operation by our will and its use is proper in boys, it is necessary that we indicate a better method of performing it and an easier path leading to healing.
Dico ergo, quod antiqui non dixerunt circumcisionem in aliquo suorum librorum: quoniam non utuntur in legibus suis, et non est nisi quod acquisiuimus per experimentum.	I say therefore that the ancients did not mention circumcision in any of their books because they do not use it in their laws and it is only something that we have acquired through experience.
Quod est, quia ego inueni maiorem partem artificum, et phlebotomatorum uti mundificatione, circumcidendo cum nouacula, et cum forficibus: et utuntur alfecati, et ligaudo cum filo, et incisione cum ungula.	That is to say that I have found the majority of barbers and bloodletters using cleansing with a knife or forceps for circumcision, and they use cauterization and ligation with thread and incision with a nail.
Et ego quidem iam probaui omnes istos modos, et non inueni meliorem mundificatione cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo.	And indeed I have already tested all these methods and found none better than cleansing with forceps and ligation with thread.
Quoniam in mundificatione cum nouacula, multotiens effugit cutis.	For when using a knife for cleansing, the skin often escapes.
Quoniam cutis praeputii duas habet tunicas: ergo forsitan inciditur cutis superior, et temanet tunica inferior: cogitur ergo ad incisionem ad incidendum alteram, et dolorem futurum.	Because the foreskin has two layers of skin, sometimes only the outer layer is cut and the inner one remains. This forces another incision to be made, causing pain.
Et cum mundificatione quae fit per alfecati, id est, digitalis, quo utuntur sutores, non securatur incisio extremitatis uirilis membri: quoniam fortasse ingreditur in foramen eius.	But with the cleansing done through catgut, that is, by finger, which surgeons use, the incision at the end of the male member is not secured, because perhaps it might enter its opening.
In mundificatione autem cum ungula, fortasse euadit ferrum, et corrumpit operationem tuam: et cutis quidem pueri est breuis natura, et multotiens nascuntur taliter, quod non indigent mundificatione: et iam uidi illud.	But in cleansing with a nail, perhaps the iron might slip out and ruin your procedure; moreover, the skin of a child is naturally short, and many are born in such a way that they do not need cleansing; indeed I have seen this myself.
Mundificationis autem cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo, bonum experimentum detexit mihi: quoniam forfices sunt proportionalis incisionis: propterea, quod acuitas quae est superius, est sicut acuitas quae est inferius.	But I have found by experience that cleansing with forceps and ligature with thread is good, because the forceps are proportionate to the incision; therefore, what is sharp above is like what is sharp below.
Cum ergo premis manum tuam, proportionantur duae acuitates, et incidunt secundum operationem unam in tempore uno: et fit compressio simili figura, continens cutem uirgae ab omni parte, cum qua non cadit error omnino.	Therefore, when you press your hand, the two sharp points become proportional and make one incision at once, creating a compression with a similar shape that holds the skin of the rod from every side without any error.
Et modus operationis propriae est, ut facias extimare, puerum praecipue, si est ex eis qui intelligunt parumper, quod tu non facis, nisi quod ligas filum in uirga sua tantum: et dimittas ipsum usque ad diem alium.	And the proper way of operating is that you should make the child especially understand, particularly if he is one of those who comprehend quickly, that you are only tying a thread on his member and leaving him until another day.
Deinde fac eum gaudere et laetari omnimodo quo possibile est tibi illud, ex eo quod recipit intelligentia sua.	Then make him happy and rejoice as much as possible, to the extent that he understands what is happening to him.
Deinde fac eum stare inter manus tuas praeparatae staturae, et non sit sedens: et occulta forfices in manica tua, aut sub pede tuo, ne uideat eos puer omnino, neque aliquid ex instrumentis.	Then make him stand between your prepared hands and not sitting; hide the forceps in your sleeve or under your foot so that the child does not see them at all, nor any other instruments.
Deinde intromitte manum tuam ad uirgam eius, et suffla in cutem, et trahe eam sursum, donec egrediatur caput uirgae.	Then insert your hand towards his member, blow on the skin, and pull it upwards until the head of the foreskin comes out.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex eo quod aggregatur in ea sordicie.	Then cleanse it from the dirt that has accumulated on it.
Deinde liga locum signatum cum filo duplo.	Then tie the marked spot with a double thread.
Postea liga inferius eo parumper ligamentum secundum.	Next, bind it below briefly with another ligature.
Deinde tene cum indice tuo, et pollice locum ligamenti inferioris retentione bona, et incide inter duo ligamenta.	Then hold the site of the lower ligature with your index finger and thumb and cut between the two ligatures.
Deinde eleua cutem sursum uelociter, et extrahe caput uirgae.	Then quickly elevate the skin upwards and remove the head of the splinter.
Deinde dimitte sanguinem currere paulatim (est enim melius) et pone puluerem desuper: et super puluerem pannum in quo expansus est uitellus oui decocti in aqua rosata, concussum cum oleo ros.	Then allow the blood to flow gradually (for it is better), and then apply powder on top. Place over the powder a cloth containing the beaten yolk of an egg cooked in rose water mixed with rose oil.
Recenti bono: et dimitte eum super ipsum usque ad diem alium: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then apply it well and leave him on it overnight until the next day, treating him with the remaining treatment until he is healed.
Forma autem forficis ad mundificationem haec est.	The shape of the forceps for cleaning is as follows.
Sint hebetes duae extremitates, et sint incidentes: ne egrediatur in eis ramus claui: et sit longitudo duarum acuitatum, sicut longitudo duorum manubriorum aequaliter.	Let the two ends be blunt and inclined so that the branch of the nail does not come out. Let the length of the two points be equal to the length of the two handles equally.
Error uero cadens in mundificatione est: quoniam fortasse effugit cutis intrinseca tota, aut pars eius apud incisionem.	The error occurring during cleaning is that perhaps the entire inner skin or part of it escapes at the incision.
Ergo oportet, ut extendas eam ex hora tua cum ungue tuo ante apostemationem loci: et incidas eam secundum aequalitatem.	Therefore, you should stretch it out with your nail before cauterizing the site and cut it evenly.
Quod si non potes tenere eam cum ungue tuo, tunc extrahe eam cum uncino, et incide eam.	But if you cannot hold it with your nail, then remove it with a hook and cut it.
Si autem praeterierint ei tres dies, et remanet quod est sub uirga inflatum, apostematum: tunc dimitte illud, donec sedetur apostema calidum, et excoria illud cum facilitate, et incide illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi: et caue tibi a capite uirgae.	But if three days pass and there is still swelling under the splinter, then let it be until the swelling becomes hot and hard, and remove it gently and cut it according to what you prepare for yourself, being careful about the head of the splinter.
Non enim nocebit ei illud.	For it will not harm him.
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod consolidat uulnus ex pulueribus, quos narrauimus in tractatu de pulueribus: et si inciditur ex cute supra mensuram, et euadit ad superiora, non nocet ei illud etiam.	Therefore treat it with that which solidifies wounds from powders, those of which we have spoken in the treatise on powders. And if it is cut more than necessary and reaches higher areas, it will not harm him either.
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod diximus, donec sanetur.	Therefore treat it with what we have said until it heals.
¶ De extractione Vrinae retentae in uesica.	On the Extraction of a Retained Foreign Body in the Bladder.
Caput LVIII.	Chapter 58
Urinae retentio in uesica, fit ab opilatione facta ex lapide, aut sanguine congelato, aut pus, aut carne nata, et similibus illis ex eis quae diximus ex modis curationis in diuisione.	Retention of urine in the bladder occurs due to obstruction caused by a stone, congealed blood, pus, flesh growths, or similar things from those mentioned earlier in our discussion on treatment methods.
Et si non soluitur Vrina, et uides retentionem eius esse propter Lapidem, qui iam est in collo uesicae: tunc oportet ut sit infirmus super genua sua curuatus.	But if urine does not dissolve and you see that its retention is due to a stone already in the neck of the bladder, then it is necessary for the patient to be positioned on their knees with their buttocks elevated.
Deinde componantur pedes eius super dorsum eius, et extendat uentrem suum ex superiori parte dorsi eius, et stringat infirmus anhelitum suum quantum possibile est ei.	Then have his feet placed on his back and extend his belly from the upper part of his back. The patient should hold their breath as much as possible.
Cogitur ergo cum collo uesicae ad expulsionem Lapidis ad posteriora: quare absoluitur Vrina.	Therefore, pressure is applied to the neck of the bladder towards the rear for the expulsion of the stone, and thus urine is released.
Quod si non soluitur cum eo quod diximus, et uehemens sit res super infirmum: tunc oportet ut administres extractionem eius cum instrumento, quod nominatur siringa, cuius haec est forma Sit ex argento, et sit subtile, lene, concauum sicut cannula pennae auis in subtilitate radii, longum in similitudine palmi unius et medii: cui sit cannula subtilis in capite eius.	If it does not dissolve with what we have said and the situation is urgent for the patient, then you should administer extraction using an instrument called a "syringe," which has this form: It should be made of silver, thin, smooth, hollow like a quill's cannula in its fineness, long resembling the length of one and a half palms, with a fine cannula at its tip.
Et modus exitus Vrinae per ipsum est, ut accipias filum duplicatum, et liges in extremitate eius lanam, aut cotum, ligatura bona: et intromittas extremitatem fili in inferiori parte Siringae: et incide cum forficibus si superfluit aliquid ex lana, uerum intromitte in cannulam cum uehementia, sicut alzer.	The method of extracting urine through it is as follows: Take a doubled thread and tie wool or cotton securely at its end. Insert the thread's tip into the lower part of the syringe, then cut any excess wool with scissors, but insert it forcefully into the cannula like squeezing water from a sponge.
Deinde inunge siringam cum oleo, aut cum butyro, et albugine oui: et fac sedere infirmum super sedem, et embroca uesicam, et ipsius uirgam cum oleis humidis, et oleo oliuae, et aqua tepida.	Then grease the syringe with oil, butter, and egg white. Have the patient sit on a chair, then catheterize the bladder and its tube with warm olive oil and water.
Deinde intromitte siringam in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat ad radicem uirgae.	Then insert the syringe into the tube gently until it reaches the root of the tube.
Deinde dupla ipsam superius a parte umbilici.	Then press it twice on the upper side near the navel.
Deinde impelle siringam intra ipsam, donec perueniat ad Vesicam, et sentiat eam infirmus iam peruenisse ad rem uacuam: et non fit hoc secundum hunc ordinem, nisi quoniam meatus, in quo uadit, est in quo est tortuositas.	Then push the syringe further until it reaches the bladder, and the patient feels that it has reached an empty space. This should be done gently, especially if the passage is tortuous.
Deinde extende filum cum lana paulatim.	Next, slowly extend the thread with wool attached.
Vrina enim sequetur lanam.	For indeed the stone will follow the wool.
Deinde extrahe eam, et fac currere Vrinam per uiam urinae: et itera siringam, et non cesses facere illud, donec euacuetur uesica, et inueniat infirmus alleuiationem.	Then pull it out and cause the stone to pass through the urine pathway. Repeat the syringing process until the bladder is emptied and the patient finds relief.
¶ De qualitate clisterizationis uesicae cum Clepshydra.	On the Nature of Catheterizing the Bladder with a Waterclock
Caput LIX.	Chapter 59
Quando accidit in uesica ulcus, aut sanguis in ea congelatur, aut coartatur in ea pus, et uis distillare in eam aquas et medicinas: tunc fiat cum instrumento quod nominatur Clepshydra, et haec est forma eius.	When an ulcer occurs in the bladder or blood congeals in it, or pus collects and distills water and medicines cannot reach it, use the instrument called a Clepsydra, which is shaped as follows:
Est enim surda, id est, clausa.	It is indeed deaf, that is to say, closed.
Et in eo sunt tria foramina, duo ex parte una, et unum ex parte altera, sicut uides.	And it has three holes, two on one side and one on the other, as you can see.
Et locus concauus, in quo est illud quod impellit, sit secundum quantitatem quod opilet ipsum sine additione, donec quando trahitur cum eo aliquid, ex humiditatibus attrahatur: et quando impellitur, cum eo expellatur ad longinquum: secundum quod facit clepshydra, qua proiicitur naphta, id est, ignis graecus in praeliis martis.	And the concave space where the piston is located should be exactly suited to its size without any addition. When it is pulled out along with something inside it, liquid is drawn from the humidity; when pushed, it expels the liquid far away, just like a waterclock that throws naphta (Greek fire) in naval battles.
Cum ergo uis proiicere humiditates in uesicam, intromitte extremitatem clepshydrae in humiditatem, et trahe cum eo quod impellit ad superiora, humiditas enim trahitur in concauitatem clepshydrae.	When you wish to introduce liquids into the bladder, insert the end of the Clepsydra into the liquid and pull up the piston. The liquid will be drawn into the concave space of the Clepshydra.
Deinde intromitte extremitatem eius in uirgam, secundum quod narrauimus in siringa.	Then insert its tip into the urinary meatus as described for a syringe.
Deinde impelle humiditatem cum eo quod impellit illa namque humiditas peruenit ad uesicam statim, ita quod sentit eam infirmus.	Then push the liquid with the piston; this liquid will immediately reach the bladder so that the patient feels it.
Forma clisteris subtilis quo clisterizatur uesica.	The shape of the thin catheter used for catheterizing the bladder
Fiat ex argento, aut auricalco: cuius caput altius sit simile alcama paruo, et sub eo sinus inter quem cadat ligamentum.	Make it from silver or gold. Its tip should be shaped like a small trumpet with a cavity underneath where the ligature is attached.
Deinde accipe uesicam arietis, et pone in ea humiditatem, qua uis clisterizare uesicam.	Then take a ram's bladder and apply moisture to it for use as an enema.
Deinde liga eam inter duos sinus ligatura forti cum filo duplo: et calefac illam humiditatem parumper super ignem.	Next, tie the bladder between two cavities with a strong thread doubled over, and gently warm the moisture on a fire.
Deinde intromitte extremitatem clisteris in uirgam, postea stringe manum tuam super uesicam cum humiditate strictura decenti, donec sentiat infirmus, quod illa humiditas iam peruenit ad uesicam.	Then insert the tip of the enema into the rectum, and afterwards apply your hand over the bladder with appropriate pressure until the patient feels that the moisture has reached the rectum.
Si autem non est tibi praesens uesica, tunc accipe frustum pergameni, et fac ex eo circulum, et perfora ipsum ab omni rotunditate sua.	If a bladder is not available, then take a piece of parchment and make it into a circle. Poke holes around the entire circumference of the circle.
Deinde intromitte filum forte in illis foraminibus, sicut reuoluuntur.	Then insert a strong thread through these holes as they revolve.
Deinde aggrega circulum, sicut aggregatur alsofratu: postquam tu ponis in eo illud quod uis ex humiditatibus, et oleis, et aquis.	Next, gather the circle together like a drawstring purse; after which you may place within it whatever moist substance, oils, or waters you desire.
Deinde liga ipsum in instrumento: et fac cum eo sicut fecisti cum uesica ex expressione cum manu tua, donec perueniat humiditas ad uesicam.	Then tie the instrument shut and proceed with it as you would have with a bladder by expressing its contents with your hand until the moisture reaches the rectum.
¶ De extractione Lapidis.	Chapter on Removing Stones
Caput LX.	Chapter 60
Iam diximus in diuisione species Lapidis, et curationem eius cum medicinis: et dixi differentiam inter Lapidem generatum in renibus, et uesica, et signa illius totius: et dixi Lapidem in quo cadit operatio cum manu et sectio: et est Lapis generatus in uesica proprie: et ille qui figitur in uirga: et ego sum narrans illud cum expositione manifesta et abbreuiatione.	We have already spoken about the classification of stones and their treatment with medications. We also discussed the difference between stones originating in the kidneys and bladder, as well as their symptoms. We mentioned how to operate on stones and perform lithotomy, specifically for stones generated within the bladder and those lodged in the urethra. I will now explain the procedure clearly and concisely.
Dico ergo, quod Lapis generatus in uesica, plurimum accidit pueris.	I say therefore that stones generated in the bladder most commonly occur in children.
Et ex signis eius est, quod urina egreditur ex uesica similis aquae in subtilitate sua: et apparet in ea harena alba, et fricat infirmus uirgam suam, et laborat cum ea, et multotiens pendet.	The symptoms of such a stone include urine exiting the bladder like water in its fineness, along with white sand appearing in it. The patient also experiences discomfort and irritation in the urethra while urinating, and often struggles or hesitates to finish.
Deinde erigitur, et egreditur cum eo anus in multis eorum.	Then, erection occurs and a piece of stone exits through the anus in many cases.
Et est facilis sanatio puerorum, ex eo usquequo consequuntur quatuordecim annos.	The healing of children is easy until they reach fourteen years.
Et est difficilis in senibus.	And it is difficult in the elderly.
In iuuenibus autem est media, in eo quod est inter illud: et eius cuius Lapis est maior, curatio facilior: et si paruus, est econuerso illius cura.	But in young people it is intermediate; in that which is between the two extremes, cure is easier if the stone is larger; but if small, its treatment is conversely more difficult.
Cum ergo peruenimus ad curationem, oportet in primis, ut mundificemus infirmum cum clisteri, quod extrahat totum stercus quod est in intestinis suis: ipsum enim quandoque prohibet inuentionem Lapidis apud inquisitionem.	Therefore, when we come to treatment, it is first necessary to cleanse the patient with a clyster that removes all waste from their bowels; for this sometimes prevents the detection of the stone during examination.
Deinde accipiatur infirmus cum pedibus suis, et concutiatur, et moueatur ad inferiora: ut descendat Lapis ad profundum uesicae, aut saliat de loco alto aliquotiens.	Then take the patient with their feet and shake them and move them towards their lower parts so that the stone descends to the bottom of the bladder or sometimes jumps from a high place.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas praeparatum, et manus eius sint sub coxis ipsius, ut fiat uesica tota decliuis ad inferiora.	Then have him sit between your hands prepared, and his hands should be under his hips so that the bladder is completely inclined towards its lower parts.
Deinde perquire eum, et tange eum extrinsecus.	Then examine him and touch him externally.
Si ergo sentis Lapidem in spacio, tunc propera statim cum sectione super ipsum.	If you feel the stone in space, then immediately proceed with an incision above it.
Quod si non cadat sub tactu tuo omnino, tunc oportet ut abstergas digitum indicem cum oleo manus sinistrae, si infirmus est puer: aut digitum medium si est iuuenis completus: et intromittas ipsum in anum suum, et perquire de Lapide, donec stat sub digito tuo: et conuerte eum paulatim ad collum uesicae.	But if it does not fall under your touch at all, then you must cleanse your left index finger with oil (if the patient is a child) or middle finger (if an adult), and insert it into their anus to search for the stone until it is located beneath your finger; then gradually turn it towards the neck of the bladder.
Deinde preme super ipsum cum digito tuo, et impelle ipsum ad exteriora aduersus locus, cuius sectionem uis: et praecipe ministro, ut premat uesicam manu sua, et praecipe alii ministro, ut extendat testiculos manu sua dextra ad superiora: et alia manu sua, ut remoueat cutem, quae est sub testiculis in parte a loco in quo est sectio.	Then press upon it with your finger and push it towards the location of the incision that you wish to make; and order an assistant to press on the bladder with their hand, and another assistant to extend the testicles upwards with their right hand while removing the skin that is below them in the area where the incision will be made.
Deinde intromitte Spatumile incidens, cuius forma haec est.	Then insert the spatula incising, which has this shape:
Et finde in eo quod est inter anum et testiculos, et non in medio, ad latus natis sinistrae: et sit sectio super ipsum lapidem, et digitus tuus sit in ano: et fiat sectio transuersa, ut sit sectio exterius ampla, et interius stricta, secundum quantitatem quod sit possibile egressio Lapidis ex ea non maior.	And find it between the anus and testicles, not in the middle but to the left side of the navel; make the incision directly over the stone while your finger is still in the anus. Make the incision transverse so that it is wide externally and narrow internally, according to what is possible for the emergence of the stone from it without being too large.
Fortasse enim comprimit digitus, qui est in ano Lapidem apud sectionem, et egreditur absque difficultate.	Perhaps your finger, which is inserted into the anus at the time of the incision, compresses the stone and causes it to emerge without difficulty.
Et scias, quod ex Lapide est cui sunt anguli et margines, quare fit difficilis exitus eius propter illud.	Know that a stone with corners or edges makes its exit difficult on account of this.
Et ex eo est lenis, similis glandulae, et rotundus: et fit facilis egressus eius.	And one that is smooth and round like a gland exits easily.
Ei ergo cui sunt anguli, et margines, adde in fissura.	Therefore, for one with corners and edges, make an incision in the furrow.
Quod si non egreditur ita, tunc oportet ut ingenies super ipsum: aut stringas super eum cum gesti decenter, cuius extremitas sit sicut Luna, quae stringat super Lapidem, et non euadat ab ea: aut ut intromittas sub eo instrumentum subtile, curuatae extremitatis.	But if it does not come out that way, then you must try this: either place a loop over it with the hand properly positioned, its end shaped like a crescent moon to grasp the stone and not slip away from it; or else insert beneath it a thin instrument with a curved tip.
Si autem non potes super cum, tunc amplifica foramen parumper.	But if you cannot do this, then enlarge the opening somewhat.
Quod si uincit te aliquid ex sanguine, abscinde ipsum cum zegi.	If anything troublesome occurs concerning blood, cut it off with a cautery.
Si uero lapis est plus quam unus, tunc impelle in primis magnum ad os uesicae.	But if the stone is larger than one, then first insert a large bougie into the urethra.
Deinde incide super ipsum.	Then make an incision over it.
Postea impelle paruum post illud: et similiter fac si sunt plures duobus.	Next, insert a small one behind it; do likewise if there are more than two.
Quod si magnus est ualde, tunc ignorantia est ut seces super ipsum sectione magna.	But if it is very large, then it is ignorance to attempt an incision over it that is too large.
Quoniam accidit infirmo una duarum rerum, aut ut moriatur, aut accidit ei distillatio urinae assidua: proptera, quia non consolidatur locus omnino.	For the patient will suffer one of two things: either he will die, or else continuous dripping of urine will occur, because the place will not heal at all.
Verum administra expulsionem eius, donec egrediatur: aut ingenia in fractura eius cum forficibus, donec extrahas eum frustatim.	But continue to dilate it until it emerges; or else attempt to fracture it with forceps and remove it piece by piece.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc imple uulnus thure, et aloe, et sanguine draconis: et stringe ipsum, et pone super ipsum pannum infusum oleo et uino, aut oleo rosato, et aqua frigida: ut sedetur apostema calidum.	When you have completed your operation, then fill the wound with frankincense, aloe, and dragon's blood; bind it up and place over it a cloth soaked in oil and wine, or rose oil and cold water, so that the swelling may subside.
Deinde resupina infirmum super collum suum, et non soluas ligamentum, usque ad diem tertium.	Then lay the patient on their back with their head hanging over the edge of a bed or similar support, without loosening the bandage until the third day.
Cum ergo solueris ipsum, embroca locum cum aqua, et oleo multo.	When you have loosened it, wash the area with water and plenty of oil.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dyafinicon, et unguento basilicon, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with salve of diaphoretic and salve of basilicon until healed.
Si autem accidit in uulnere apostema calidum additum, et corrosi, et illi similia: sicut si congeletur sanguis in uesica, et prohibeatur ex eo urina: et cognoscitur illud ex egressione sanguinis cum urina.	But if a hot abscess forms in the wound and causes corrosion or similar symptoms, such as when blood coagulates in the bladder and obstructs the flow of urine, this can be recognized by the emission of bloody urine.
Intromitte ergo digitum tuum in uulnus, et extrahe illum sanguinem.	Then insert your finger into the wound and draw out the blood.
Nam si remanet, prouocat ad corruptionem uesicae, et putrefactionem eius.	For if it remains, it will cause corrosion and gangrene of the bladder.
Deinde ablue uulnus cum aceto, et aqua, et sale: et oppone omni speciei cum eo quod conuenit ex curatione, usquequo sanetur.	Then wash the wound with vinegar, water, and salt, and apply whatever suitable remedy applies until healed.
Et oportet in horis curationis totius, ut liges duas coxas, et aggreges, caussa medicinarum quae ponuntur super locum.	And during the entire period of treatment, it is necessary to bind both thighs together and press them closely together, so that medicinal substances placed on the area are retained in place.
Quod si lapis est paruus, et sit in meatu uirgae, et figitur in eo, et prohibetur urinae exitus: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod narro antequam peruenias ad sectionem.	But if the stone is small and located in the urethra at the bladder neck, and blocks the passage of urine, then treat it with the remedy I have mentioned before resorting to surgical intervention.
Multotiens enim a sectione excusaris per hanc curationem, iam enim probaui illud.	For often you will be spared surgical intervention by this treatment, as I have proven its effectiveness many times.
Et est, ut accipias Perforatorium ex ferro alferico, cuius haec est forma, triangulatae extremitatis, acutum, fixum in ligno.	And you should take a perforator made of iron steel, which has the shape of a triangular point and is sharp, fixed into wood.
Deinde accipe filum, et liga cum eo uirgam sub lapide ut non redeat ad uesicam.	Then take a thread and tie it around the penis below the stone so that it does not slip back up into the bladder.
Deinde intromitte ferrum perforans in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat Perforatorium ad ipsum lapidem: et reuolue Perforatorium manu tua in ipso lapide paulatim: et coneris perforationem eius, donec facias ipsum penetrare a parte altera.	Then carefully insert the perforator into the penis until it reaches the stone. Then gradually rotate the perforator with your hand on the stone and attempt to pierce it until you break through to the other side.
Urina namque absoluitur statim.	The urine is immediately relieved.
Deinde preme manum tuam super illud quod remansit ex lapide ab exteriori parte uirgae.	Then press your hand on that which remains of the stone from the external part of the penis.
Ipse enim frangitur, et egreditur cum urina, et sanatur infirmus.	For it will break apart and come out with the urine, and the patient will be healed.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi haec curatio, propter aliquid quod prohibet ab illo: tunc liga filum sub lapide, et filum aliud supra lapidem.	But if this treatment is not possible due to some obstacle preventing it, then tie a thread beneath the stone and another above it.
Deinde seca super lapidem in ipsa uirga inter duas ligaturas.	Then cut over the stone on the penis between the two ligatures.
Deinde extrahe ipsum.	Then extract it.
Postea solue ligamentum, et mundifica sanguinem congelatum, qui fit in uulnere.	Afterwards, untie the ligature and cleanse the congealed blood that forms at the wound.
Et non est necessarium ligamentum fili sub lapide, nisi ut non redeat ad uesicam: et ligamentum aliud desuper, nisi ut quando soluitur filum post egressionem lapidis, redeat cutis ad locum suum, et cooperiat uulnus: et propter illud necesse est tibi illud quando ligas filum superius, ut eleues cutem ad superiora, ut redeat apud complementum tuum, et cooperiat uulnus, sicut diximus.	And it is not necessary to tie a thread beneath the stone unless to prevent it from returning to the bladder. And another thread above it is only necessary so that when the thread is untied after the stone has come out, the skin will return to its place and cover the wound. And for this reason, when you tie the thread above, you must raise the skin upwards so that it returns to its original position and covers the wound, as we have said.
¶ De extractione Lapidis mulierum.	Chapter on the Extraction of a Woman's Stone
Caput LXI.	Chapter 61
Parum generatur Lapis in mulieribus.	A stone is rarely produced in women.
Si autem accidat alicui earum lapis, tunc difficilis est curatio, et prohibetur propter modos multos.	But if it happens to any of them that she has a stone, then treatment is difficult and prevented by many obstacles.
Vnus eorum est: quod mulier fortasse est uirgo.	One of these obstacles is: perhaps the woman is a virgin.
Et secundus est, quia tu non inuenis mulierem quae detegat seipsam medico, quando est casta, aut ex habentibus maritos.	And the second obstacle is: because you cannot find a woman who reveals herself to a physician when she is chaste or has had no marital relations.
Tertius est, quia tu non inuenis mulierem bene scientem hanc artem, praecipue operationem cum manu.	The third obstacle is: because you cannot find a woman who knows this art well, especially the manual operation.
Et quartus est longinquitas a loco lapidis: quare indiget sectione profunda, et in illo est timor.	And the fourth obstacle is the remoteness of the stone's location, which requires a deep incision and causes fear.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad illud, tunc oportet ut accipias mulierem medicam, bene scientem: et parum inuenitur.	But if necessity demands it, then you should take a woman physician who is well-versed in the art, although they are few to be found.
Si uero priuaris ea, tunc quaere medicum castum, subtilem, et praesenta mulierem obstetricem bene doctam in re mulierum, aut mulierem quae in hac arte innuit partem artis: fac ergo eam praesentem, et praecipue ei, ut faciat totum quod praecipis ei ex inquisitione super lapidem.	But if you lack such a woman physician, then seek out a chaste and skilled male physician and present a female midwife who is well-versed in the art of women's health or another knowledgeable woman. Make sure she is present and instruct her to perform all that you order regarding the examination for the stone.
In primis quod est, ut aspiciat si mulier est uirgo: tunc oportet ut intromittat digitum in anum eius, et quaerat lapidem.	Firstly, she should examine whether the woman is a virgin. If so, she should insert her finger into the woman's anus and search for the stone.
Si ergo inuenit ipsum, coartet eum sub digito suo, et tunc praecipe obstetrici, ut intromittat digitum suum in uuluam infirmae, et inquirat super lapidem, postquam ponit manum suam sinistram super uesicam, et comprimit eam compressione bona.	If she finds the stone, she should grasp it with her finger. Then instruct the midwife to insert her finger into the patient's vulva and search for the stone after placing her left hand on the bladder and applying gentle pressure.
Si ergo inuenit lapidem, tunc oportet ut gradatim moueat eum ab orificio uesicae ad inferiora cum summa uirtutis suae, donec perueniat cum eo ad radicem coxae.	If she finds the stone, then she should gradually move it from the opening of the urethra downwards with all her strength until she reaches the root of the thigh.
Deinde secet super eum apud oppositionem medietatis uuluae apud radicem coxae, ex quacunque parte praeparatur ei, et sentit lapidem in illa parte: et digitus eius non remoueatur a lapide, coartans sub eo: et sit sectio parua in primis.	Then she should make an incision opposite the middle of the vulva at the root of the thigh, on whichever side the stone is felt. Her finger should not be removed from the stone while holding it in place, and the initial incision should be small.
Deinde intromittat radium super illam sectionem.	Then she should insert a probe through that incision.
Si ergo sentit lapidem, tunc addat in sectionem secundum quantitatem proportionatam quod lapis egreditur ab ea.	If she feels the stone, then she should enlarge the incision according to the size of the stone as it emerges from it.
Et scias, quod species lapidis sunt multae.	And know that stones have many forms.
Ex his enim est paruus, et magnus, lenis et asper, longus, et rotundus habens ramos.	They are small or large, smooth or rough, long or round with branches.
Scias ergo species eius, ut significetur tibi per hoc super illud quod uis.	Therefore, know the forms of stones so that you may be informed about their nature and your intentions.
Si ergo uincit te sanguis, tunc adde in loco zegi tritum, et tene ipsum hora una, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If bleeding defeats you, then apply powdered mallow in the place of the incision and hold it there for one hour until the bleeding stops.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec egrediatur lapis: et fac, ut praepares tecum ex instrumentis, quae dixi in extractione lapidis in uiris, ut adiuueris per ea in operatione tua.	Then return to your procedure until the stone emerges. And ensure that you have with you the instruments I mentioned for extracting stones from the bladder, so as to assist you in your procedure.
Quod si uincit te fluxus sanguinis, et scis quod expulsio sanguinis est ex arteria quae incisa est: tunc pone puluerem super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis strictura decenti: et non mutes illud: et dimitte lapidem, et non extrahas ipsum.	But if you are defeated by bleeding and know that the loss of blood is from an artery that has been cut, then place powder on the location and compress it with a suitable bandage; do not remove this [compression]; and leave the stone alone and do not attempt to extract it.
Fortasse enim morietur mulier infirma.	For perhaps the sick woman will die.
Deinde cura uulnus.	Then dress the wound.
Cum ergo sedatur acuitas sanguinis post dies, et putrefit locus, tune redi ad operationem tuam, donec egrediatur lapis.	After several days when the bleeding has subsided and the location becomes infected, then return to your procedure until the stone emerges.
¶ De sectione suiper Herniam aquosam.	Chapter on the Incision of a Hydrocele.
Caput LXII.	Chapter 62
Ramex aquosa non est, nisi aggregatio humiditatis in sifac albo, quod est sub cute testiculi continente ouum: et nominatur sifac.	A watery tumor is not anything other than an accumulation of fluid in the tunica albuginea, which is beneath the skin that contains the testis; and it is called a tunica.
Et quandoque est in panniculo proprio sibi, quem praeparauit ei natura in parte oui, donec putetur: quod est ouum aliud, et est cutis testiculi inter sifac album, quod diximus: et non fit illud nisi raro.	And sometimes it is enclosed within its own membrane, which nature has prepared for it in the part of the testis until it becomes hard; this is another testis, and it is the skin of the testis between the tunica albuginea that we have mentioned; and this occurs rarely.
Et generatio quidem huius ramicis, est ex debilitate quae accidit testiculis: quare effunditur ad eos haec materia.	The formation of such a tumor arises from weakness that befalls the testes, whence this material accumulates towards them.
Et quandoque accidit ex percussione super testiculos.	And sometimes it occurs as a result of injury to the testes.
Et haec humiditas est habens colores multos.	This fluid has many different colors.
Aut enim est color eius decliuis ad citrinitatem, aut est sanguineus rubeus, aut faeculentus, niger, aut est aquosus albus, et est illud quod est plus.	It may be yellowish, or red like blood, or black and foul-smelling, or it may be a clear white watery fluid, but the latter is more common.
Et signa quibus scitur ubi sit aggregatio aquae, sunt ista.	The signs by which one knows where there is an accumulation of water are these.
Nam si est in sifac albo quod diximus, tunc apostema est rotundum ad longitudinem parumper sicut figura oui: et non apparet testiculus, quoniam humiditas continet eum ab omni parte.	For if it is in the tunica albuginea that we have mentioned, then the tumor will be round, scarcely more than a finger's length, like the shape of an egg; and the testis itself will not be apparent because the fluid surrounds it on all sides.
Et si est humiditas in panniculo proprio sibi, tunc apostema est rotundum cum parte oui, et propter hoc extimat homo quia est ouum aliud.	But if there is fluid in the tunic of its own, then the tumor will be round with an egg-like portion, and because of this the man may think that it is another testicle.
Et si humiditas est inter cutem testiculorum et sifac album, tunc cadit sub sensu.	But if the fluid is between the skin of the testes and the tunica albuginea, then it falls under sensation.
Quando ergo uis cognitionem coloris humiditatis, tunc experire colorem humiditatis in apostemate cum Intromisso quadrato, cuius forma praecessit.	Therefore, when you wish to determine the color of the fluid, then examine the color of the fluid in the tumor by inserting a square probe, whose form has preceded.
Secundum illud ergo quod egreditur in uestigio Intromissi, iudica de illo quod est inter ipsum.	Therefore, according to what emerges at the point of insertion, judge about that which is between them.
Cum ergo uenimus ad curationem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, ut phlebotometur si possibile est ei illud, et uides corpus eius plenum.	When we come to the treatment with iron, then it is necessary that you order the patient, if possible for him, to undergo bloodletting, and see that his body is full.
Deinde resupinetur super dorsum suum super rem altam parum, et pone sub eo pannos multos.	Then he should lie on his back upon something high and place many cloths beneath him.
Deinde sede tu super sinistram eius, et praecipe ministro, ut sedeat a dextra eius, qui extendat uirgam eius ad unum duorum laterum cutis testiculorum, et ad partem mirach uentris.	Then you should sit on the left side of him and order an assistant to sit on his right side, who will stretch out the penis towards one of the two sides of the skin of the testes, and towards the part called the "mirah" of the belly.
Deinde accipe spatumile latum, et seca cutem testiculorum ex medio per longitudinem, usque prope pectinem: et fiat sectio secundum rectitudinem aequedistantis lineae quae diuidit cutem testiculorum, donec perueniat ad sifac album comprehendens: et excoria ipsum et obserua, uel caue ex hoc, ut seces ipsum: et sit excoriatio tua qua ipsum excorias, ex parte quae suspenditur cum ouo plus: et subtiliter scrutare cum excoriatione secundum quantitatem quod tibi possibile est.	Then take a broad scalpel and cut the skin of the testes from the middle lengthwise until near the pubic hair: and let the incision be made straight according to the line that divides the skin of the testes equally, until it reaches the tunica albuginea enclosing it: and strip off this skin and observe carefully, or else avoid cutting it, for fear of damaging it; and let your stripping away of the skin be on the side which hangs down more with the testis: and search carefully with the stripping according to what is possible for you.
Deinde perfora sifac plenum aqua perforatione ampla, et extrahe totam aquam.	Then bore through the full tunica albuginea with a wide borehole and draw out all of the water.
Deinde separa inter duo labia sectionis cum uncinis, et extende sifac ad superiora, et non tangas cutem testiculorum comprehendentem: et incide sifac qualitercunque est possibile tibi incidere ipsum, aut cum totalitate sua, aut frustatim, praecipue latus eius subtile.	Then separate the two lips of the incision with forceps and extend the tunica albuginea upwards without touching the skin that surrounds the testicles; and cut the tunica as much as possible either entirely or in pieces, especially its thin side.
Nam si tu non exquisite perscrutaris, in incisione eius non fit securitas, quin aqua redeat.	For if you do not carefully examine it in the incision, there is no safety that water will not return.
Si autem procedit ouum exterius a cute sua in hora operationis tuae: tunc quando compleueris sectionem sifac, reduc ipsum.	But if an egg protrudes externally from its skin during your operation: then when you have completed the incision of the tunica albuginea, push it back.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cutis testiculorum cum sutura.	Then join together the two lips of the skin around the testicles with a stitch.
Deinde cura ipsum sicut reliqua uulnera, donec sanetur.	Then treat it like other wounds until it heals.
Quod si inuenis ouum corruptum ex nigredine alia, tunc oportet ut liges uasa, quae sunt suspensorium, timens fluxum sanguinis.	But if you find that the egg is corrupted by blackness: then you should tie off the vessels which are the suspensiony ligaments, fearing blood flow.
Deinde abscinde testiculum cum suspensorio, et extrahe ouum: postea cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	Then cut off the testicle with its suspension ligament and remove the egg; afterwards treat it as we have said.
Si uero aqua est aggregata in duabus partibus, tunc scias quia sunt duae ramices: seca ergo partem aliam secundum quod fecisti in altera aequaliter.	But if water is collected in two parts, know that there are two branches; therefore cut the other part equally as you did the first one.
Et si aequatur tibi, ut sit operatio una, tunc fac: deinde absterge sanguinem.	And if it seems equal to you that it should be one operation, then do so; afterwards wipe away the blood.
Et intromitte in sectiones lanam submersam in oleo, aut in oleo rosato: et pone deforis lanam aliam quam submersisti in uino et oleo, et expande eam super duos testiculos, et mirach uentris: et pone desuper pannos duplicatos, et sunt puluilli: et liga eos desuper cum ligamento, quod est habens sex secundum hanc formam.	And insert into the incisions wool soaked in oil or rose oil; and place outside more wool that has been soaked in wine and oil, and spread it over both testicles and the abdomen; then put on top of it doubled cloths which are bandages, and bind them together with a ligature that is six fingers wide according to this form.
Deinde sumantur duo panni, et suantur, et impleantur la na carminata, secundum hanc similitudinem: et fiant extremitates quibus premitur ex coto, aut lana humida: et aggregentur cum strictura in lumbari bracharum: et una extremitatum accipiat super anum usque ad dorsum, et secunda accipiat ad partem pectinis: et duae extremitates super duas coxas inferius, et duae extremitates aliae super duo inguina, et aggregetur strictura tota in lumbari bracharum.	Then take two cloths and soak them, fill them with red wool like this; and make their ends to press on with cotton or wet wool; and tie them together with a bandage at the level of the hips: one end should go over the anus up to the back, and the second to the chest part, and two other ends should go under both thighs and two more ends on both groins, and all bands should be tied together at the level of the hips.
Et, quandoque artificialiter medicatur haec ramex cum cauterio loco sectionis cum ferro: et est, ut accipias cauterium cultellare subtile, et seces cum eo cutem testiculorum: et est ignitum, secundum quod narrauimus: donec quando detegitur sifac album continens aquam: tunc accipe cauterium, secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes this instrument is artificially treated with a cautery instead of the knife at the place of section; and take a sharp knife cautery, and cut the skin of the testicles with it, and heat it as we have described until when white smoke containing water appears: then take the cautery in this form.
Assimilatur literae graecae.	The letters are Greek.
Deinde perfora cum eo illud sifac, et est ignitum, donec egrediatur humiditas tota.	Then pierce that opening with it and heat it until all moisture has come out.
Deinde extende sifac cum uncinis, et excoria cum cauterio subtili ignito, et incide ipsum secundum quod possibile est tibi, donec eradices totum eius.	Then stretch the opening with hooks and scrape it clean with a hot sharp cautery, and cut into it as much as you can until you have removed all of it.
Et caue ex ouo, ne tangat ipsum ignis.	And take care that the egg does not touch the fire.
Et scias, quod haec operatio est saluior, et longinquior a fluxu sanguinis, et melior quam operatio cum sectione.	Know that this operation is safer and less likely to cause bleeding, and better than an operation with cutting.
Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit in hora sectionis, aut in hora cauterii apostema calidum, aut fluxus sanguinis, aut aliquid aliud: tunc oportet ut cures quod contrarietatem tibi facit ex illo cum curatione quae conuenit ei, secundum quod praemissum est.	But if during the time of section or cautery, a hot abscess or bleeding or anything else happens that opposes you, then it is necessary to treat what opposes you with the treatment that suits it, according to what has been stated.
Si autem infirmus est timidus, et non expectat super hanc operationem, propter horribilitatem suam: tunc administra perforationem secundum quod ego narro illud: et est.	But if the patient is fearful and does not await this operation because of its horrible nature, then perform the perforation as I describe it now: And thus.
Quando certificatur tibi apud te per illud quod diximus de significationibus, quod ramex est aquosa: tunc oportet quod facias sedere infirmum super sedem eleuatam.	When you have confirmed through what we said about the meanings that the instrument is watery, then make the patient sit on a raised seat.
Deinde perfora apostema in inferiori parte sui cum spatumili lato: et pone perforationem secundum longitudinem corporis, et sit apertio ampla, donec currat aqua tota.	Then pierce the abscess at its lower part with a broad spatula and make the opening along the length of the body so that all water may flow out.
Deinde pone super locum cotum, et liga ipsum, et dimitte ipsum ut currat residuum aquae: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Next, place a cloth on the area and tie it, allowing the remaining water to run off; then treat it until the wound heals.
Si autem contrarietas sit egressioni aquae in hora qua perforas ipsam: et non sit illud nisi propterea, quia panniculus albus contrarietatem facit in orificio uulneris, et prohibet exitum aquae: tunc oportet ut intromittas pennam in uulnus, aut instrumentum cum quo extrahitur aqua hydropicorum, cuius forma praecessit: aut adde in operatione uulneris parumper.	But if there is obstruction to the outflow of water at the time when it is pierced and this happens only because a piece of cloth causes an obstacle at the wound's opening, preventing the exit of water, then you must insert a feather into the wound or use an instrument with which water is drawn out from dropsy, the shape of which has been previously described. Otherwise, wait briefly during the operation on the wound.
Et scias, quod aqua redit, et aggregatur post sex menses, aut circiter eos.	Know that the water returns and accumulates again after six months or roughly that period.
Cum ergo aggregatur, tunc pertoretur secundum eundem modum, et pertransibit infirmus dies suos.	Therefore, when it collects again, pierce it in the same manner, and the patient shall spend their days accordingly.
¶ De cura Ramicis carnosae.	Chapter on the treatment of flesh-colored growths (warts).
Caput LXIII.	Chapter 63
Scias, quod in sectione super hanc Ramicem, est ex timore perducente ad perniciem in pluribus dispositionibus.	Know that cutting this wen [wart] often leads to further harm due to the fear-induced movements of many people.
Quapropter uidetur mihi eius dimissio saluari ex ea.	Therefore, it seems to me that letting it alone would be the safer course.
Et ego sum rememorans operationem in ea, et species apostematis.	And I remember an operation performed on one such wen and its appearance as an abscess.
Dico ergo, quod accidunt apostemata multa in corporibus, ex quibus componuntur testiculi: et fit illud ex caussis multis, scilicet.	Therefore, many abscesses occur in the body, from which testicles are formed; this happens due to many causes.
Aut ex superfluitate acuta, uel acri, quae effunditur ad testiculos.	Or from an acute or sharp excess that flows towards the testicles.
Aut ex percussione.	Or from injury by blows.
Et est color apostematis secundum colorem corporis, et non inuenitur ei dolor: et est apostema graue.	And the color of the abscess is similar to the color of the body itself and it does not cause pain; nonetheless, it is a serious abscess.
Et fortasse est apostema lapideum, cuius color est fuscus, et non est sensus ei.	And perhaps there is a stony-like abscess, which has a dark color but no sensation or feeling attached to it.
Et quandoque fit ex nodatione arteriarum, et inflatione earum: sicut iam praecessit eius rememoratio: aut ex inflatione uenarum.	And sometimes it occurs due to the blockage of arteries and their swelling, as has already been mentioned, or from the swelling of veins.
Quod ergo est ex eis ex inflatione arteriarum, cognoscitur per dispositionem apostematis, quando comprimis ipsum digitis tuis.	Therefore, when you press on it with your fingers, you can recognize whether the abscess is due to arterial swelling by its pulsating sensation.
Et non oportet ut tangas ipsum prorsus.	Do not touch it at all.
Illud uero quod fit ex inflatione uenarum, non dispergitur ex eo aliquid apud compressionem cum digitis.	But that which is caused by swelling of the veins does not disappear upon pressing with fingers.
Et iam possibile est, quod super hanc speciem fiat sectio, et super reliquas carnes: et est, ut seces cutem testiculorum.	And now it is possible for an incision to be made over this type of swelling and over other flesh: the skin of the testicles should be slit open.
Deinde extende ouum ad sursum, et extrahe ipsum cum sifach albo: et libera suspensorium ex uasis, et liga uasa: et incide suspensorium postquam tu liberas ipsum ab omni parte ex partibus oui.	Then draw the testicle upwards and remove it together with its white tunic. Free the suspensory ligament from the blood vessels and tie them off. Finally, cut the suspensory ligament after you have freed it completely from all parts of the testicle.
Si ergo ouum consolidatum est cum illis carnibus natis, tunc oportet ut attrahas ouum, et incidas ipsum.	If however the testicle has grown together with the surrounding tissues, then draw the testicle back and make an incision into it.
Et si adhaerentia est inter aliquid ex siphaket, aut in eo quod est inter uasa: tunc oportet ut liberes totam illam adhaerentiam, et incidas eam incisione rotunda.	And if there is adherence between any part of the scrotum or between the blood vessels, then you should free all that adhering tissue and cut it with a round incision.
Si autem est natiuitas carnis in loco adhaerentiae quae est retro: tunc oportet ut incidas totum eius, et extrahas ouum, sicut diximus.	But if there is growth of flesh in the place where the adhesion was behind, then you should cut through all of it and remove the testicle as we have said.
Cum ergo completur operatio tua, tnnc imple uulnus in lana infusa in oleo rosato, et uino: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	After you have completed your operation, then fill the wound with wool soaked in rose oil and wine. Then care for it with the usual treatment until it heals.
¶ De cura Ramicis, quae est cum Vite.	On the Treatment of Hemorrhoids
Caput LXIIII.	Chapter 64
Uitis est apostema inuolutum quadam inuolutione, simile botro, cum mollificatione testiculorum: et fit difficilis super infirmum motus et exercitium, et deambulatio.	If an abscess has formed around the scrotum, resembling a bubble and accompanied by swelling of the testicles, it becomes difficult for the patient to move about and exercise, as well as to walk.
Et in curatione huius aegritudinis est ex timore, propter illud cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And in treating this condition, there is a concern due to what preceded it, as mentioned earlier.
Verum oportet, ut dicamus operationem in ea secundum quod fecerunt primi.	However, we must mention the operation performed on such cases by those who came before us.
Dico ergo, quod oportet ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem eleuatam.	I say therefore that you should make the patient sit on a raised seat.
Deinde impelle suspensorium testiculorum ad inferiora.	Then push the testicles downwards with their suspensory ligaments.
Deinde tene cutem testiculorum cum digitis tuis, cum uasis quae sunt propinqua uirgae: et teneat ea minister alius, et extendat ea extensione uehementi.	Then hold the skin of the testicles with your fingers near to the penis. Another assistant should do this and stretch it forcefully.
Deinde incide cum spatumili lato acuto sectione transuersa in directo uasorum, donec detegantur uasa.	Then cut transversely with a broad, sharp blade across the direct path of the vessels until they are exposed.
Deinde excoria ab omni parte, sicut diximus tibi in extractione Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then strip it from every side, as we have told you regarding the extraction of arteries found in the temples.
Postea fige in eis acum in qua sit filum duplum, et liga ipsum in primo locorum quibus accidunt Vites: et liga ipsum iterum in ultimo eorum.	Next, insert a needle into it on which there is a double thread, and tie it at the first point where veins are encountered; then tie it again at the last of them.
Deinde seca ea in media sectione recta secundum longitudinem corporis, et extrahe quod aggregatur ex humiditatibus faeculentis corruptis.	Then cut it midway along a straight line according to the length of the body and remove what is accumulated from corrupt fetid humors.
Deinde cura uulnus cum curatione reliquorum uulnerum, in quibus uis generari saniem, ut cadant uasa quae nutriunt unum testiculorum.	Then dress the wound with the dressing of other wounds, in which pus is generated so that the vessels that nourish one of the testicles may fall.
Non est enim malum per illud.	For there is no harm from this.
Si autem accidat Vitis omnibus uasis, tunc oportet ut extrahantur propter hoc testiculi cum uasis: ut non priuetur ouum nutrimento, propter incisionem, et tabescat, uel arescat, et non sit iuuamentum cum eis.	But if all the veins are affected, then it is necessary to remove both testicles with their vessels so that the egg may not be deprived of its nourishment due to the cutting and thus shrivel or dry up without being beneficial.
¶ De cura Ramicis intestinalis.	Chapter on the treatment of rupture of the intestines.
Caput LXV.	Chapter 65.
Euentus huius Ramicis est ex sectione, quae accidit in sifach extenso super uentrem in parte inguinum ex mirach uentris.	The event of this rupture occurs from a cut that happens during stretching the sigmoid colon on the lower abdomen near the groin due to sudden distention of the belly.
Quare descendunt intestina ex illa Ruptura ad unum testiculorum.	Therefore, the intestines descend through that rupture to one of the testicles.
Et haec Ruptura est aut ex sifach, aut extensione eius.	And this rupture occurs either from the sigmoid colon itself or from its stretching.
Et accidunt istae duae species ex caussis multis.	These two types occur from many causes.
Aut ex percussione.	Or from a blow.
Aut saltu.	Or by falling.
Aut clamore.	Or by shouting loudly.
Aut eleuatione rei grauis, et similibus.	Or lifting of heavy objects and similar activities.
Et signum, quando est ex extensione sifach.	And the sign is when it occurs from stretching of the sigmoid colon.
Est quod accidit paulatim in tempore longo, et non accidit subito: et est apostema aequale uersus profundum: propterea, quod sifach comprimit intestinum.	It occurs gradually over time and not suddenly; there is an abscess directed towards the depths due to the sigmoid colon pressing on the intestine.
Et signum eius quando est ex sectione sifach, quia facit accidere ex principio sui dolorem uehementem subito: et est apostema diuersum, apparens sub cute propinque: et illud est propter exitum intestini, et cursus eius ad exteriora sifach.	When it occurs after an incision of the sigmoid colon, there is initially a sudden intense pain; moreover, a different abscess appears under the skin nearby due to the exit of the intestine and its course towards the outside of the sigmoid colon.
Et quandoque egreditur cum intestino zirbum: et nominatur haec Ramex intestinalis, et zirbia: et quandoque fit cum uentositate.	Sometimes it emerges along with the intestine's hernia; this is called "Ramex intestinalis" and "hernia." Sometimes it occurs with wind.
Et quandoque currit in intestinum stercus, et retinetur illic: et est cum eo pernicies infirmi: quoniam facit accidere dolorem prauum, et praecipue quando premitur.	Sometimes feces run into the intestine and get trapped there, causing harm to the patient; this is especially so when it causes severe pain upon pressure.
Et in curatione specierum aegritudinis huius cum ferro est timor: quare oportet ut caueatur casus in ea.	In treating such diseases with an iron instrument, there is fear of injury; therefore, caution should be exercised to avoid mishaps in this regard.
Et modus operationis est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut reducat intestinum manu sua ad interiora concauitatis suae, si obedit reditui.	The method of operation is as follows: order the patient to gently push their intestine back into place with their hand if it can be returned.
Deinde resupinetur super collum suum inter manus tuas: et eleua crura eius.	Then have the patient lie on their back between your hands, elevating their legs.
Deinde extende cutem quae sequitur cutem ad superiora, et seca cutem testiculorum totam per longitudinem.	Next, extend the skin that follows the scrotum upwards and cut the entire skin of the scrotum along its length.
Deinde fige in duobus labiis sectionis uncinos, secundum quod indiges ad aperiendum sectionem cum eis: et sectio sit secundum quantitatem, quod sit possibile, ut egrediatur ex ea ouum.	Then insert forceps into the two lips of the incision according to your need to open it; make the incision as wide as possible so that an egg can pass through it.
Deinde excoria siphak, et quae sunt sub cute testiculorum, donec quando detegitur sifach album, durum ab omni parte: tunc intromitte digitum tuum indicem in eo quod sequitur testiculum, in eo quod est inter siphach album, quod est sub cute oui, et inter sifach secundum, et absolue cum eo adhaerentiam quae est in posteriori parte oui.	Then strip off the sigmoid colon and the structures underneath the skin of the scrotum until you expose the white, hard part of the sigmoid colon on all sides. Then insert your index finger into the space between the testicle and the exposed sigmoid colon, pushing it gently without adhering to what is behind the egg-like structure.
Deinde moue cum manu dextra ad interiora cutem testiculorum: et cum hoc extende sifach album ad sursum, cum manu sinistra: et eleua ouum cum sifach ad partem sectionis: et praecipe ministro, ut extendat ouum ad sursum: et tu solue adhaerentiam, quae est retro solutione completa.	Then gently move the sigmoid colon with your right hand towards the inside of the skin of the scrotum. With your left hand, push the exposed white sigmoid colon upwards while lifting the egg along with it towards the incision site. Instruct an assistant to hold the egg upwards, and then carefully separate the adhesions behind it once completely freed.
Et quaere digitis tuis, ut non sit aliquid illic ex intestino inuoluto in sifach albo duro.	And search with your fingers to ensure there is nothing of the intestine wrapped around the rigid white sigmoid colon.
Si autem inuenis ex eo aliquid: tunc impelle ipsum ad uentrem inferius.	If you find anything wrapped around it, then push it down towards the lower abdomen.
Deinde accipe acum, in qua sit filum grossum, factum licinium ex decem filis: et intromitte ipsam apud postremum sifach, id est, tunicae, quod est sub cute testiculorum quae sequitur sectionem: deinde incide extremitates quae eminent ex filo, donec sint quatuor fila.	Then take a needle with a thick thread made of ten strands twisted together, and insert it into the last sigmoid colon. Then cut the ends that stick out from the thread until there are four threads remaining.
Deinde compone quaedam eorum super quaedam cum figura quae sit in modo crucis: et liga cum eis alsifach, de quo diximus, quia est sub cute testiculorum ligamento uehementi, donec non possit aliquod ex uasis, quae nutriunt eos mittere ad eos aliquid: ut non accidat inde apostema calidum.	Then arrange some of the threads over others in the shape of a cross, and tie them together with the alisfach (ligament) we mentioned earlier, which is located underneath the skin of the scrotum. Tie it tightly so that no fluid can flow into the testicles from any of the vessels, lest an inflamed abscess develop as a result.
Et pone iterum ligamentum secundum extra ligamentum primum, longinquum ab eo minus duobus digitis.	And place another ligament next to the first one, keeping it about two fingers' width away from it.
Et post ista duo ligamenta dimitte ex sifach, quod est sub cute testiculorum, quantitatem magnitudinis digiti: et incide reliquum totum secundum rotunditatem, et aufer ex eo ouum.	After tying the two ligaments, allow about one finger's width of sigmoid colon to remain beneath the skin of the scrotum. Then cut along the circumference and remove the egg (testicle).
Deinde seca in inferiori parte cutis testiculorum sectione, ex qua currit sanguis, et sanies: sicut narrauimus in eo quod praemissum est.	Then cut across the lower part of the skin of the scrotum where blood and pus are flowing out, as previously described.
Deinde administra lanam submersam in oleo, et pone in uulnus: et administra ligamentum quod narrauimus.	Then apply wool soaked in oil to the wound and secure it with the ligament mentioned earlier.
Et quandoque cauterizatur sifach album quod diximus, post incisionem eius timendo de fluxu sanguinis.	And sometimes cauterize the white sigmoid colon that we have mentioned after its incision to prevent bleeding.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	For this happens very often.
Et dimitte ligamentum, donec cadat per se.	Leave the ligature in place until it falls off on its own.
Si autem tardatur casus eius, tunc embrocetur cum aqua calida: et pone super ipsum illud quod diximus, donec cadat.	But if its falling off is delayed, then apply warm water and put on top of it what we have mentioned until it falls off.
Deinde cura uulnus cum reliqua curatione uulnerum, donec curetur.	Then dress the wound with the usual dressing for wounds until it heals.
¶ De Ramice uentosa.	Chapter on Hemorrhoids.
Caput LXVI.	Chapter 66.
IN Hac Ramice non uidi aliquem qui ausus fuerit super curationem eius cum ferro.	In this case, I have not seen anyone who dared to attempt treatment with a knife.
Et primi quidem dixerunt, quod fit sicut narrauimus in Ramice quae est cum Vite.	And the first authors said that it happens as we have described for hemorrhoids accompanied by Veins.
Quod est, ut liges uasa post sectionem super ea cum facilitate inferius: deinde seca in medio, et cura postremo cum eo quod aperit ipsum, donec cadant uasa: et cura uulnus, secundum quod diximus, donec sanetur.	 namely, to tie the veins after cutting them below with ease; then cut through in the middle, and finally treat it with what opens it until the veins fall off; and dress the wound according to what we have said until it heals.
¶ De disruptione quae fit in inguinibus.	Chapter on Dislocations that occur in the Groins.
Caput LXVII.	Chapter 67.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, sicut diximus, et eminet locus, et non descendit ad testiculos aliquid ex intestinis: et si descendit, est illud parum, et redit in omnibus horis: uerum si prolongatur cum ea tempus, additur fissura in sifach, donec descendunt intestina in sifach.	When a rupture occurs in the groin, as we have described, and a swelling appears but nothing from the intestines descends to the testicles, or if something does descend but it is small and returns at all times: however, if this continues for some time, a tear will occur in the scrotum until the intestines descend into the scrotum.
Et accidit illud ex extensione sifach, quod est in inguinibus, sicut diximus.	And this happens due to stretching of the scrotum, which is located in the groin, as we have said.
Quod est, quia extenditur sifach: deinde mollificatur, et apostematur locus, et eminet.	namely, because the scrotum stretches, then it becomes soft and swell up, and a boil appears.
Et cura eius est cum cauterio, sicut praecessit eius narratio.	And its treatment is with a cautery, as its description has preceded.
Et quandoque curatur cum ferro, secundum hunc modum: et est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum inter manus tuas.	And sometimes it is treated with an iron tool, in this manner: namely, that the patient should lie on their back between your hands.
Deinde seca locum Rupturae apostematum et eminentem, sectione per latitudinem, secundum quantitatem trium digitorum.	Then cut the boil and swelling of the rupture with a transverse incision according to its size, which is about three finger-widths.
Deinde stringe alsifak et, quae sunt sub cute, donec quando detegitur sifach album, quod est sub cute quae sequitur ipsum.	Next, tie the scrotum and what is beneath the skin until you can see the white scrotal sac underneath the skin that follows it.
Tunc accipe radium, et pone ipsum super locum eminentem ex sifach, et preme ipsum ad profundum uentris.	Then take a probe and place it on the swelling of the scrotum and press it into the depth of the abdomen.
Deinde sue duo loca eminentia super extremitatem radii ex sifach, et annecte cum sutura unum eorum cum altero: deinde extrahe extremitatem radii.	Then, take two points that are prominent on the end of the probe from the swelling and connect them with a suture. Then remove the end of the probe.
Et non incidas alsifach omnino, neque tendas ouum, neque aliud, sicut feci te scire in curatione ramicis intestinalis.	And do not cut into the swelling at all, neither stretch nor do anything else as I have taught you in treating a prolapse of the intestines.
Deinde cura illud curatione uulnerum.	Then treat it with wound treatment.
Cum ergo incidis fila, mundifica illud, et restaura uulnus, donec consolidetur.	After cutting the threads, cleanse them and dress the wound until it heals.
Sisach enim contrahitur, et non additur eminentia Rupturae.	For the swelling will contract and there will be no prominence of rupture.
Et cauterium est melius in hoc loco: quoniam est propinquius ad salutem.	And cautery is better for this location since it is closer to health.
¶ De mollificatione cutis testiculorum.	Chapter on the softening of the skin of the testicles.
Caput LXVIII.	Chapter 68
Multotiens mollificatur cutis testiculorum in quibusdam hominibus, propter quod mollificantur carnes quae sunt inter ea, et foedatur aspectus eius.	The skin of the testicles is often softened in some men, causing the flesh between them to also become soft and making their appearance unsightly.
Ergo necesse est ei qui rogatur in curatione eius, ut faciat iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et incidat totam cutem quae mollificata est super cutem naturalem.	Therefore, it is necessary for the one performing the treatment to have the patient lie on their back and incise all of the softened skin down to the natural skin.
Deinde aggreget duo labia cum sutura: et si uis, sue in primis superfluitatem cutis mollificatae tribus suturis, aut quatuor, et firma suturam.	Then bring together both lips with a suture: and if you wish, remove the excess softened skin by three or four sutures, then secure it firmly with a suture.
Deinde incide inter sututuras.	Then cut between the sutures.
Deinde cura curatione reliquorum uulnerum, usquequo sanetur, et cadant fila.	Then treat it like other wounds until it heals and the stitches fall out.
¶ De Castratione.	Chapter on Castration.
Caput LXIX.	Chapter 69
Scias, quod Castratio in lege nostra excommunicata est: et propter illud liceret mihi, ut non rememorarer eius in libro meo isto: et non est necessaria rememoratio eius, nisi propter duos modos.	Know that castration is condemned by our law, and therefore I would not have mentioned it in this book of mine if it were not for two methods.
Quorum unus est, ut sit illud in scientia medici quando interrogatur de ea: et ut sciat curationem eius cui accidit.	One reason is so that the knowledge of castration may be possessed by a physician when asked about it, and so that he may know how to treat it if it occurs.
Et modus alter est, quod nos multotiens indigemus castratione quorundam animalium, propter iuuamenta nostra per illud, sicut arietum, hyrcorum, et gattorum, et similium ex animalibus.	And another reason is because we often need the castration of certain animals for our own uses, such as rams, roosters, and cats, among others.
Dico ergo, quod Castratio fit secundum duos modos.	I say therefore that castration is done in two ways.
Aut per attritionem.	Or by friction.
Aut per fissuram, et sectionem.	Or by incision and separation.
In illa autem quae fit per attritionem, uia operationis est: quod nos faciamus sedere animal in aqua calida, donec mollificentur testiculi eius, et leniantur, et pendeant: deinde attere eos manu tua, donec resoluantur et non appareant sub tactu.	In that which is done by friction, the method of operation is as follows: let the animal sit in warm water until its testicles become softened and relaxed, and hang down; then press them with your hand until they dissolve and are no longer visible to touch.
In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.	In castration by incision and division, it is necessary that you hold the animal and press the skin of its testicles with your left hand.
Deinde liga suspensorium, et seca super omne ouum sectione una, donec quando procedunt duo oua: tunc incide ea postquam excoriaueris utrumque, et non dimittas super ea ex sifaket aliquid praeter sifac subtile, quod est super uasa.	Then tie the suspensory ligament and make a single cut over all the testicles until two emerge; then cut them after you have stripped each one, leaving nothing but the thin sifak covering on top of the blood vessels.
Et iste modus castrationis est melior eo qui fit per attritonem: quoniam attritio fortasse relinquit aliquid ex testiculis, quare desiderat animal coitum.	And this method of castration is better than that which is done by friction, because friction may sometimes leave some of the testicles behind, causing the animal to desire copulation.
Deinde cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Then dress the wound until it heals.
¶ De cura Hermafroditae duorum modorum.	On the Care of Hermaphrodites in Two Methods.
Caput LXX.	Chapter 70
Hermafrodita ex uiris est secundum duos modos.	A hermaphrodite is of two kinds according to males.
Vnus eorum est, quia apparet in eo quod sequitur spacium, aut in cute testiculorum, in eo quod est inter duos testiculos, figura quasi uulua mulieris, in qua sunt pili: et quandoque currit urina ex eo quod est in cute testiculorum.	One of them is when there appears a space after the scrotum, or on the skin of the testicles between the two testicles, shaped like a woman's vulva with hairs, from which urine may sometimes flow.
In mulieribus autem est species una, et est uulua mulieris super pectinem sicut testiculi uiri parui omnino, eminentes ad exteriora: quorum unus est sicut priapus uiri, et duo sicut duo testiculi.	In women, however, there is one form, which is a woman's vulva above the pubis like small, protruding male testicles. One of these resembles the penis of a man, and two resemble the two testicles.
Et curatio trium specierum, duarum ex uiris, et speciei unius ex mulieribus, est: quia oportet ut incidas carnes additas, donec effugiat impressio earum.	And the treatment of these three forms - two from males and one from females - is as follows: it is necessary to cut away the excess flesh until the impression is removed.
Deinde cura eas curatione reliquorum uulnerum.	Then, treat them with the care used for other wounds.
In specie autem secunda uirorum, ex qua egreditur urina, quae est in cute testiculorum, non est operatio, neque est eius curatio omnino.	In the second species of males, from which urine flows, which is on the skin of the testes, there is no operation, nor any treatment at all.
¶ De incisione Tentiginis, et carnis eminentis in uuluis mulierum.	On the Incision of a Hemorrhoid and Excess Flesh Protruding from the Vagina of Women
Caput LXXI.	Chapter 71
Tentigo fortasse additur super rem naturalem, donec foedatur et turpis fit aspectus eius: et quandoque magnificatur in quibusdam mulieribus adeo, donec expanditur sicut in uiris, et peruenit usque ad coitum.	A hemorrhoid may sometimes be added to the natural condition until it disfigures and becomes unsightly; and in some women it may become so enlarged that it resembles that of men, even extending to sexual intercourse.
Oportet ergo ut teneas superfluitatem Tentiginis manu, aut cum uncino, et incidas: et non ultimes in incisione, praecipue in profundo radicis: ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Therefore, you should hold the excess hemorrhoid with your hand or hook and make an incision; but do not cut too deeply, especially at the root, so that bleeding does not occur.
Deinde cura ipsam curatione uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the care used for wounds until it heals.
Caro autem orta, est caro quae nascitur in orificio matricis, donec impleat ipsum: et fortasse egreditur ad exteriora secundum similitudinem caudae: et propter illud quidam primi nominant aegritudinem caudatam.	But the flesh that arises is the flesh that grows at the mouth of the womb until it fills it, and perhaps it may protrude externally in the manner of a tail. And on account of this some call this condition "tailed".
Oportet ergo ut incidamus eam sicut incidimus Tentiginem, et curemus eam, donec sanetur.	Therefore we should cut it like a hemorrhoid and treat it until it heals.
