Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	If there are hemorrhoids or abscesses wounding the anus, then use a very fine, gentle enema, such as those used for children.
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	This is the shape of the fine enema that should have a narrowed tip to fit snugly against the skin
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	On the treatment of head wounds without bone fracture
Caput LXXXIIII.	Chapter 84.
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	Now that I have spoken about the division of wound treatments appropriate for this book, I will now discuss their treatment by hand and with medicines according to what is lacking.
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	I say therefore that wounds are differentiated according to the cause of the wound, and according to the place where the wound occurs.
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	The causes of wounds are manifold, such as a blow from a stone; or a cut from a sword or knife; or a wound made by a spear, stake, arrow, or similar objects.
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	Wounds which occur according to the parts of the body are, for example, those that fall upon the head, neck, chest, belly, or limbs.
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I am relating the treatments of certain wounds so that I may set forth a reasoning and rule for the remainder of wounds.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	And I shall begin with simple head wounds, since the memory aid on compound fractures will come at the beginning of Chapter Three.
Dico ergo.	I say therefore
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	I say therefore that when a simple wound occurs on the head and there is no bone fracture, you should consider whether it was caused by a stone throw or similar object. If so, then only the skin has been broken and the wound is large, causing fear of a hot swelling (abscess). In this case, act quickly and perform a cephalic phlebotomy immediately; do not delay. Remove blood according to the patient's strength, provided there are no contraindications for phlebotomy, especially if little blood is flowing from the wound.
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the phlebotomy be performed on the opposite side of the wounded part.
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And the patient should avoid overeating, drinking wine, and consuming heavy foods.
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	But if some contraindication forbids bloodletting, then reduce by diet alone; avoid meats and wines.
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And if a hot swelling (abscess) occurs, apply to the wound a poultice made from wormwood steeped in rose oil alone or with wine that has been thickened.
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	But if you are free from the hot swelling (abscess), then apply to the fresh wound with its blood and not yet exposed to air, a powder which I will describe later. And if it has already been exposed to air, then apply some ointment until it heals.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	But if the wound is large or made by a cut with a knife and similar ones, and its lips do not join together through poultices, then close it up with stitches according to what I will describe regarding the suture of abdominal wounds.
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	But if the wound has been exposed by bone and hangs open with no tension except for a small suspension, then cut into it.
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Then treat the wound with medicines and replace the lost skin with tough flesh. Order the patient to be fed on foods that increase thickness, such as broths and cooked wheat, until they recover their strength; and similar foods.
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	But if you find putrefaction in the skin which does not adhere to the bone, then cut away all the putrid part and throw it out; then treat the wound.
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	But if in these wounds there is an artery or vein from which blood flows and cannot be tied off with medicines, then press upon the artery.
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	If you find it not cut, then cut it with a scalpel, or tie it with a ligature.
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if the necessity arises when what we have said does not suffice, then cauterize it until the bleeding stops.
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	But if these wounds are small and simple, their treatment is easy and light. Thus, sprinkle this powder upon them because it solidifies them before they become exposed to air.
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	Here follows the method of the powder for flesh-colored wounds
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Take one part of olibanum (frankincense), two parts of dragon's blood resin, and three parts of slaked lime. Grind all together thoroughly and sift it. Fill the wound with this powder and apply a good dressing until it adheres well and coagulates with the blood.
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then bind it from above with linen strips, and leave it alone without removing it until it dries completely so that it does not become loosened.
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	For the medicine should not be removed from him until he is healed.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And sometimes lime alone does the job, when you do not have frankincense and dragon's blood at hand. It also works in many great wounds when it is applied and bound, especially with fresh wounds that have not been exposed to air.
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	But if the wound has already been exposed to air for some time, especially during summer, then this powder should not be used. Instead, treat it with what was mentioned earlier, applying ointments made from digested ingredients or pastes made from barley flour mixed with water and honey until it discharges pus.
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then continue treating it with the remaining treatment until it heals.
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	But if a fracture of the bone occurs together with the wound, and it is small, then extract it using forceps. I will discuss the treatment of head fractures later on.
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	Chapter on Neck Wounds
Caput LXXXV.	Chapter 85
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	If a wound occurs on the neck, then there is no difference in treatment between it and a simple head wound.
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	But if the neck wound has severed a nerve or an artery: then if it is a nerve, there is no remedy except to treat it with something that causes strong coagulation, like cinnabar (cinnabar), lead, and other similar substances.
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	For they harm the nerves and contract them.
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	And do not apply anything cold to the wound at all, because the substance of nerves is cold and their continuity goes up to the brain which is the most noble organ. Therefore, what you use to treat it should be gentle medicines such as lime washed with sweet water and repeatedly infused with oil or rose oil, and also tutia (a perfume), when used for washing even with sweet water, along with other mineral stones and moist ointments.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	But if the wound is large, then apply stitches (sutura): otherwise, press its lips together with lint.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	But if the wound is deep or there is a cavity in its lower part where pus has already gathered, then pierce it in a more depressed spot.
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	If an artery has been cut in the wound and its blood flow is copious, then separate or cut it and tie it; or cauterize it if necessity demands it.
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	But if the spine of the throat or all of it has been injured, and the Adam's apple is saved, then join the edges of the skin with stitches over the bone of the throat and do not touch the throat itself, but leave it alone and let it return to its natural shape.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then bind it with a suitable bandage and leave it for a few days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointments that have an astringent and drying effect until it heals.
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	But if the wound has made an impression on the bone, then examine it. If there are bone fragments in it, remove all of them that you can; but what cannot be prepared, leave it until the wound putsrefies, separates and its discharge is relieved.
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	But if the wound is fresh, then sprinkle upon it the powder I have mentioned.
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	But if bone appears in the wound and a fistula forms, then treat it according to the method described in its chapter.
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	Chapter on wounds of the hands.
Caput LXXXVI.	Chapter 86.
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If there is a wound from a lance or knife and you see its depth, then consider (the severity).
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	If breathiness emerges from the wound when the patient gasps, know that the wound is mortal.
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	If the wound does not have depth and is fresh with its own blood, then do not apply powder to it at first, nor bind it tightly, so that blood does not become trapped within its depths and return to the heart, causing the death of the patient. Instead, apply an absorbent ointment to it and change it twice a day.
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	But if an absorbent ointment is not available to you, then place a piece of old linen over the mouth of the wound so that it may absorb any moisture exiting from it. And make sure the patient sleeps on their wound so that what collects within it may flow out.
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	If three days or more have passed since the wound was inflicted and no spasm has occurred for the patient, nor bad trembling of the heart, nor constriction in breathing, and you see that all other symptoms are favorable, then know that the wound is safe.
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Therefore treat it with linen bandages and other remedies until it heals.
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	But if its healing is delayed and it keeps opening up again, then know that a fistula has already formed.
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Therefore treat the fistula according to its own chapter.
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if the wound is from a sword or knife cut and is simple on the surface of the chest or back, then treat it with what preceded regarding stitching if it is large, or with powder if it is small.
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	But if the wound has already reached the bone and there are bone fragments from it, then examine the wound and promptly remove those fragments if they have separated.
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	However, if [the bone fragments] have not separated, then leave them alone until the wound has putrefied and softened, for their removal will thus be easier.
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	The treatment of other wounds occurring in other parts of the body is as we have described.
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	Chapter on Abdominal Wounds, and on the Protrusion of Intestines and Their Exit
Caput LXXXVII.	Chapter 87
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	Disruption that occurs to the abdomen is either great, medium, or small.
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	Therefore, in a large disruption sometimes one intestine or several intestines protrude.
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Hence, their replacement and suture is urgent and difficult.
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And a small disruption also presents difficulties in another way.
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	Therefore, it follows that their reduction is more difficult if you do not promptly replace them to their original position immediately, because they swell up, open, and become thicker, making replacement more difficult.
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	Therefore, a medium disruption is better because with it there is no difficulty in reducing the intestine, unlike in those two types [great and small].
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	Know that there are four ways to suture an abdomen.
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	Two types of sutures are common for both abdominal wounds and other wounds on the body, while two others are specific to other wounds.
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	However, these latter two types of sutures are particularly suitable for abdominal wounds, and I will now explain each one to you with its proper description.
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	I say therefore that when the wound is small and some intestine protrudes from it, making reduction difficult, then one of two methods should be used.
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Either because of the smallness of the disruption, as we have said, or because there is swelling in the intestine due to exposure to cold air.
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	Therefore, when such is the case, then you should warm the protruding intestine by immersing a sponge or moist cloth into warm water alone.
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or boil it in water with squill, cyperus, and spikenard, along with embrocation until the inflammation is resolved.
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	Sometimes wine with astringent properties is used; this is better than water alone for resolving inflammation.
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	When you see that the inflammation has been resolved, then moisten the protruding intestine with water in which has been boiled either celery or mallows.
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For this will alleviate its entrance when it is slightly inserted.
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	But if the return of the protruding intestine persists after this treatment, then make a small incision with an instrument used for cutting hemorrhoids.
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	The first treatment is better when it is prepared; the incision should not be forced unless necessary and due to a lack of proper instruments.
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	Let one part of it be twisted, sharp, and the other part not sharp; let its tip be somewhat blunt, not too fine like a needle; rather, it should resemble a chisel in appearance.
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	When the wound is widened and the protruding intestine enters it, then it is necessary that its reduction should be according to its natural shape in its proper place, if possible; for this is better.
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	But when the incision is large in the lower part of the abdomen, then it is necessary to make the patient lie on their back and elevate their legs higher than their head.
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	And if it is in the upper part of the abdomen, then place its head and chest higher than its lower parts.
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	Similarly, if the incision is on one of two parts of the abdomen, then always keep your intention and attention on ensuring that the part with the wound is higher than the other.
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	And so it should be done in both large wounds and medium-sized ones.
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	In small wounds, however, place the patient according to how you prepare them.
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then ensure that a pious assistant is present, who holds the wound open with one hand; then approximate the edges with your fingers.
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Next, wipe it clean and pass the needle to the one who follows for continuous suturing. This is the common method of single-layer closure.
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And take a needle or several needles according to the size of the wound.
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then insert the needle at a distance of about one fingerbreadth from the end of the wound (i.e., about an inch), and sew back and forth under the skin with two strands of thread until you have approximated both edges of the cut and have made four stitches.
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then tie the needle with doubled thread several times on both sides simultaneously until the two edges of the wound are approximated nicely.
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then insert the needle again at the same depth and sew with a straight stitch as you did with the first suture.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	Do not cease doing this until you have completed the closure of the entire wound.
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And use needles of medium size, neither too fine nor too coarse. Very fine needles cut the flesh quickly, while thick ones are difficult to insert into the skin. Therefore, it is best to use needles of medium thickness and fineness.
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	Do not insert the needle too close to the edges of the skin on both sides at once, so that you do not cut the flesh quickly and open the wound before it has healed properly. Also, do not make the stitches too long, as this may hinder the healing of the wound.
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Then cut off the ends of the threads to prevent them from bothering the patient during sleep. Put gauze pads made from clean cloth around the wound to hold the thread ends in place. Leave them there until you know that the wound has healed properly.
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	This method of suturing with needles is particularly suitable for small wounds.
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	For stitching them, one needle will suffice, or two, or approximately that number.
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	The second method of stitching is common, where you join together the four ends: two of skin and two of the thread. Take one needle with an evenly wound thread that is neither too fine nor too coarse.
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then when you have pierced the four ends with your needle, bring it back on the same side from which you started, so that the thread falls evenly across the top of the wound. The stitch should be like a seam in cloth. Place between every stitch an amount of thread equal to the thickness of a finger joint.
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	This method of stitching is known by men.
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	And with this stitching method I myself sutured a wound that had occurred on the abdomen of a man who was wounded with a knife. The disruption of the wound was about one palm's length and about two palms' worth of intestine had protruded from the middle intestine, with a tear in the center of the abdomen.
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	Therefore I reduced it back into place after his intestines had been outside the wound for 24 hours.
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	Thus, the wound healed in about fifteen days. I took care of it and he recovered well, living many years thereafter with no further issues.
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	And the physicians had judged that it would not heal.
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	It was by a miracle that I did not treat this wound with an ointment.
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	Because there were no salves or medicines available in the place where I was located.
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	Therefore, I applied an old piece of linen twice a day to the wound and washed it regularly with honey water until it healed.
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	I will now describe two types of stitching according to the spoken tradition.
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	Begin with a sharp suture by inserting the needle from the outer to the inner part.
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	When the needle has pierced the skin and is traveling through the flesh according to the length and width of the entire body, release the thread on the side where you inserted the needle, and make it pierce from the inner part to the outer part at the other end.
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	After you have made it pierce, then make it pierce back from the outer part to the inner part at the same end. Release the thread on this side and make the needle pierce into the other end from the inner part to the outer part, and continue piercing until it has pierced through everything.
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	Then begin again from this same side, and with the end that is on the other side, pull out the needle from the skin it has pierced.
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then bring it back into that skin with the end on the other side and make it pierce again from its part, pulling it out from the skin. Do this repeatedly until all is stitched together according to this example.
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	The final result of this stitching is similar to the way tanners sew hides together, so that one end of the thread goes in on one side of the skin and comes out on the other side, completing the stitch.
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	Here is the second type of proper stitching, which Galen spoke about.
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	This type of stitching is described as being done in a similar manner to how some physicians join parts together by bringing them close together and matching them naturally. The end of the thread is applied to one end of the part, while the other end is applied to its opposite end.
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And this is what I have told you.
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	You must insert the needle into the end of mirah that is nearest to you from the outer part and make it pass through to the inner side alone. Then release both ends of sifac.
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then turn the needle around and insert it from the outer part to the inner side on both ends of sifac, that is, on either side.
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then turn both over and make them penetrate from the inner to the outer side on both other ends of mirah that are on the opposite side.
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this method of stitching is a better stitch than the common easy one, and it is a stitch which leaves a memory.
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This is also the speech of Galen.
Et dixerunt quidam.	And some said,
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	 Sutures of the belly should be corrected using two needles.
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	This is so that you insert one thread into both of them and begin with the insertion of the needle from what is nearest to you, making it pass through to the other side according to the stitching of those who join skins evenly.
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	And know that when a rupture is in the middle of the belly, its stitching is more difficult than that of other parts of the belly.
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	But the judgment of treating wounds is the same as for other wounds.
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	That is to say, when you encounter a fresh wound with its own blood before the air alters it and you reduce the intestines and tie it up properly, then apply powder of cinnabar.
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	But if the air has already altered the wound, then apply some ointments that you have with you until they cause it to suppurate and release the threads, and sifac and mirah are consolidated.
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it as other wounds are treated, until it heals.
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	If you do not have the medicines present, then immediately apply a bandage at the point where it begins to discharge pus, and change it twice a day as I have taught you, until it heals.
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For you do not need other medications in many cases when wounds are simple.
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	But if you fear that the wound may communicate with the principal members in injury, then it is necessary to immerse soft wool in oil of moderate heat or rose oil and apply it around the areas between the thighs and under the armpits.
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	If the patient feels pain, pricking, or putrefaction in their intestines (for this often happens), then administer a clyster with black, tepid, astringent wine, especially if the putrefaction has reached the intestine and caused a deep evacuation.
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And know that what comes from the large intestine is easier to heal, but what comes from the small intestine is harder to heal.
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	However, the intestine called the ileum does not receive healing from a wound that occurs in it at all: and this is because of its multitude of veins, their size, the subtlety of its body, and its proximity to the nature of the nerves.
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	But if what comes out from the wound is blood clots and you find them fresh, then reduce them according to your method of reducing intestines evenly.
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	But if some time has passed and it has become green or black, then you must tie it with a thread above the place that has been darkened by it to prevent bleeding.
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	For in bruises there are veins and arteries.
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then cut what is beyond that ligament and place two ends of the thread hanging down from the lower part of the wound outside it: so that its tension may be relieved upon you, and its extraction at the time of the bruise, and the discharge of pus from the wound.
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	Remembering a wound that occurs in the intestines.
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When there is a rupture in the intestines and it is small, then it is possible for it to be restored in some people; therefore, because I have seen one who was wounded in his belly with a lance blow, and the wound was on the right side of the stomach, and it was old: and a fistula formed, and there was emission from it, and windiness.
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	I therefore applied treatment until I had no confidence in the healing of it; nor did I cease to treat it finely until it was healed and the place consolidated.
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	After I saw that the place was already consolidated, I feared for the patient that some bad event might occur to him in his belly; and no such thing happened to him.
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	And he remained in better conditions than before, eating and drinking, and having intercourse, and entered the baths, and exercised himself in his usual activities.
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And now some experts say that when a wound occurs in the intestines and it is small, then it should be tied in this manner.
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	It is necessary to take large-headed ants.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then gather together the two lips of the wound and place one of those ants which have an open mouth upon the two lips of the wound.
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	When it seizes them and closes its mouth, cut off its head, for it adheres and does not let go.
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then place another ant near the first one, and do not cease doing this with ants in succession according to the total quantity of the wound.
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then dress it and heal its wound.
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	For those heads remain attached in the intestines until the intestines are eaten and healed, so that no harm befalls the patient.
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And now it is possible to suture the intestine even with a fine thread: what has been removed from the animal's intestine should be attached to it when it is inserted into the wound.
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And you should take the end of this thread from the intestine and burn it well.
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then tie a fine linen thread onto its end.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then insert that thread into the wound and bring the intestine with it.
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then reduce it into the incision.
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And this method of suturing with ants and intestines is only a matter of trust and hope.
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	Know that if the wound is large or wide, especially if it affects one of the delicate intestines, then there is no hope and no cure for it.
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	On the treatment of fistulas.
Caput LXXXVIII.	Chapter 78
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	You should know that every wound or abscess which becomes old and hardened, turns into an ulcer, does not heal, constantly emits pus but is not cut off: then it is universally called a fistula in whichever limb it may be found, and we call it zuchemen.
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And a fistula is indeed in truth a hard, white knot like a sieve, without pain and concave like the feather of a bird. And because of this some call it 'risati', that is, 'feather'.
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And at certain times it may be moist and emit pus.
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And perhaps the moisture splits open at certain times.
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	And sometimes this moisture is abundant and sometimes scarce; it may be thick or thin.
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And I have already stated in the division where wounds are concerned, that every wound which does not heal and upon which flesh does not grow, is so only because of one of nine causes.
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	These are nine causes: either because of the scarcity of blood in the body; or because of the quality of the blood; or because there is hard flesh between the wound and its lips preventing flesh from growing; or because it contains much dirtiness and foulness; or because the wound itself is putrid, and the material sent to it is of bad quality; or because the treatment is unsuitable for its healing; or because a falling corruption in the region is a kind of pestilence, such as occurs in Caesaraugusta where digestion of illnesses is difficult and healing of apostemes is delayed by nature; or because there is one bone too many or not enough bones.
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	And I have already shown all these causes and their signs, and treatments with medicines for each one in the division; and here it is necessary that I inform you about the treatment of fistulas and ulcers which occur through an operation by hand.
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	Know therefore that fistulas occur in all members of the body.
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	For there are fistulas which reach the large veins and arteries, nerves, or bones; or the intestines, bladder, or some of the ribs; or some of the vertebrae in the back, or some of the joints composed by articulation, such as hands and feet. And there are those which approach the main member and similar ones.
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	Therefore, among these fistulas, those that follow this pattern are difficult to heal and do not receive treatment. They are troublesome and accompanied by ignorance.
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	But if there is one among these fistulas whose depth does not reach those places I mentioned and you hope for its healing and trust in its treatment, then take a probe made of brass or iron, if the fistula extends straight ahead, and explore it with that.
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	If the fistula is twisted, then investigate it with a probe made of fine lead.
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	Because lead, due to the gentleness of its substance, alleviates and curves around the twist.
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	But if a fistula has many openings, it is not possible for you to indicate it with a probe.
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	Therefore, seal off one of its openings from the others.
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For the water with which you perform the enema will flow towards the other openings and run out through them.
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then examine carefully to find out whether it is possible for you: so that you may know whether there is a bone or nerve there, and if the fistula is deeply concave, either nearby or far away; or if it is one fistula with many openings. And stand on all of this with your utmost strength, through questioning the patient and finding pain at compression with your hand over the area, and similar signs and causes that occur in an apostema.
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	When you have stood firm on all of these with true steadfastness, then proceed to treat it with confidence. And consider at that time whether the fistula is close by and apparent, or in a safe place far from the junction, or from nerve, artery, vein, or one of those places I mentioned to you. Then cut open the fistula according to what has been previously stated in my description, and remove whatever is inside it through filtration, including rotting flesh that grows at its opening from flesh, gland, or similar things. And treat it until it heals.
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	But if the fistula is deeply buried and extends straight ahead, then it is necessary for you to cut into it as deeply as possible.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then cleanse it of all its corrupted flesh.
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then insert medicated linen wrapped around sharp needles into the cavity of the fistula you have grasped with forceps; do this repeatedly until the acrid medicine has eaten away all that remains inside the cavity.
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then dress it with salves which promote healing, until it is healed.
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	But if it does not heal by this method, then cauterize it as we have described.
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	If the cause of the fistula is bone and you are certain of this, then expose it and cut into it as I have told you; but if anything prevents you from doing so, such as a vein, nerve, or main limb, as we have said.
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If you expose bone and find that there is decay or blackness in it, then scrape it away until all the decay is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then dress it with what promotes healing until it heals.
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	But if it does not heal and continues to discharge pus as before, then know that you have not completely removed all the decay.
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Therefore expose it again and investigate its cause thoroughly, and cleanse it with all your strength.
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then dress it.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	But if it does not heal, then know that the decay is deeply buried within the body and you have not reached it.
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	Therefore there is no remedy for it but to leave it to nature.
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	But if a small bone is affected and you are able, grasp it with fine forceps that fit its size.
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	If there are many bones, then carefully grasp them all with your strength and leave none behind.
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	But if anything resists you due to moisture and there is no fear of cutting or error involved, then cut through the moistures and flesh (if any are present) and free the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	But if you lack the preparation to remove bones from your own body, then place something that will rot on the wound and leave it until what is surrounding those bones in flesh and moisture rots.
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And guard the wound so that it does not heal.
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And bind the incision that you made during your operation.
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	Rather, if you wish, place on it [the wound] cotton soaked in ground sulfur with oil; or cotton soaked in Egyptian ointment, or any of the gold-colored ointments.
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when those moistures putrefy and separate from them [the bones], the removal of these becomes easier, as does their attraction.
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	But if there is one large bone, such as the leg bone or the hip bone and similar ones, and a large part of it has decayed, then shave it down to the last layer until that blackness and decay are removed.
Deinde restaura uulnus.	Then close the wound.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	But if what is decayed in it is a large part and the decay has already reached the bone marrow, then it is necessary to close it [the wound] and cut all the way to the point where the decay has reached; then treat it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I tell you this example of a man who had an injury to his leg so that you may use it as a model and aid for your own operations.
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	There was once a young man of about thirty years old who had pain in his leg due to an internal cause that moved upon it until matter reached the leg and formed a large abscess; there was no external cause for this.
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	So much time passed with the error of doctors until the abscess burst open and much matter gathered around it.
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And its treatment was delayed until the leg became fistulous and many openings appeared in it which all discharged pus and bodily fluids.
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	Therefore many doctors treated it for about two years but there was no skilled hand in the art until I was called and saw his leg, and the materials that flowed from those openings with great abundance: indeed the whole man's body was already emaciated, and his complexion was yellowish.
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	I inserted a probe into one of those holes, and it reached to the bone.
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all the openings, and found that they communicated with each other from every part of the leg.
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	So I prepared and opened above one of those holes until I reached the bone itself, which I found corrupted; it was already rotted, blackened, putrefied, and perforated, having penetrated to the marrow.
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	I therefore cut away what I had discovered of the corrupted bone.
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And ordered that nothing be left on the bone except that corruption which I cut off and sawed away.
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	I had already removed it.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I applied dressings with strengthening medicines for a long period of time.
Et non est consolidatum.	And it did not heal.
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I probed and searched again above the first discovery, and found continuous corruption with the bone; I sawed away what appeared to me of that corruption also.
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Then I attempted its restoration.
Et non est restauratum.	And it was not restored.
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	Therefore I searched again upon it and did not cease cutting the bone bit by bit and attempting its restoration until I cut about a palm's breadth of it out and extracted it along with its marrow.
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with medicines, and it was quickly consolidated and healed; nor would this repetition of operation and section have been necessary if not for the disposition of the patient's weakness, his lack of tolerance, and my fear for him regarding death, since he suffered continuous syncope from the profuse evacuation.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	Therefore he was healed with a complete recovery: and hard flesh grew in place of the bone, and his bodily condition improved, and his strength returned; and he resumed his usual activities without any harm from walking.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	But if the bone protruding from the body is already broken: then you should take hold of it in this manner: and there is to take a bandage, and wrap it tightly around the end of the projecting bone: and order someone to stretch it upward: and place another bandage made of coarse wool over the first bandage.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind it over the flesh that is below the bone; and stretch its end so as to draw the flesh downwards; and you uncover the flesh at the place where you wish to compress it, so that the compress does not injure the flesh.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place wood or a board under the bone below appropriately: for when you do this, it will prevent cutting into the rotted flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it is necessary that the compression be maintained for a short time over the rotted place so that there may not be a hollow in the bone; nor should it appear evident in its appearance and compel another compression.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	But if the bone is rotted and not protruding, rather being continuous with itself; and the corruption is in its midst or on one of its parts: then uncover all the flesh from all sides.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place wood below.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Next cut it from the first side where there is corruption until the compression continues to the other side; and let the compression be along the length of the corruption for a short distance as we have said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If there is corruption at a joint, cut the corrupted joint itself, and saw the bone where it continues on the other side.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	But if corruption is between two joints, there is no remedy for it except scraping.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	However, if the corruption is in the wrist of the hand or foot, then this case is very difficult.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	But it is necessary to investigate how the corruption appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And scrape it and cleanse it according to any possible arrangement that you can make with whatever tool suits you: as long as the vein or nerve does not cause you opposition.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	Know that saws and chisels for cutting these bones are many, according to the position of the bones, their preparation, thickness, thinness, size, fineness, hardness, and rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore it is necessary that you prepare an appropriate tool for each type of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations indicate to you the kind of tool that you need when you are engaged in study for a long time.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And the knowledge of methods in this art is witness to the methods of illnesses. Then you will find by yourself what is suitable for each disease from the tools available.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am confirming to you at the end of this chapter the number of instruments which you should have as examples on which to practice and by which to test others.
Forma Serrae.	Shape of Saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	Shape of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Shape of yet another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Shape of a fourth saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This shape of the saw is depicted neatly.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its upper curve be sharp with iron, and its handle be made of boxwood, and let it be pyramided neatly.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	Shape of Rasp for Joints.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	The head of this rasp should be in the shape of a star-nail head, and its points should resemble those of an awl.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it is not fitting unless the heads of joints are rubbed with it when they become corrupted or if the bone is wide and large.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	Shape of the Larger Rasp.
Forma medii Rasorii.	Form of the Medium Rasp.
Forma Rasorii lati.	Shape of the Broad Rasp.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	Shape of the Rasp with Concavity.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	Shape of Another Fine Rasp.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	Form of Another Rasp with a Curved Tip.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	Form of the Small, Fine, and Flexible Rasp.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	Shape of the Rasp Used for Cutting Bones.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	And also the Shape of the Large Rasp.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This resembles a Rod and its end is like a Saw; it is used in many places due to the reason of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	Shape of the Rasp fitting for use on that which has been pierced by bone.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its tip is triangular, with sharp points.
Fit ex Indi.	It is made from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly, it is necessary that all which we have spoken of be made from Raspers, Cutters, and Saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	§ On the Incision of Extremities and Sawing of Bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	Extremities putrefy due to external or internal causes.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	Therefore, when you have treated that corruption with medicines, and the treatment does not help, and you see the corruption spreading to the limb without any sign of improvement, then it is necessary to cut off that limb up to where the corruption reaches, so that the patient may be saved from death or from a greater loss of the limb.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign that this has occurred is when the limb becomes blackened until it seems burned; if fire has not burned it, then it rots after becoming blackened; and the corruption should be cut out until it reaches that which follows the limb, and if it spreads throughout the body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, make the incision promptly, and likewise if the cause of the corruption is from the bite of some venomous creature such as a marine scorpion, viper, adder, or similar ones.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If corruption or a bite is on the tip of a finger, then cut into the finger and do not allow space for the corruption to spread up to the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it occurs on the hand, then cut into it from its root towards the wrist, and do not allow space for corruption until it reaches the elbow.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	If it invades further, then cut into the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if corruption passes through and you see that it is encircling the elbow, then death of the patient is imminent.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And apart from that, everything else for treatment amounts to nothing but powerlessness.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly do the same for the foot when corruption invades a toe; cut into it at one of its joints. But if it reaches the heel, then amputate the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it ascends to the knee, then cut into the thigh at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	However, if corruption has already reached above the knee, there is no remedy for it except to abandon (the limb) and leave the patient to their fate.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	The method of cutting into a limb or binding it is to tie off the ligament below where you wish to cut and tie off another ligament above the location.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And let one assistant hold one ligament downward, while another assistant holds another ligament upward.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh that is between the two ligaments using a broad spatula until all the flesh is exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then cut or bind it.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	It is necessary to place linen cloth on all sides and not let the bandage touch the healthy area, so that additional injury or a hot abscess does not occur.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	But if bleeding occurs internally while you are working, then cauterize the location quickly or apply some powders that stop bleeding on it.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your treatment until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable bandage and care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you that what happened to this man's foot is exactly as I have described to you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	This is because blackness occurred on his foot with burning akin to fireburn: and that corruption initially happened in his toe, until it began to spread throughout the entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	So the man amputated himself after seeing the severity of the corruption occurring in his limb, which he discovered through pain and burning sensation. He cut it at the joint and was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, the same corruption occurred on his right index finger.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	So he came to me, and I tried to recover that swelling with the medications I applied on his hand after cleansing his body. But the swelling did not recede and began to spread to another finger until corruption reached his entire hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	So he called for me to cut off his hand. But I refused that because I hoped the swelling would recede from my treatments. And I also feared death might occur during the amputation of his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Because the man's strength was greater than his illness.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	After he despaired of me, he returned to his own land. And I heard that he had hastened and cut off his entire hand himself, and was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I relate this story not for any other reason than to provide help regarding cases of this kind of illness and to indicate a method according to which one should act.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the treatment of sinuses and the quality of enemas with medications.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.
