Et modus alter est, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et suspende manum eius a collo ipsius cum ligamento.	And another method is for the patient to lie on their back and hang their hand from their neck with a bandage.
Deinde praecipe duobus ministris, ut teneat unus eorum illud quod est supra fracturam cum manibus suis: et ut alter teneat inferius eius, et extendat unusquisque eorum ad partem suam.	Then instruct two assistants to hold what is above the fracture with their hands and for each of them to extend it towards his own part.
Et si uis, ut sit extensio fortior, tunc stringe sub fractura cum ligamento, et supra ipsam cum ligamento alio: et extendat ea unusquisque duorum ministrorum ad duas partes suas.	And if you wish for a stronger extension, then bind beneath the fracture with one bandage and above it with another bandage; and let each of the two assistants extend them towards their own parts.
Si ergo fractura est propinqua extremitati humeri, tunc oportet, ut ponatur unum ligamentum sub titillico, et alterum sub fractura uersus cubitum.	If the fracture is near the end of the arm, then it is necessary to place one bandage under the elbow and another under the fracture towards the elbow.
Et similiter si fractura est propinqua cubito: tunc oportet, ut ponatur ligamentum super illum locum, et super cubitum ipsum.	And similarly, if the fracture is near the elbow, then it is necessary to place a bandage over that location and over the elbow itself.
Deinde aequa fracturam cum facilitate absque labore, donec quando aequatur fractura secundum quod oportet, et applicatur applicatione bona: tunc stringe eam, si non accidit apostema calidum.	Then align the fracture with ease without exertion until it equals what is necessary, and apply it properly. Then bind it if there is no hot swelling.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam usque ad diem septimum.	But if a hot swelling occurs, then leave the bandage loose for seven days.
Et pone super ipsum lanam succidam imbibitam in aceto et oleo rosato, donec quando quiescit apostema: tunc stringe eam: et modus stringendi eam est, ut ponas emplastrum super fracturam.	And place on it a piece of wool soaked in vinegar and rose oil until the swelling subsides. Then bind it again; and the method of binding is to put the plaster over the fracture.
Deinde pone inuolutionem ex panno nouo super emplastrum.	Then place a fresh cloth wrapping over the plaster.
Deinde aggreget brachium super adiutorium ipsum, et ponat manum suam apertam super humerum suum.	Then bring the arm close to the splint, and let them place their hand open on their shoulder.
Et pone pannum, et stringe super adiutorium brachium, ut brachium stet loco astellarum: si non prohibet te ab illo aliquid, neque alteretur super te aliquid ex osse fracto.	And place a cloth and bind over the splint arm so that it stays in place without hindering anything or being disturbed by any part of the broken bone.
Quod si times, quod alteretur super te ex osse fracto aliquid, tunc utere astellis: et est, ut ponas super fracturam ipsam astellam quae sit latior et fortior reliquis astellis.	But if you fear that something might be disturbed from the broken bone, then use splints. And it is necessary to place over the fracture itself a splint which is wider and stronger than the others.
Et ponas inter omnem astellam latitudinem digiti: et sit longitudo astellarum secundum fracturam cum additione trium digitorum ab omni parte.	And let the width between each splint be the thickness of a finger, and let the length of the splints be equal to the fracture with an additional three fingers on either side.
Deinde stringe super astellas strictura quam dixi in principio capituli.	Then bind over the splints with the bandage that I mentioned at the beginning of this chapter.
Et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae strictior.	And it is necessary for your binding to be tighter over the location of the fracture.
Et quanto plus elongatur fractura, sit strictura minor.	And the more the fracture extends, the looser the binding should be.
Si ergo uides situm astellarum et stricturam, sicut diximus, in hora qua restauras membrum statim, tunc fac: et si times apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam et astellas usque ad diem septimum, sicut diximus.	If you see that the splints and bandage are set properly, as we have said, when you put the limb back in place, then do so. And if you fear hot swelling, then leave the bandage and splints loose for seven days, as we have said.
Deinde considera ligamentum in omnibus tribus diebus, ut non accidat in loco pruritus, aut inflatio, aut prohibeatur cibus peruenire ad membrum, propter dispositionem superfluitatis stricturae.	Then observe the ligature on all three days so that itching or swelling does not occur, nor is food prevented from reaching the limb due to tension from excessive tightness of the bandage.
Rectifica ergo illud totum, secundum quod diximus.	Therefore correct that entirely according to what we have said.
Si uero es super fiduciam, ut non accidat ex illo aliquid: tunc non soluas ligamentum, nisi post tres dies, aut plus.	But if you are confident that nothing bad will result from it, then do not loosen the ligature until after three days or more.
Et sit dormitio infirmi super dorsum suum, et manus eius super stomachum suum: et pone sub adiutorio culcitram plenam lana aequaliter.	And let the patient lie on their back with their hands over their stomach, and place under their buttocks a bolster filled evenly with wool for support.
Et considera in omni hora noctis, aut diei, ut non soluatur figura membri fracta, aut mollificetur ligamentum.	And observe at every hour of the night or day that the figure of the broken limb does not loosen nor the ligature become slackened.
Rectifica ergo illud totum uirtute tua.	Therefore correct it all with your own strength.
Et pone cibum infirmi secundum ordinem quem praemisimus, ita ut sit cibus subtilis in primis, donec incipiat os stringi: tunc oportet, ut ingrosses cibum eius.	And give food to the patient according to the order that we have previously set forth, so that at first the food is thin until the bone starts to grow together, then it is necessary to increase their food.
De consuetudine enim adiutorii et cruris est, ut stringatur in quadraginta diebus: tunc ergo oportet, ut soluatur, et administretur balneum, et medicetur cum unguentis quae rectificant illud.	For the custom is for splints and bandages to remain on for forty days. Therefore at that time they should be removed, and a warm bath should be given, and it should be treated with ointments that straighten it.
Quod si fractura fuerit foeda, attrita: tunc non soluas ab ea ligamentum et astellas usque ad quinquaginta dies, et usque ad duos menses.	But if the fracture is ugly and crushed, then do not remove the bandage and splints from it until fifty days have passed or two months.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Brachii.	Chapter on the Reduction of a Broken Arm
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13
Brachium est compositum ex duobus ossibus, quae nominantur duo focilia.	The arm is composed of two bones called the two hollows (humerus and radius).
Quorum unum est paruum: et est illud quod sequitur pollicem.	One of which is small, namely the one that follows the thumb.
Et alterum est magnum, et est illud quod est positum sub paruo ab inferiori parte.	And the other one is large, and it is the one placed beneath the small one from below.
Fortasse ergo frangitur focile maius solum, aut paruum: et fortasse franguntur simul.	Therefore sometimes only the large hollow breaks, or sometimes only the small one does, and sometimes they both break at once.
Quando ergo frangitur focile paruum superius, tunc restauratio eius est facilis, et sanatio eius est facilior.	When therefore the small upper hollow breaks, then its restoration is easy, and its healing is easier.
Et quando frangitur focile inferius, est fractura eius mala, et sanatio eius difficilis.	And when the lower hollow breaks, its fracture is bad, and its healing difficult.
Et deterior ea est, quando franguntur duo ossa simul.	And it is worse when both bones break at once.
Si ergo os quod frangitur est focile parum superius, tunc conuenit medico apud restaurationem eius, ut ponat extensionem paruam cum facilitate, donec aequet ipsum.	If therefore the bone that breaks is the small one above, then it befits the physician, in its restoration, to place a slight extension gently until it becomes even.
Si uero focile magnum est illud quod fractum est: tunc oportet, ut ponat stricturam fortiorem ualde.	But if the bone that is broken is the large one, then it is necessary for him to apply strong traction very forcibly.
Et oportet, ut ponat figuram manus apud restaurationem eius, et ipsius extensionem extensam super puluinar.	And he must put his hand in the shape of a fist upon its restoration, and stretch out its extension over the pillow.
Et sit pollex manus ad superiora altior omnibus digitis: et sit articularis inferior omnibus digitis, uel reliquis: et infirmus sedens quadratus super seipsum, et sit puluinar coram eo, uel in directo eius, in altitudine, ut non incurrat infirmus laborem.	And let the thumb of the hand be higher than all the fingers towards the top, and let the lower joint be below all the fingers or the rest; and let the patient sit square upon himself, and let there be a pillow before him, or directly in front of him at the proper height, so that the patient does not suffer discomfort.
Deinde extendat minister Brachium ab inferiori parte, aut manu sua, aut cum ligamento.	Then let the assistant stretch out the arm from below with his hand or with a bandage.
Et minister alius extendat desuper similiter.	And another assistant should likewise stretch it out from above.
Deinde aequet medicus os, donec reducat ipsum secundum meliorem figuram quam potest.	Then let the physician set the bone until he brings it back into the best position possible.
Quod si in fractura ossis sunt satagiae, tunc conare reducere omne frustum in loco suo uirtute tua.	But if there are fragments in the fracture of the bone, then strive with all your strength to replace each fragment in its proper place.
Si uero apparet in eo sathaiatum separatum, et pungit cutem, et non est tibi spes in restauratione eius: tunc finde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum secundum modum quem diximus in eis quae praemissa sunt.	But if there appears a separated fragment that pierces the skin and there is no hope of restoring it, then cut over it and remove it according to the manner which we have described earlier.
Si autem fractura est cum uulnere, ego iam feci ad illud capitulum singulare, ergo accipe curationem illius inde.	But if the fracture is with a wound, I have already dealt with that in its own chapter, so take the treatment of it from there.
Quod si accidat in principio tuae restaurationis apostema calidum, tunc line pannum cum caeroto facto ex oleo rosato, et caera alba, et sit medium inter spissitudinem et subtilitatem: et stringe pannum super ipsum strictura subtili, donec quando sedatur apostema: tunc remoue caerotum, et pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum albumine oui.	But if a hot swelling occurs at the beginning of your restoration, then take a cloth and make a plaster with wax and rose oil, medium in thickness between thick and thin; and apply it over it with a thin bandage until when the swelling subsides. Then remove the plaster, and place an emplaster made from flour dust with egg white.
Deinde pone astellas, et sit astella quae ponitur super fracturam ipsam latior parumper, et fortior.	Then apply splints, and let the splint placed over the actual fracture be somewhat broader and stronger.
Et scias, quod numerus astellarum Brachii est sex in pluribus dispositionibus: siue sit fractura in focili uno, aut in duobus focilibus simul.	Know that the number of splints for the arm is six in most cases: whether there is a fracture in one joint or two joints at once.
Deinde pone stricturam tuam super locum fracturae fortiorem et uehementiorem, et aliquanto plus cum strictura ad superiora fracturae, aut ad inferiora eius: aut pone stricturam molliorem strictura eius parumper, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius in principio capituli.	Then place your bandage over the site of the fracture more strongly and more tightly, and a little bit higher with the bandage above the fracture or below it: or place a softer bandage than its usual tension for a short time, according to what was mentioned at the beginning of this chapter.
Et sint panni qui inuoluuntur super fracturam, panni lenes, humidi: et non sint duri, asperi.	And let the cloths that are wrapped around the fracture be soft, wet cloths: and not hard or rough.
Et sit filum quo stringitur ex lino proprie, medium inter subtile et grossum, sicut narrauimus.	And the thread with which it is tied should be made of linen properly, medium in thickness between thin and thick, as we have described.
Et considera membrum et ligamentum post dies.	And examine the limb and its ligaments after some days.
Quod si accidat aliquid cuius rectificatio sit necessaria, sicut pruritus qui accidit membro: tunc oportet, ut embroces membrum cum aqua calefacta, donec quiescat ille pruritus, et dimittas membrum non constrictum, donec quiescat, deinde itera stricturam.	But if something occurs that requires correction, such as itching in the limb: then you must embrocate the limb with warm water until the itching ceases, and leave the limb unrestrained until it calms down, then repeat the bandaging.
Quod si strictura iam mollificata est, et os iam remotum, et similia illis: tunc rectifica illud totum uirtute tua, et considera iterum.	But if the bandage has already softened and the bone is now moved away, and similar things have occurred: then correct it all with your skill and examine it again.
Nam si nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad membrum, propter superfluitatem stricturae, tunc oportet, ut mollifices ipsum parumper, et dimittas ipsum aliquot diebus, donec currat ad ipsum nutrimentum, deinde stringe ipsum.	For if nourishment is prevented from reaching the limb due to excess tightness of the bandage, then you must soften it for a short time and leave it for several days until nourishment flows to it again, then tie it.
Si autem non accidit infirmo aliquid eorum quae diximus, tunc non oportet, ut soluatur, nisi post uiginti dies, aut circiter hos.	But if nothing of what we have said happens to the patient, then you should not remove it unless after twenty days or thereabouts.
Deinde suspendatur manus infirmi ad collum eius.	Then hang the patient's hand over their neck.
Et sit collum eius aequale, et custodiatur uirtute sua a motibus agitatiuis.	And let their neck be level, and it shall be kept firm with its own strength against violent movements.
Et fac eum dormire super dorsum suum.	Make him lie on his back.
Et scias, quod haec fractura in triginta diebus, aut in triginta duobus diebus restauratur: et fortasse restauratur in uigintiocto diebus.	Know that this fracture is restored in thirty days or at most forty-two days; sometimes it may be restored in eighty-eight days.
Totum illud est secundum dispositiones complexionum, et dispositiones uirtutis.	All of this depends on the dispositions of temperaments and the dispositions of strength.
¶ De restauratione fracturarum Manus.	Here begins the chapter On the Reduction of Fractures of the Hand
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIV
Scias, quod pectini Manus, et nodis digitorum raro accidit fractura.	Know that fractures of the comb of the hand and joints of the fingers rarely occur.
Et non accidit ei, nisi attritio multotiens.	And it does not happen to him except with frequent attrition.
Quando ergo accidit plantae fractura, aut attritio: tunc oportet, ut sedeat infirmus quadratus: et coram eo sit sedes secundum aequalitatem.	When therefore a fracture of the palm or attrition occurs, then the patient should sit squarely and before him there should be a seat of equal height.
Deinde pone Manum eius super eam extensam.	Then place his hand upon it, extended.
Deinde extendat minister ossa fracta, et aequet ea medicus, donec quando coniunguntur coniunctione bona.	Then let the assistant extend the broken bone, and the physician shall align them until they join together with good union.
Tunc oportet, ut ponat emplastrum et stuppam, si non accidat apostema calidum.	Then it is necessary to apply a plaster and wadding if there is no hot abscess.
Deinde pone astellam desuper secundum quantitatem loci: et tu iam inuoluisti eam in panno lini.	Then place a splint over the top according to the size of the place, and you have now wrapped it with linen cloth.
Si autem fractura est ad inferiora circiter uentrem plantae, tunc fac simile spherae ex panno: et praecipe infirmo, ut coartet super eam cum planta sua fracta: deinde stringatur cum panno longo.	But if the fracture is towards the lower part near the palm of the hand, then make a spherical shape from cloth and order the patient to wrap it around with their fractured palm; then bind it with a long piece of cloth.
Et sit astella ex corio, in quo sit lenitas, ut applicetur corium cum corpore plantae: et stringe eam, secundum quod oportet.	And let the splint be of leather, soft so that it may be applied to the body of the palm; and bind it as necessary.
Si autem fractura est ad exteriora, tunc oportet: ut ponas astellam desuper, et astellam aliam ab inferiori in planta: et sit manus aperta recta.	But if the fracture is towards the outside, then you should place a splint above and another below at the palm; and let the hand be held straight with fingers extended.
Deinde pone stricturam, sicut reuoluitur manus: et extende inter digitos cum ligamento.	Then apply a bandage in the same way as the hand is wound, and extend it between the fingers with a ligament.
Quod si accidat fractura alicui nodorum digitorum, tunc si est pollex, aequetur secundum quod oportet.	If some of the joints of the fingers are broken, then if it is the thumb, set it according to what is appropriate.
Deinde stringatur cum planta: et si amas, pone ei astellam rectam, paruam: ut eleuetur fractura, et non moueatur.	Then bind it with a splint: and if necessary, place a small straight splint so that the fracture is elevated and not moved.
Si autem fractura est reliquis digitis, sicut medio, et indici, aut auriculari, et anulari, tunc aequetur, et ligetur cum digito sano qui sequitur eum: aut ligentur omnes secundum continuationem: et est melius.	But if the fracture is in any of the other fingers such as the middle finger or the index finger, or the little finger and the ring finger, then it should be aligned and bound with the healthy finger that follows it; or all should be bound together in continuity, which is better.
Aut pone super ipsum astellam paruam, sicut diximus in pollice.	Or place over it a small splint as we have said for the thumb.
Et considera in restauratione tua, et post ipsam dispositionem apostematis calidi: et oppone cum eo quod oportet, quando accidit aliquid ex illo, secundum quod iteratur eius narratio.	And consider during your restoration, and after this arrangement, apply a warm poultice, and counterpose with what is appropriate when something happens from it, according to how its story repeats itself.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Coxae.	Paragraph: On the reduction of a fracture of the hip.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15
OS Coxae multotiens frangitur, et declaratur sensui: quoniam conuertitur ad interiorem et posteriorem partem.	The hip bone is often broken and it is apparent to the senses because it turns inward and backward.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, quod stringitur ligamentum supra fracturam, et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	And its reduction is done by binding one ligature above the fracture and another below it.
Et infirmus prostretur super faciem suam.	And the patient should lie face down.
Deinde extendat omne ligamentum minister ad partem suam secundum aequalitatem: et hoc, quando est fractura in medio ossis.	Then each assistant should stretch their ligature according to equality on their respective side when there is a fracture in the middle of the bone.
Si autem est fractura propinqua radici Coxae, tunc sit ligamentum ad partem pectinis, ut cadat extensio ad sursum: et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	But if there is a fracture near the root of the hip bone, then let one ligature be on the chest side so that the extension falls upwards and another ligature below the fracture.
Et sic similiter si est fractura propinqua genu, tunc sit ligamentum propinquum genu, ut sit extensio ad inferiora.	And similarly if there is a fracture near the knee, then let one ligature be near the knee so that the extension falls towards the lower part.
Deinde aequet medicus os utriusque manibus suis, donec reducat ipsum secundum similitudinem figurae naturalis: et coniugatur os coniunctione bona.	Then the physician should set the bone with both hands until it is reduced according to its natural shape and joined together with good union.
Tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum et stricturam, si non accidit membro apostema.	Then it is necessary to apply a poultice and bandage if there is no inflammation in the limb.
Quod si accidat in eo apostema: tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur apostema calidum, deinde redi ad curationem tuam.	If an abscess forms in him: then let it be for some days until the abscess becomes warm, then return to your treatment.
Strictura autem eius ita sit.	The bandage should be as follows
Oportet ut inuoluas super fracturam imema duram, id est, bindam: et dupla eam bis, aut ter: et remaneat ex ea superfluitas.	It is necessary to wrap a hard piece of wood over the fracture, that is, a splint; and fold it twice or thrice, with some excess remaining.
Deinde inuolue crus, donec perueniat calcaneus apud radicem natis.	Then wrap the leg until it reaches the heel at the ankle joint
Et intromitte filum longum inter Coxam et crus prope genu ad inferiora, et ueniant extremitates fili a superiori parte duarum partium.	Next, insert a long thread between the thigh and the leg near the knee towards the lower part, so that the ends of the thread come out from above on both sides.
Deinde reuolue super Crus et Coxam quod superfluit ex alimema.	Then wrap around the leg and thigh what is left over of the splint.
Deinde pone super Coxam in loco fracturae ipsius astellas, et pone ex eis astellam unam super os cruris.	Next, place stars on the thigh at the location of the fracture, and place one star on the bone of the leg.
Deinde imple uacuitates inter crus et coxam cum pannis lenibus, ut aequetur strictura.	Then fill the gaps between the leg and thigh with soft cloths so that the bandage is even.
Deinde incipe cum strictura forti a medio super locum fracturae tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor.	Next, begin with a firm wrapping from the middle over the fracture site with three or four turns.
Et quanto plus elongaris cum ligamento a loco fracturae, sit strictura tua minor et mollior, et lenior.	And as you extend the bandage further away from the fracture site, make your wrapping tighter and softer, and more gentle.
Deinde intende ad duas extremitates fili, quod tu intromisisti inter coxam et crus.	Then tie the two ends of the thread that you inserted between the thigh and leg.
Liga ergo cum utrisque tres astellas quae sunt desuper.	Therefore, tie three stars each with both threads from above.
Deinde uade cum duabus extremitatibus fili ad inferiora, donec peruenias ad cauillam pedis.	Then go down with the two ends of the thread until you reach the ankle bone.
Et cum utrisque stringe etiam extremitates astellarum a parte altera: ut non remoueatur ligamentum ex loco suo.	And tie both threads and also the ends of the stars on the other side so that the bandage does not move from its place.
Deinde dimitte stricturam super illud, dum permanet, ita quod non accidat membro corrosio, neque apostema, neque inflatio, et similia eis.	Then leave the bandage in place until healing occurs, ensuring that no injury, abscess, inflammation, or similar condition arises.
Quod si accidat aliquid ex illo.	If anything happens
Propera ergo cum solutione eius, et rectifica illud quod accidit inde totum, secundum quod diximus multotiens.	Then promptly come with its solution and correct whatever has happened according to what we have said many times.
Si uero in osse est frustum ex osse quod pungat: tunc oportet, ut aeques illud, si est tibi possibile.	But if there is a sharp fragment of bone sticking out, then it is necessary to smooth it down if possible.
Et si non, finde super illud, et remoue illud: et cura cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio, donec sanetur.	And if not, cover it with a bandage and remove it: and treat him according to what has preceded until he is healed.
Et quandoque stringitur haec fractura Coxae, praeter quod addantur ei astellae, sicut diximus in adiutorio et brachio.	And sometimes this fracture of the hip becomes dislocated, besides those added ligatures, as we have mentioned in the aid and the arm.
Verumtamen in restauratione eius taliter fracta, non accidit infirmo claudicatio.	However, upon its restoration, it does not happen that the patient limps.
Et si restauratur sola, praeter quod applicetur ei crus alterum, tunc necesse est, ut claudicet ille cuius est, semper.	But if it is restored alone, without applying the other leg to it, then it is necessary for him whose it is to limp always.
Et scias, quod Coxa stringitur in quinquaginta diebus, uel additur parum, aut minuitur parum: totum illud est secundum diuersitatem complexionum, et reliquarum dispositionum.	And know that the hip is dislocated for fifty days or it may be added a little or diminished a little: all this depends on the diversity of temperaments and other dispositions.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Rotulae genu.	On the restoration of the fracture of the knee-cap.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI
Scias, quod Rotulae genu raro accidit fractura, sed accidit ei attritio multotiens.	Know that a fracture of the patella rarely occurs, but wear often does.
Si uero accidit ei fractura, tunc non nisi aut fissura, aut foramen in partibus suis.	But if it occurs to it [the patella], then there is only either a crack or a hole in its parts.
Et est illud cum uulnere, et absque uulnere.	And this occurs with a wound and without a wound
Et statur super illud totum cum sensu.	And it stands on top of it all with sensation.
Et restauratio eius est ita, ut aequetur quod disruptum est ex partibus eius cum digitis, donec aggregetur, et coniungatur secundum quod possibile est ex aequatione et facilitate, et fabricatione.	And its restoration is such that what was broken off from its parts should be made even with it using fingers until it adheres and joins together according to the possibility of making even and easy [and] fashioning.
Deinde pone emplastrum ex farina sisami, uel molendini, cum albumine oui: et pone super ipsum astellam rotundam, si indiges illa: et stringe desuper strictura conueniente ad illud.	Then apply a plaster of sesame flour or fine flour with egg white and place over it a round bandage if you need one, and bind it with an appropriate ligature.
Deinde considera omnes dispositiones quas narrauimus in reliquis fracturis: sicut apostema calidum, et similia illi: ita, ut opponas omni accidenti cum eo quod conuenit ei, donec sanetur.	Then consider all the dispositions that we have described in other fractures, such as warm inflammation and similar ones, so that you may oppose every accident with what is fitting for it until it heals.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Cruris.	On the restoration of the fracture of the leg
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII
Scias, quod Cruri sunt duo ossa, quorum unum est grossum, et nominatur nomine Cruris: et alterum subtile, et nominatur Focile.	Know that there are two bones in the leg, one thick called the tibia and the other thin called the fibula.
Et accidit utrisque ex speciebus fracturae quod accidit duobus ossibus brachii: et propter illud fit restauratio eius, sicut restauratio brachii aequaliter, et operatio est una.	And similarly for both types of fractures that occur in the two bones of the arm, restoration is done equally and the operation is one.
Quod si franguntur duo ossa simul, conuertitur Crus ad omnes partes.	If both bones are broken at once, the leg becomes disabled on all sides.
Et si frangitur os subtilius, conuertitur Crus ad anteriorem partem.	And if only the thin bone is fractured, the leg turns towards the front.
Et si frangitur os grossius, inuenis illud inferius: et est ex eis quae non occultantur tibi.	And if the thick bone is fractured, you will find it below and it is one of those that do not hide from you.
Deinde administra extensionem, et aequationem, et ligationem astellarum secundum illud aequaliter.	Then apply extension, alignment, and wiring according to what is equal in the two bones.
Verumtamen oportet, si fractura Cruris est fractura foeda, habens sethagie multa: ut sit extensio minor, et lenior alleuiatione tua.	However, if it is a nasty fracture of the leg with many splinters, then extension should be less and gentle in easing.
Et in Crure quidem est ex operatione quiddam super brachium: et est, ut quando tu aequas astellas, et comples omnem operationem tuam, tunc accipe duas fascias ex ligno pini, quod administratur in fabricatione solariorum quod ponitur sub tabulis: et fiunt ex spatulis palmae: et elige ex eis quibus est grossitudo parua, et neque sint ex minutis: et sit longitudo earum secundum longitudinem Cruris a genu usque inferius.	And in the leg there is something similar to what is done on the arm. And it should be that when you align the splints and complete all your operation, then take two strips of pinewood used for making soles and put them under the table boards: and make them from the palm-sized ones. Choose those which are not too thin nor too small and let their length be equal to the length of the leg from the knee downwards.
Deinde inuolue super unamquamque pannum duabus inuolutionibus secundum longitudinem eius.	Then wrap each bandage around twice according to its length.
Et pone unam partem Cruris a parte una, et alteram a parte altera: et sint ex genu usque inferius pedis.	And place one part of the leg on one side and the other on the other side from the knee down to the foot.
Deinde liga duas fascias in tribus locis ex duabus extremitatibus et medio.	Then tie the two bands at three points, at both ends and in the middle.
Cum enim strictura prohibetur, Crus declinat ad dextram et sinistram, et stat statione bona.	For when the tying is tightened, the leg inclines to the right and left, but it stands in good position.
Et iam quidem administretur cunabulum ex ligno secundum longitudinem Cruris, et ponatur in eo Crus, ut conseruet ipsum a motu.	And now a splint made of wood according to the length of the leg should be applied and the leg placed on it so that it may keep it from moving.
Et plurimum quidem oportet, ut facias illud in fractura quando cum ea est uulnus proprie.	But especially it is necessary to do this when there is a wound along with the fracture.
Deinde considera Crus in omni die, et stude cum eo studio ultimo ab apostemate, aut inflatione, aut reliquis aliis.	Then observe the leg every day, and give it your utmost care from the time of amputation or inflation, or any other cause.
Si ergo accidit aliquid ex illis, tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur, si Deus uoluerit.	If any of those things happen, then apply to it what is necessary until it heals, God willing.
De fractura ossium Pedis, et Digitorum.	On the fracture of bones in the foot and toes
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18
Calcaneo quidem non accidit fractura penitus.	Indeed, there has never been a case of a calcaneus bone being fractured.
Ossibus uero Pedis accidit quandoque fractura, et Digitis parum etiam accidit fractura: et non accidit eis nisi attritio in pluribus dispositionibus.	But sometimes fracture occurs in the bones of the foot and even rarely in the toes; and they are mostly subjected to sprains in many positions.
Quod si accidit ossibus Pedis fractura, et uides illa ossa sublimari super se adinuicem, tunc ponat infirmus Pedem suum super terram praeparatam, sicut ambulans.	But if fracture occurs in the bones of the foot and you see those bones raised above each other, then let the patient place their foot on the ground as if walking.
Deinde sta tu, et pone Pedem tuum super illud quod eleuatur ex illis ossibus: postea preme, uel calca eam: et aequa ipsam, donec redeat in locis suis.	Then stand and place your foot on that bone which is raised among them; then press or step on it until it returns to its proper position.
Deinde pone emplastrum, et stuppam desuper: et pone sub uentre Pedis tabulam paruam, cui sint duo capita plana.	Then apply a poultice and lay a wick on top of it; and place a small board with two flat heads under the sole of the foot.
Deinde stringe eam cum Pede strictura decenti, postquam tu inuoluis eam cum pannis, et reliquis quibus indiget.	Then bind it firmly with the foot, after you have wrapped it with cloths and other things needed.
Cum ergo praetereunt ei tres dies, aut quatuor, tunc solue ligamentum.	After three or four days have passed, then remove the bandage.
Nam tu inuenies ossa aequata, siue sint fracta, aut sint dislocata.	For you will find the bones set right, whether they were fractured or dislocated.
Operatio ergo in eis est, sicut uides.	Therefore, operate on them as you see fit.
Si autem franguntur aliqui digiti, tunc restaura eos, et aequa ipsos secundum quod narraui tibi in restauratione digitorum manus.	But if some of the toes are broken, then restore them and set them straight according to what I have told you about the restoration of fingers.
Deinde pone digito tuo astellam secundum longitudinem digiti, et sit latior eo parumper: deinde pone sub Pede hanc tabulam quam narraui tibi, et stringe eam strictura decenti.	Then place your finger on the top of the toe according to its length and let it be a little wider; then place that board which I told you about under the foot and bind it firmly with a suitable bandage.
Si uero quod frangitur ex ossibus est duo, aut tria, aut plus, tunc pone super omnem digitum astellam suae quantitatis, inuolutam in panno lini: et stringe tabulam in inferiori Pedis: et sit stans super unum capitum tabulae extra uentrem Pedis, ut teneat retentione bona.	But if two or three or more of the bones are broken, then place a splint suitable to each toe wrapped in linen on top of them; and bind the board under the foot and let it stand on one head of the board outside the sole of the foot so that it holds it firmly.
Et conuenit tibi, ut non obliuiscaris, quin consideres omnia quae dixi tibi in reliquis fracturis ex accidentibus quae diximus: et oppone omni accidenti cum eo quod oportet.	And you should not forget to consider all that I have told you about other fractures from accidents which we discussed, and apply each appropriate remedy.
¶ De fractura Vuluae mulieris, et ossis pectinis, et uirgae uiri.	On the fracture of a woman's vulva, and of the breastbone, and of the male pubic bone.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Quando frangitur Vulua mulieris, tunc fac eam sedere quadratam.	When the vulva of a woman is fractured, then make her sit on a square cushion.
Deinde inclina eam ad partem dorsi ipsius parumper, et teneatur retro.	Then tilt her backwards slightly towards her back and hold it there.
Deinde impleat obstetrix Vuluam eius coto, donec impleat eam: et fiat in Vulua ex eo sicut sphera.	Next, the midwife should fill the woman's vulva with cotton until it is full; and let it be formed into a ball-like shape in the vulva.
Deinde concutiatur mulier, et eleua dorsum eius paulatim.	Then shake the woman gently, and gradually lift up her back.
Illud enim cotum egreditur, donec fiat ante portam Vuluae sicut sphera, et os fractum redit.	For that cotton comes out until it forms a ball-like shape before the vulva, and the broken bone returns to its place.
Deinde pone puluillum super dorsum eius.	Then place a pillow on her back.
Quando ergo uult mingere, remoueat cotum cum facilitate, deinde mingat: et reduc ipsum secundum modum, quo intromisisti ipsum in primis: deinde redeat ad puluillum suum primum.	When she wants to urinate, let her remove the cotton gently, then urinate; and replace it according to how you first inserted it. Then return to her pillow.
Faciat illud septem diebus, aut circiter, os ipsum enim restauratur.	She should do this for about seven days, after which the bone will be healed.
Et si uis, accipe uesicam ouis, et stringe super foramen eius cannulam arundinis, et intromitte uesicam totam in Vuluam eius.	And if you wish, take the bladder of a sheep and tie a reed tube over its opening, then insert the whole bladder into her vulva.
Deinde suffla in cannulam cum uirtute, donec infletur uesica intra Vuluam, fractura enim redit.	Then blow air through the tube with force until the bladder expands within the vulva, for the fracture will be reduced.
Deinde impleatur cum coto, et stet aliquot diebus, secundum quod narrauimus, donec sanetur.	Then fill it with cotton and let her remain like that for several days, as we have described, until she is healed.
Et quando frangitur os Pectinis uiri, aut mulieris, tunc administra in restauratione eius, et ipsius aequatione illud quod narrauimus in osse Anchae.	And when the breastbone of a man or woman is fractured, then use for its reduction and alignment what we have described for the bone of the ankle.
Et non occultatur rectum in his fracturis propinquis, quae parum contingunt, praecipue cui est quiddam studii, uel usus.	And it is not hidden that there is no rectitude in these fractures if they are near each other, especially in those who have some practice or use.
Et intellige librum meum istum multum, quoniam fractura ipsa significat tibi in pluribus dispositionibus uiam rectam in restauratione sui, et strictura sui: intellige ergo.	And understand my book much, for the fracture itself indicates to you in many dispositions the straight path towards its restoration and tightening: therefore, understand.
In Virga autem uiri quando frangitur, accipe guttur anseris: et intromitte uirgam in ipso.	In the case of a fractured penis, take the neck of a goose and insert the stick into it.
Deinde pone super ipsum inuolutionem ex panno, et inuoluatur, et dimittatur tribus diebus, aut circiter eos, et sanabitur, si Deus uoluerit.	Then place over it a wrapping made of cloth, wrap it around, and let it remain for three days or thereabouts, and it will be healed if God wills.
¶ De restauratione fracturae ossium, quando est cum uulnere.	¶ On the restoration of bone fractures when they are accompanied by wounds.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20
Conuenit ei cui accidit fractura cum uulnere, praecipue si est magnum, sicut os coxae, aut adiutorii, aut simile illi, ut properes, et phlebotomes ipsum statim: si attestantur tibi conditiones phlebotomiae, sicut praemisimus.	It is fitting for one who suffers a fracture accompanied by a wound, especially if it is large like that of the thighbone or shinbone, etc., to perform bloodletting on them immediately: if you find the conditions favorable for bloodletting, as we have previously mentioned.
Quod si uulnus effluit sanguinem, tunc oportet, ut properes ad abscisionem eius, ita ut puluerizes super ipsum zegi tritum: si non est tibi praesens aliud.	But if the wound is flowing blood, then it is necessary that you quickly proceed to cauterize it, using powdered myrrh if nothing else is available.
Deinde incipe restaurare fracturam in illo eodem die: et non postponas illud, si non accidit apostema.	Then begin restoring the fracture on the same day itself, and do not postpone this unless gangrene occurs.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte restaurationem eius usque ad diem nonum, donec sedetur apostema.	But if gangrene is warm, then delay its restoration until the ninth day until it settles down.
Et non appropinques ei in die tertio, et quarto omnino, nam tu faceres ei accidere accidentia mala.	And do not approach him on the third and fourth days entirely, for you would cause him harm thereby.
Si autem os fractum est eminens super cutem detectum: tunc oportet, ut coneris reducere ipsum, et aequare ipsum manibus tuis cum facilitate et extensione parua.	But if the fractured bone is protruding from the skin and exposed, then it is necessary that you try to reduce and align it with your hands using gentle pressure.
Si autem non praeparatur extensio eius, et ipsius aequatio manibus tuis: tunc reduc ipsum cum isto instrumento.	But if its extension and alignment cannot be prepared by hand, then reduce it using this instrument.
Et est instrumentum quod fit ex ferro, cuius longitudo est quantitas septem digitorum, aut octo: et eius latitudo est secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And there is an instrument made of iron, its length being that of seven fingers or eight, and its width according to the size of the wound.
Et propter illud necesse est medico, ut accipiat ex eis tria, aut quatuor secundum quantitatem qua indiget ad illud ex curatione in omni specie fracturae.	Therefore, it is necessary for the physician to take three or four of these according to the quantity needed for that treatment in all kinds of fractures.
Et sit rotundum: et sit in eo grossitudo parua, ut non duplicetur apud compressionem super ipsum in hora operationis: et sit acutae extremitatis, cui sit margo in extremitatibus suis.	And it should be round, with a small thickness so that it does not double over upon itself during compression at the time of operation; and it should have a sharp point at both ends.
Et sit superius eius ad grossitudinem ex medietate eius usque ad inferiora.	Its upper part should be thick from its middle to its lower end.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its shape.
Oportet in Hac Operatione, ut ponatur extremitas eius acuta curuata super extremitatem ossis eminentis: et impelle ipsum cum eo uice una, donec quando redit os et aequatur quadam aequatione.	In this operation, place its sharp curved end over the prominent end of the bone and push it with one stroke until the bone returns to its proper alignment.
Conare ergo aequare extremitates fracturae adinuicem.	Therefore, strive to align the ends of the fracture together.
Quod si extremitates eius fracta est subtilis, et non accipit eam instrumentum accaeptione bona, tunc opotet, ut incidas extremitatem illius ossis, donec instrumentum potestatem habeat eius.	But if the ends of the fracture are too thin and do not accept the instrument well, then you should cut off the end of that bone until the instrument can grasp it.
Si uero non potes reducere eos cum eo quod narrauimus omnino, tunc incide ipsum cum eo quod conuenit ei ex Incisoriis quae diximus: aut serra ipsum cum una serrarum quocunque modo possibile est tibi.	But if you cannot reduce them at all with the instrument described above, then cut it with a suitable knife from those mentioned earlier, or saw it with any saw in whatever way is possible for you.
Deinde rade illud quod remanet in osse ex asperitate et corticibus minutis.	Then shave off what remains on the bone, such as any roughness and small ridges.
Cum ergo reducitur os, et inuenit infirmus post reductionem eius dolorem uehementem laedentem, tunc scias, quod os non rediit ad locum suum naturalem.	When the bone is reduced but the patient still feels intense pain after the reduction, know that the bone has not been returned to its natural place.
Fac ergo illud.	Then do this:
Nam tu confers infirmo iuuamentum magnum, cum completur restauratio tua quam facis ossi.	For you should give the patient a large splint when the restoration of the bone which you are performing is completed.
Tunc submerge pannum in uino stiptico, nigro.	Then dip a cloth in black wine vinegar.
Et proprie si est in aestate.	Especially if it is summertime.
Et non ponas super uulnus caerotum, neque aliquid in quo sit oleum: ut non faciat accidere in ipso putredinem et corruptionem.	And do not place anything oily on the wound, nor anything containing oil, lest it cause putrefaction and corruption to occur in it.
Deinde administra astellas in hora complementi tui a restauratione ossis.	Then administer astragalus (castor bean) poultice at the hour of bone restoration.
Et dimitte uulnus detectum: ita, ut incidas cum forficibus foramen in inuolutionibus secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And leave the wound open; thus, cut with scissors a hole in its folds according to the size of the wound.
Et caue omni cautela, ne stringas uulnus cum fractura.	And beware of all caution not to bind a wound that has been fractured.
Multotiens enim fecerunt istud stolidi medici: et fecerunt accidere super infirmos suos aut mortem, aut corrosionem, aut zuchem, id est, saniem.	For many foolish physicians have done this and brought about the death of their patients or corruption or pus.
Et sit strictura tua mollis, lenis, diuersa stricturae fracturarum reliquarum.	And let your binding be soft, gentle, and different from the bindings used for other fractures.
Quod si uulnus est malum, aut est uulnus magnum, et times super ipsum quaedam accidentia mala quae narrauimus, et inuenis dolorem in loco suspensum: tunc non oportet, ut ponas super ipsum astellas.	But if the wound is bad or large, and you fear that certain ill accidents may occur as we have described, and you find pain suspended in its place, then it is not necessary to apply an astragalus poultice.
Et fac eis inuolutiones ex pannis duris in loco astellarum, et stringe ipsum cum eis.	And make them dressings of hard cloths in the place of the astragalus poultice, and bind it with these.
Cum autem est post diem unum, aut dies duos, et uides uulnus iam incipere, ut in eo generetur pus: tunc aufer desuper ipsum pannum quem posuisti super ipsum cum uino.	But when after one day or two days you see that the wound is beginning to generate pus, then remove the cloth which you placed upon it with wine.
Deinde administra licinia, et unguenta cum quibus de consuetudine nostra est, ut medicemur uulnera: sicut unguentum tetrapharmacon, et similia illi.	Then apply lint and ointments according to our customary practice for treating wounds, such as the ointment Tetrapharmacon, and similar ones.
Et conuenit tibi, ut soluas ligamentum.	And it is fitting for you to loosen the bandage.
Et considera uulnus in omni die mane et uespere, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	And examine the wound every morning and evening until it solidifies and heals.
Et oportet, ut praeparetur membrum taliter, ut currat ex eo pus ad inferiora cum facilitate.	It is necessary to prepare the limb in such a way that pus flows out of it freely towards the lower parts.
Quod si praetereunt uulneri dies multi, et non consolidatur, neque abscinditur pus ab eo: tunc scias, quod illic sunt satagie ossis parua.	But if many days pass without the wound healing or the pus being discharged from it, then know that there are small bone spurs present.
Quare oportet, ut inquiras uulnus cum tenta.	Therefore, you should examine the wound with probes.
Quot uero ex illis alsatagie sunt separata, remoue ea, et extrahe ipsa.	How many of those bone spurs are separated off, remove them and extract them out.
Et quae ex eis sunt non separata, et pungunt membrum, et faciunt accidere dolorem, conare incidere ea, et auferre ea omni modo quo possibile est tibi illud.	And those that are not separated off but cause pain in the limb and bring about suffering, attempt to cut them open and remove them in any way possible for you.
Quod si accidat uulneri zuchen, aut ekileten, id est, estiomenus, aut species alia corruptionis et putrefactionis: tunc oportet, ut opponas unicuique ex eis cum eo quod conuenit ei ex curatione, cuius praecessit narratio in capitulo suo.	But if a wound is inflicted by a weapon or ulceration occurs, that is, gangrene appears or another type of corruption and putrefaction: then it is necessary to apply remedies suited to each case with their appropriate treatment, the order of which has been described in its respective chapter.
Et ex eo in quo oportet ut stet sermo meus, et cui facias praesentem mentem tuam quando frangitur os, et eminet super membrum, sicut os coxae, et adiutorii, et similia eis ex membris magnis, est, ut non praesumas attractionem eius, multotiens enim accidit ex illo mors, imo dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat.	And in those cases where it is necessary for my speech to remain steady and when you have full attention upon breaking a bone that protrudes from the limb, such as the thighbone or shinbone, and similar bones from major limbs, do not attempt to reduce it by traction, for many times death has occurred because of this, rather leave it alone until it putrefies.
Fortasse enim cadet per se post uiginti dies, aut triginta.	For perhaps it will fall off on its own after twenty or thirty days.
Tunc ergo cura uulnus, si uidetur tibi: et sinon, dimitte ipsum.	Then treat the wound if you think fit, otherwise leave it alone.
¶ De curatione Nodationis in uestigio fracturae.	On the treatment of swelling at the site of a fracture.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21
Multoties accidit haec Nodatio in uestigio sanationis fracturae.	Many times this swelling occurs at the site of a healing fracture
Praecipue, quae est prope iuncturas: et foedatur ex ea figura membri.	Especially those near joints: and it produces a distorted shape of the limb.
Et fortasse prohibet membrum ab operatione sua naturali.	And perhaps it prevents the limb from functioning naturally
Considera ergo tunc, si nodatio est recens: administra in ea medicinas quae stipticitatem habent, sicut aloe, et olibanum, et myrrha, et sarcocolla, et acacia, et similia eis.	Therefore, if the swelling is recent, apply medicines that have an astringent effect, such as: aloe, frankincense, myrrh, tragacanth, and acacia, among others.
Ita, ut accipias ex istis quasdam, aut omnes eas: et confice eas cum uino stiptico, aut cum albumine oui, aut cum aceto: et pone eas super nodationem in stuppa, et stringe eas super ipsam strictura bona.	Thus take some or all of these ingredients and mix them with astringent wine, egg white, or vinegar. Then apply the mixture on linen to the swelling and secure it in place with a good bandage
Et dimitte stricturam, nec soluas eam diebus multis.	And leave the bandage untouched for many days without removing it
Deinde solue eam, et itera aliam, donec remoueatur nodatio.	Then remove it and apply another one until the swelling disappears
Aut stringe super ipsam laminam plumbi decenter.	Or bind a lead plate upon it appropriately.
Plumbo enim est proprietas remouendi omne quod timetur ex membris.	For lead has the property of drawing out anything feared from the limbs.
Si autem nodatio iam in lapidem conuersa est, et stricta est, et festine prouocat necessitas ad auferendum eam: tunc finde super eam ex superiori parte eius, et incide superfluitatem eminentem: aut rade eam cum quibusdam rasoriis, donec remoueatur: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	But if the swelling has already turned into a hard lump and is pressing urgently for removal, then lay an incision over it from above and cut away the superfluous protruding part; or shave it with some razors until it is removed. And take care of it until it heals.
¶ De curatione quando restauratur, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, non secundum naturam suam.	Here ends the treatment when the restoration is made and the limb remains afterwards thin, not according to its nature.
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22.
Quando restauratur fractura ossis, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, debile: tunc non fit illud nisi propter caussas multas.	When a fracture of the bone is restored and the limb remains afterwards thin and weak, this happens only for many reasons.
Quarum una est, multitudo solutionis ligamenti et ligationis eius non secundum quod oportet: aut propter superfluitatem stricturae ligamentorum, donec prohibeatur nutrimentum currere ad membrum: aut propter multitudinem embrocationis superfluae in non sua hora: aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore infirmi, et debilitatem eius.	One of these reasons is an excessive loosening and tightening of the ligaments not done as it should be; or because of an excess in constricting the ligaments so that nourishment cannot reach the limb; or because of an excessive use of ointments at the wrong time; or because of a scarcity of blood in the patient's body and his overall weakness.
Et curatio illius est, cibare infirmum, et tenerum facere corpus eius, donec multiplicetur sanguis in eo.	The treatment for this is to feed the patient and make his body soft until his blood increases.
Et administra balneum.	And administer a bath.
Et intromitte gaudium et laeticiam super eum.	And bring him joy and gladness.
Deinde pone picem super membrum: ut attrahat pix ad ipsum nutrimentum multum.	Then apply pitch on the limb so that it attracts much nourishment to itself.
Et assiduet embrocationem eius cum aqua tepida, donec currat nutrimentum, et redeat ad figuram suam naturalem.	And continue applying warm water ointments to it until nourishment flows and the limb returns to its natural shape.
¶ De curatione ossium fractorum quando restaurantur tortuose.	Here ends the treatment of bones that are restored crookedly.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23
Quando accidit membro iam restaurato post sanationem eius tortuositas, et eminentia ossi fracto, aut nodatio: et foedatur per illud forma membri, uerumtamen membrum non prohibetur ab operatione sua naturali: tunc non oportet ut recipias sermonem eius, qui existimat, ut frangatur membrum denuo.	When it happens that a limb is restored crookedly after its healing and there is prominence of the broken bone or swelling which disfigures the limb but does not prevent it from functioning naturally, then you should not pay heed to anyone who suggests breaking the limb again.
Et iam fuerunt multi stolidorum medicorum et restauratorum, qui fecerunt illud in terra nostra.	And there have been many foolish doctors and bone-setters who have done this in our land.
Et haec quidem operatio est uituperabilis ualde, perducens ad mortem, uel timorem magnum, ut scilicet sit mortalis.	Indeed, this operation is very blameworthy, leading to death or great fear, so that it may be fatal.
Verum si claudicatio et nodatio sunt recentes: tunc oportet, ut embrocetur cum aqua tepida, in qua decoctae sint herbae mollificantes, sicut folia alteae, et radix eius, et mellilotum, et illis similia.	But if the limp and stiffness are recent, then it is necessary to treat with warm water in which soothing herbs have been cooked, such as mallow leaves and roots, and marsh-mallows, and similar ones.
Et fiat ei emplastrum cum emplastro mollificatiuo, sicut dyachilon decenter factum.	And make for him an ointment with a softening plaster, such as well-made wax ointment.
Aut sumatur mucilago radicis alteae, et concutiatur cum adipe gallinae, aut oleo sisamino: et emplastretur cum eo.	Or take the mucilage of mallows' roots and beat it with chicken fat or sesame oil, and plaster it on.
Aut sumantur ficus pingues, et terantur cum fimo columbino, et similibus eis quae nominantur ex medicinis diminuentes consolidationem.	Or take ripe figs, grind them with pigeon dung and other substances which are named among medicines that reduce hardness.
Et quandoque soluitur nodatio cum fricatione assidua, antiqua, et leni, quae fit cum manibus humidis.	And sometimes stiffness is loosened by persistent, gentle friction using wet hands.
Et administretur motus membri ad omnem partem in horis omnibus.	And movement of the limb should be encouraged towards all parts at all times.
Si autem tortuositas iam antecessit, et fortis facta est, et conuersa est in lapidem, et prouocata est necessitas ad curatonem eius cum ferro: tunc oportet, ut secetur superius eius, et soluatur continuatio ossis, et incidatur quod superfluit ex nodatione aut osse cum Incisoriis subtilibus: et administretur facilitas in illo cum sollicitudine et studio.	But if twisting has already preceded and become strong and turned into a stone, and there is need for its treatment with iron: then it must be cut above it, and the continuity of bone must be loosened, and what has flowed out from stiffness or bone must be cut away with fine cutters: and care must be taken to facilitate movement in it.
¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	¶ On the subject of dislocation.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	Dislocation is the displacement of one or more joints from their normal position.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	Therefore it prevents movement and spoils the appearance of the limb.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	And causes sharp pains and severe injuries to occur in the patient.
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	Therefore when dislocation occurs it is necessary to hasten its reduction without any delay.
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	For if there is delay, the place becomes inflamed, and perhaps also the reduction of the dislocation itself.
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	Therefore it should not be moved or extended during the inflammation period.
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	For often it causes spasms and painful injuries.
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	But when this happens, then you should proceed to perform bloodletting on the patient.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	Then it should be left alone until the inflammation subsides.
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	Then the limb should be rubbed with warm water and oil.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	Then it should be gently reduced (i.e., placed back in its proper position).
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And the entire limb should be wrapped along with that which is to be remembered in its place.
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	Indeed, I have already arranged the chapters on dislocations, also according to what precedes in fractures, from the upper part of the body down to its lower part.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	Chapter: On the treatment of dislocation of the lower jaw.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	The two jaws rarely dislocate, except in rare cases.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	And dislocation of both occurs according to one of two methods.
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	Either they are removed from their places by a slight movement and softened for a short time;
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	The shoulder joints are dislocated completely, until they become softened towards the chest area, until the sick person runs and cannot hold it or close their mouth, and their tongue becomes twisted with speech.
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	If the dislocation is minor, it returns to its original state more often on its own with less effort.
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	If the dislocation is complete and intact, then it is necessary for reduction to be administered quickly and not delayed at all. And so the attendant should hold the patient's head, and the physician should insert their thumb of one hand into the root of the jawbone on the side of the dislocation.
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	Or they may insert both thumbs simultaneously if the dislocation is on both sides.
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	And the remaining fingers of their hands should be outside where it is suitable.
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	Instruct the patient to cleanse and rinse out their jaws thoroughly on all sides.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the physician should place the jawbone in its proper position and press it until it returns to its original place.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	But if the reduction is difficult, especially if both jawbones are dislocated at once, then administer a warm vapor with water and oil until the reduction becomes easier for both. And do not delay the reduction of both at all, as we have said.
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	When they have returned to their proper places and the patient's mouth is closed and no longer feels soft, then place over them small pads of linen with wax prepared with rose oil.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	Then it should be bandaged gently with soft bindings.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	And let the patient sleep on their back with their head supported between two pillows so that they do not move it to the right or left. They should not attempt to chew anything and should be given only soft food until the pain has subsided and the jawbone is healed, at which point they may eat what they wish without difficulty.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	He should not exert himself in eating, drinking, and yawning until the jawbone is healed.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	But if the reduction of the two jawbones proves difficult when they are dislocated at some hour and do not return to their places, then fever and frequent sighing may occur, and perhaps the sick person's stomach will be loosened, and perhaps they may vomit pure bile.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	Therefore, when you see that [the condition], know that it is fatal, and often the person to whom it happens dies within ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	On the reduction of dislocation of the shoulder blade and end of the arm.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The collarbone does not dislocate from its inner side due to its continuity with the chest.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	And sometimes it dislocates outwards; this is evident to the senses.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	To reduce it, have the patient lie on their back and stretch out their arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then press the spot firmly with your palm, for it will return to its place.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then apply a plaster and bandages, and bind it.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	The ends of the bone that follow the elbow and are connected to it rarely dislocate.
Quod s dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	If it does dislocate on some day, then it must be reduced and set according to what we have said, and what is prepared for you.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then apply a plaster, bandages, and a splint.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And instruct the patient to remain calm and quiet until it heals.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And with this same treatment, the end of the arm is reduced when it becomes separated from its place as well.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	On the Reduction of Dislocation of the Arm
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	You should know that the arm does not dislocate except in three ways:
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	One of which is, that it dislocates towards the region of the armpit below.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	The second is, that it dislocates towards the chest area.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps it dislocates to the upper part of the arm bone, which occurs rarely.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	It does not dislocate towards the back due to the spur.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And it does not dislocate forwards due to the nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	Indeed, it most often dislocates and comes out towards the armpit below, especially in those whose flesh is thin.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	Because it goes out quickly and enters quickly in them.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	But in those whose flesh is much, it is the opposite of that, namely that it goes out with difficulty and enters with difficulty.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And perhaps some people suffer an injury or accident, and the arm bone becomes swollen with a hot swelling, and it is thought because of this that it has already been dislocated.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	Therefore, you should examine it until you stand on its certainty, and then proceed with its treatment.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	And dislocation is recognized when it is towards the armpit below, and you should distinguish between the dislocated arm bone and the healthy one.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	For you will find a clear difference between them, and you will find a depression in the head of the arm bone, and under the armpit upon touching the head of the humerus as if it were an egg: and the sick person cannot bring their hand to their ear nor move it with all movements.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	And similarly, if it is dislocated towards the chest or upwards, then you will find a clear touch upon feeling, and it cannot be hidden.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	The reduction of this dislocation is easy when it is recent, or if the sick person is a child.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	And its reduction is performed by raising one's hand upward.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	Then place your thumbs under the armpit and raise the joint with force upward to its proper position; and the assistant shall raise their hand and stretch it upward.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	Then place it below; for it quickly returns to its place by itself.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	But if it does not return through what we have said, and many days have passed since the dislocation occurred at first, then it is necessary for the sick person to bathe in warm water, and to administer an ointment which softens and soothes, such as if the roots of althea, fennel, and melilot are decocted in water.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	Then the sick person is placed on their back; and under their armpit, place a ball and wool that are equal in softness and firmness.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	Then the physician places their heel on the ball and raises the head of the shoulder joint with strength, while pulling the sick person's hand downward.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	And another assistant holds the head of the sick person so that it does not move downward; for it immediately returns to its place.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	And if you wish, reduce it in this manner: have someone present who is taller than the sick person stand on their side and insert their shoulder under the armpit of the sick person; then raise the armpit upward until the sick person is suspended in mid-air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	And another assistant pulls the hand of the sick person downward towards their belly.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	But if the sick person is light, then something else must be suspended with them to weigh them down; for the dislocation immediately returns.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	And it is also reduced in another manner: place on the ground a long piece of wood with a rounded head, like the pestle of a mortar, which is neither too thick nor too thin.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	Then place beneath the sick person soft cloths on top of the head of the wood, with the sick person standing along the length of the wood.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then stretch out their hand towards the lower part on the other side and stretch out their body with force from the other side; for the joint will return to its place quickly.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	But if its reduction is difficult by all that we have said, then use this remedy: Take a piece of wood whose length is the measure of two arms, and its width the measure of four fingers, and its thickness the measure of two fingers, with a rounded head to facilitate its entry into the depths of the joint, in this shape.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	Then wrap soft cloths around the round head of the wood so that it does not harm the sick person.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	Then place the wood under the joint of the sick person so that their hand or arm is stretched out over it towards the lower part and tie the wood to their arm and the end of their hand.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	Then place the arm on the step of a ladder along its width, stretch out the hand towards the lower part, and let the rest of the body hang down on the other side.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	The joint enters immediately.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	Therefore, when the entry of the joint is complete in whichever way is possible, then place under the joint a ball of equal size made of wool.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	Then apply the plaster prepared from flour with frankincense and egg white over the entire shoulder, as it rolls down from above.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	Then bind with a suitable bandage under the joint and wrap it around the plaster from above; and tie their hand to their neck, and let it remain without moving for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	And food should be given sparingly to the sick person until the member is strengthened; because it is quicker for its healing.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	Then increase food after seven days or five, and encourage movement.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	If it becomes firm and not softened, then it is already healed.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	But if the joint is dislocated repeatedly due to moisture that affects it or another cause, then a cautery with three holes should be applied to it, as prescribed in the chapter on cauteries.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	But if all this is done and the bandage is removed after seven days, and the joint does not firm up, and the plaster and bandage are reapplied repeatedly, and it still falls and cannot be raised upwards, then know that its nerves which are at the head of the shoulder have either been cut or stretched or softened; and know that the joint will never return to its place.
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	The dislocation which occurs towards the chest and nipple or reduction to the back happens with pressure and extension using hands until it returns, and then apply the remaining bandage and care until it heals.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	If heaviness occurs in the member after healing and slowness of movement happens, then the sick person should take a bath many times until that heaviness is relieved and it returns to its original nature.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	On the treatment of elbow dislocation.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	Know that the elbow joint is dislocated with difficulty and returns with difficulty as well; indeed it can be dislocated in all directions, but especially towards the front or back.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	And its dislocation will not remain hidden from you; for it is evident to sight and touch, in whatever form it may be dislocated.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	And when you relocate a dislocated elbow joint, it becomes clearly apparent.
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	For the joint is caved in and cannot bend the arm nor touch its own humerus.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you act quickly to reduce the dislocation before heat and inflammation occur.
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	For if heat and inflammation occur, reduction becomes difficult; and perhaps it will not heal entirely, especially when the dislocation is towards the back.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	Indeed, among all kinds of dislocations, this one is the most severe and causes greater pain; and death often occurs alongside it.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.
